title: 9Â  Signal Categorization
text:
This section discusses important categories of signals and their distinctive properties.





1.9.1Â Â Even and odd signals






A signal x[n] is called even if x[n] = x[âˆ’n], and odd if x[n] = âˆ’x[âˆ’n]. The definitions are also valid for a continuous-time signal and, in general, for any function f(x). An even function f(x) has the property that f(x) = f(âˆ’x), while an odd function has the property that f(x) = âˆ’f(âˆ’x). For instance, the cosine is an even function while the sine is an odd function.



Interestingly, any function can be decomposed into even fe(x) and odd fo(x) parts, such that f(x) = fe(x) + fo(x). The two component parts can be obtained as






 fe(x) = f(x) + f(âˆ’x) 2 Â Â Â Â andÂ Â Â Â fo(x) = f(x) âˆ’ f(âˆ’x) 2 . 






Similarly, any signal x[n] (or x(t)) can be obtained
as the sum of an even xe[n] and odd xo[n] parcels, which can be found as follows:









 xe[n] = 0.5(x[n] + x[âˆ’n]) 


(1.32)






and









 xo[n] = 0.5(x[n] âˆ’ x[âˆ’n]), 


(1.33)






respectively, such that x[n] = xe[n] + xo[n].



For example, assume the unit step function x(t) = u(t). Its even and odd parts are xe(t) = 0.5,âˆ€ â¡t and xo(t) = 0.5u(t) âˆ’ 0.5u(âˆ’t), respectively.



The function ak_getEvenOddParts.m can be used to obtain the even and odd components of arbitrary finite-duration sequences. Three examples are provided in FigureÂ 1.42, FigureÂ 1.43 and FigureÂ 1.44.








FigureÂ 1.42: Even and odd components of a signal x[n] representing a finite-duration segment of the step function u[n]. Note the symmetry properties: xe[n] = xe[âˆ’n] and xo[n] = âˆ’xo[âˆ’n].










FigureÂ 1.43: Even and odd components of a signal x[n] = n2u[n] representing a parabolic function.










FigureÂ 1.44: Even and odd components of a signal x[n] representing a triangle that starts at n = 21 and has its peak with an amplitude x[60] = 40 at n = 60. Note that the peak amplitude of the two components is 20.




1.9.2Â Â Random signals and their generation



Random signals are important to represent noise or other non-deterministic signals. Discrete-time random signals of finite duration can be represented by vectors in which the elements are outcomes of random variables (see AppendixÂ B.19). For example, assuming all elements of [2, 0, 2, 3, 3, 2, 3] are outcomes of the same random variable X, one can calculate the average ğ”¼[X] â‰ˆ 2.14, the standard deviation Ïƒ â‰ˆ 1.07 and other statistical moments of X.



Alternatively, a vector with random samples may correspond to a realization of a discrete-time random process (see AppendixÂ B.20).



 Example 1.38. Random Gaussian signals: generation, waveform and histogram. It is easy to generate random signals in Matlab/Octave. For example, the command x=randn(1,100) generates 100 samples distributed according to a standard Gaussian (zero-mean and unity-variance) distribution N(0,1), where the notation N(Î¼,Ïƒ2) assumes the second argument is the variance Ïƒ2, not the standard deviation Ïƒ. These signals can be visualized as a time-series,12 such as in FigureÂ 1.45.








FigureÂ 1.45: Waveform representation of a random signal with 100 samples draw from a Gaussian distribution N(0,1).










FigureÂ 1.46: Histogram of the signal in FigureÂ 1.45 with 10 bins.





The time-domain visualization can be complemented by plotting the probability distribution of the random signal. FigureÂ 1.46 illustrates the histogram of the signal depicted in FigureÂ 1.45. The histogram is calculated by dividing the dynamic range in bins and counting the number of samples that belong to each bin. FigureÂ 1.46 was obtained by using 10 bins (the default). Â Â â–¡



The histogram indicates the number of occurrences of the input data within the ranges (or bins) indicated in its abscissa. The histogram is also very useful to estimate a probability mass function (PMF) and probability density function (PDF) from available data, which are used for discrete and continuous random variables, respectively.



 Example 1.39. Using a normalized histogram as an estimate of the probability mass function. Even when the elements of the input vector x are real values, the histogram calculation â€œquantizesâ€ these input values into only B values, which represent the ranges of the histogram bins. In other words, the bin centers can be seen as the result of a quantization process. Besides peforming this â€œquantizationâ€, the histogram also indicates the number of occurrences of these B values in x.



The B center bins of a histogram can be interpreted as the possible distinct values of a discrete random variable. Therefore, normalizing the histogram by the total number N of samples provides an estimate of the PMF of this discrete random variable.



For instance, suppose a vector x with N=100 elements. Calculating the histogram and dividing the number of occurrences by N provides an estimate of the PMF of x. In Matlab/Octave, after obtaining the histogram with [occurrences, bin_centers]=hist(x), the PMF can be estimated using stem(bin_centers, occurrences/N). Â  Â â–¡



Normalizing the histogram by the total number N of samples provides an estimate of the PMF of a discrete random variable, with values represented by centers of the histogram bins. When this result is further normalized by the bin width, an estimate of the PDF is obtained, as discussed in the next example.



 Example 1.40. Using a normalized histogram as an estimate of the probability density function. Sometimes we know the input data x is composed of realizations of a continuous random variable with a known PDF. When the task is to superimpose a PDF estimated from data to the actual PDF, one needs to properly normalize the histogram (see AppendixÂ B.13).



The function ak_normalize_histogram.m can be used to estimate a PDF from a histogram and was used to obtain FigureÂ 1.47 according to the commands in ListingÂ 1.18.



ListingÂ 1.18: MatlabOctaveCodeSnippets/snip_signals_estimate_pdf.m


B=10; %number of bins 
x=randn(1,100); %random numbers ~ G(0,1) 
[n2,x2]=ak_normalize_histogram(x,B);%PDF via normalized histogram 
a=-3:0.1:3; %use range of [-3std, 3std] around the mean 
5plot(x2,n2,'o-',a,normpdf(a),'x-') %estimate vs. theoretical PDF
  







FigureÂ 1.47: PDF estimate from the histogram in FigureÂ 1.46. The histogram values were divided by the product of the total number of samples and bin width. A standard Gaussian PDF is superimposed for the sake of comparison.





FigureÂ 1.47 indicates that 100 samples and 10 bins provide only a crude estimation. Â  Â â–¡



 Example 1.41. Changing the mean and variance of a random variable. Assume a random variable X has a mean Î· = ğ”¼[X] and N of its realizations compose a vector x. If one wants to create a new random variable Y with ğ”¼[Y] = Î· + 3, this can be done with Y = X + 3, ou using the realizations: y=x+3. This is valid for any constant value Îº.



To prove it, observe that the expected value is a linear operator (see, AppendixÂ B.19.3), such that when Y = X + Îº, one has









 ğ”¼[Y] = ğ”¼[X + Îº] = ğ”¼[X] + ğ”¼[Îº] = Î· + Îº. 


(1.34)






Similarly, if the variance of X is Ïƒx2, a random variable Y = ÎºX has variance Ïƒy2 = ÎºÏƒx2. The proof is based on Eq.Â (B.66) and linearity:



 Ïƒy2  = ğ”¼[(Y âˆ’ ğ”¼[Y])2] = ğ”¼[Y2] âˆ’ ğ”¼[Y]2 = ğ”¼[(ÎºX)2] âˆ’ (ğ”¼[ÎºX])2 = Îº(ğ”¼[X2] âˆ’ (ğ”¼[X])2)     = ÎºÏƒx2. (1.35)Â   

Take now the particular example of the function randn in Matlab/Octave, which generates realizations of a random variable X that is distributed according to the normalized Gaussian N(0,1). Based on Eq.Â (1.34) and Eq.Â (1.35), if one creates a new random variable Y = ÏƒX + Î·, the mean and variance of Y are Î· and Ïƒ2, respectively.



Considering Matlab/Octave, the command x=sqrt(newVariance)*randn(1,N)+newMean provides Gaussians with arbitrary mean and variance.



ListingÂ 1.19 was used to generate the samples of N(4,0.09) and illustrates how to draw samples from a Gaussian with any given mean and variance from calls to a random number generator that outputs samples from a standard Gaussian N(0,1).



ListingÂ 1.19: MatlabOctaveCodeSnippets/snip_signals_gaussian_rand_gen.m


newMean=4; %new mean 
newVariance=0.09; %new variance 
N=10000; %number of random samples 
x=sqrt(newVariance)*randn(1,N)+newMean;
  







FigureÂ 1.48: Comparison of normalized histogram and the correct Gaussian N(4,0.09) when using 10,000 samples and 100 bins. Note the likelihood can be larger than one because it is not a probability.





FigureÂ 1.48 was obtained by using 10 thousand samples from a Gaussian N(4,0.09) and using 100 bins for the histogram. Now the Gaussian estimation is relatively good when compared to the one depicted in FigureÂ 1.47.



It should be noted that the normalized histogram of a continuous PDF indicates likelihood, not probability. The likelihood function is the PDF viewed as a function of the parameters. Therefore, it is possible to have values larger than one in the ordinate, such as in FigureÂ 1.48. Â  Â â–¡



While the previous example assumed a Gaussian PDF, the next one deals with a uniform PDF.



 Example 1.42. Calculating and changing the mean and variance of a uniform probability density function. A random variable X distributed according to a uniform PDF with support [a,b] (range from a to b of values that have non-zero likelihood) has a mean given by









 Î¼ = ğ”¼[X] = (a + b)âˆ•2 


(1.36)






and variance:









 Ïƒ2 = ğ”¼[(X âˆ’ Î¼)2] = (b âˆ’ a)2âˆ•12 


(1.37)






Eq.Â (1.37) can be proved observing that the uniform PDF fX(x) is a constant 1âˆ•(b âˆ’ a) over the range [a,b] and zero otherwise. Hence, using Eq.Â (B.68) with the function g(X) = g((X âˆ’ Î¼)2) leads to









 Ïƒ2 = ğ”¼[(X âˆ’ Î¼)2] = âˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆf X(x)(x âˆ’ Î¼)2dx = âˆ« ab 1 b âˆ’ a  (x âˆ’ (a + b) 2 )2dx = S2 12, 


(1.38)






where S = b âˆ’ a is the PDF support.



When using the random number generator rand for uniformly distributed samples, one should notice that the dynamic range is [0,1], i. e., a = 0 and b = 1. Hence, Eq.Â (1.36) indicates the mean is 0.5 and the variance given by Eq.Â (1.37) is S2âˆ•12 = 1âˆ•12 â‰ˆ 0.0833.



Drawing from rand, it is possible to generate N samples uniformly distributed in an arbitrary range [a,b] with the command x = a + (b-a) * rand(N,1). Â Â â–¡


1.9.3Â Â Periodic and aperiodic signals





Periodicity in continuous-time



A signal x(t) (same discussion applies to x[n]) is periodic if a given segment of x(t) is
eternally repeated, such that x(t) = x(t + T) for some T > 0, where T is called the period. For example, if T = 10 seconds and x(t) = x(t + 10), for all values of t.



In the example of T = 10, it is easy to check that x(t) = x(t + 20), x(t) = x(t + 30) and so on. In other words, a signal with period T is also periodic in 2T,3T,â€¦. The fundamental period T0 is the smallest value of T for which x(t) = x(t + T0). Note that the definition imposes T0 > 0 and a constant signal x(t) = Îº is not considered periodic.



 Example 1.43. Using the LCM and GCD for a periodic signal composed by commensurate frequencies. Two frequencies f1 and f2 are called commensurate if their ratio f1âˆ•f2 can be written as a rational number mâˆ•n, where m,n are non-zero integers. Instead of frequencies, one can use their associated time periods.



Assume a signal x(t) = âˆ‘ â¡ i=1Nxi(t) is composed by the sum of N periodic components xi(t), each one with period Ti and frequency fi = 1âˆ•Ti. The set of frequencies {fi} is commensurate if all pairs are commensurate. In this case, the fundamental period T0 of x(t) can be found using the least common multiple (LCM) of the periods {Ti} while the fundamental frequency F0 = 1âˆ•T0 can be found using the greatest common divisor (GCD) of the frequencies {fi}. Assuming both LCM and GCD are defined only for integer numbers, it may be needed to extract a common factor and later reintroduce it. A numerical example helps: let x(t) = cos â¡ (2Ï€f1t) + cos â¡ (2Ï€f2t + Ï€âˆ•2) + sin â¡ (2Ï€f3t) be composed by sinusoids
with frequencies f1 = 5âˆ•2, f2 = 1âˆ•6 and f3 = 1âˆ•8Â Hz, which corresponds to periods T1 = 0.4, T2 = 6 and T3 = 8Â seconds, respectively. To find the LCM, one may need to multiply all periods by 10 and then calculate that LCM(4,60,80) = 240. Dividing this result by the factor 10 leads to T0 = 24Â s. This LCM could be obtained in Matlab/Octave with lcm(lcm(4,60),80) given that this function is limited to accepting only two input arguments. Â  Â â–¡





Periodicity of a generic discrete-time signal



A discrete-time signal is periodic if x[n] = x[n + N0] for some integer N0 > 0. Similar to the continuous-time case, the value N0 is called the fundamental period if it corresponds to the minimum number of samples in which the amplitudes repeat.





Periodicity of discrete-time sinusoids



One important thing is that the discrete-time counterpart of some periodic analog signals may be non-periodic. The next paragraphs discuss the periodicity of discrete-time sinusoids such as cos â¡ ((Ï€âˆ•4)n), sin â¡ (3n) and eÏ€n. For example the signal x(t) = cos â¡ (3t) is periodic with period T = 2Ï€âˆ•3Â s. However, the discrete-time signal x[n] = cos â¡ (3n) is non-periodic.



A discrete-time sinusoid such as x[n] = Acos â¡ (Î©n + Ï•) is periodic only if Î©âˆ•(2Ï€) is a ratio mâˆ•N0 of two integers m and N0 as proved below.13 One can write:






 x[n + N0] = Acos â¡ (Î©(n + N0) + Ï•) = Acos â¡ (Î©n + Î©N0 + Ï•). 






If the parcel Î©N0 in previous expression is a multiple of 2Ï€, then x[n + N0] = x[n],âˆ€ â¡n. Hence, periodicity requires Î©N0 = 2Ï€m, which leads to the condition









  m N0 = Î© 2Ï€ 


(1.39)






for a discrete-time sinusoid to be periodic.



 Example 1.44. Checking the periodicity of discrete-time sinusoids. For example, x[n] = cos â¡ (3n) is non-periodic because Î© = 3 and 3âˆ•(2Ï€) cannot be written as a ratio of two integers. In contrast, x[n] = cos â¡ ((2Ï€âˆ•8)n + 0.2) is periodic with period N0 = 8 (m = 1 in this case). The signal x[n] = cos â¡ (7Ï€n) is periodic because Î© = 7Ï€ and Î©âˆ•(2Ï€) = 7âˆ•2, with m = 7 and N0 = 2. Â  Â â–¡



If mâˆ•N0 in Eq.Â (1.39) is an irreducible fraction, then N0 is the fundamental period. Otherwise, N0 may be a multiple of the fundamental period.



 Example 1.45. Finding the fundamental period requires reducing the fraction mâˆ•N0. For instance, the signal x[n] = cos â¡ ((12Ï€âˆ•28)n) is periodic because Î© = (12Ï€âˆ•28) and Î©âˆ•(2Ï€) = 6âˆ•28, with m = 6 and N0 = 28. However, if one is interested on the fundamental period, it is necessary to reduce the fraction 6âˆ•28 to 3âˆ•14, and obtain the fundamental period as N0 = 14 samples. Â Â â–¡



In summary, when contrasting continuous and discrete-time sinusoids, to find the period T of a continuous-time cosine cos â¡ (Ï‰t + Ï•), one can obtain the term Ï‰ that multiplies t and calculate






 T = 2Ï€ Ï‰ , 






which is given in seconds if Ï‰ is in rad/s. Hence, a continuous-time sinusoid is always periodic. But a discrete-time cosine cos â¡ (Î©n + Ï•) may be quasi periodic (i. e., not periodic). If someone tries to simply calculate N0 = 2Ï€ Î© , it may end up with a non-integer period. The condition for periodicity is to be able to write 2Ï€âˆ•Î© as a ratio of integers, i. e.






 N0 m = 2Ï€ Î© , 






where N0 is the period in samples. After turning an N0âˆ• an irreducible fraction, N0 is the fundamental period.



 Example 1.46. Meaning of m when determining the fundamental period. To understand the role of m, consider the signal cos â¡ ((3Ï€âˆ•17)n). In this case, 2Ï€ Î© = 34âˆ•3 cannot be the period because it is not an integer. However, if one allows for m = 3 times the number of samples specified by 2Ï€ Î© , the result is the integer period N0 = m2Ï€ Î© = 34 samples. See ApplicationÂ 1.6 for a discussion on finding m and N0 using Matlab/Octave.



Sometimes, it is misleading to guess the period of a discrete-time cosine or sine via the observation of its graph. FigureÂ 1.49 depicts the graph of x[n] = sin â¡ (0.2n) and was obtained with the following code:


M=100, w=0.2; %%num of samples and angular freq. (rad) 
n=0:M-1; %generate abscissa 
xn=sin(w*n); stem(n,xn); %generate and plot a sinusoid


In this case, the signal seems to have a period around 31 samples at a first glance (because 2Ï€âˆ•Î© â‰ˆ 31.4). But, for example, x[n] will never be 0 at the beginning of a cycle for a value of n other than n = 0. Therefore, in spite of resembling a periodic signal, the angular frequency Î© is such that 2Ï€âˆ•Î© = 10Ï€ is a irrational number and a cycle of numbers will never repeat. In this case, the signal is called almost or quasi
periodic.14








FigureÂ 1.49: Graph of the signal x[n] = sin â¡ (0.2n). Observe carefully that this signal is not periodic. The first non-negative sample of the sine cycle will never exactly repeat its value, as indicated by the â€˜xâ€™ marks.





It is useful to visualize a discrete-time sinusoid that is periodic with m > 1. FigureÂ 1.50 depicts the graph of x[n] = sin â¡ ((3Ï€âˆ•17)n) and illustrates the repetition of m = 3 sine envelopes within a period of N0 = 34 samples.








FigureÂ 1.50: Graph of the signal x[n] = sin â¡ ((3Ï€âˆ•17)n). The signal has period N0 = 34 samples as indicated by the combined marks â€˜xâ€™ and â€˜oâ€™. This value of N0 corresponds to m = 3 cycles of a sine envelope corresponding to 2Ï€âˆ•Î© = 34âˆ•3 â‰ˆ 11.3.





FigureÂ 1.49 and FigureÂ 1.50 illustrate how to distinguish strictly periodic sinusoids from quasi periodic, and help interpreting m in Eq.Â (1.39). Â Â â–¡


1.9.4Â Â Power and energy signals



It is important to understand the concepts of power P and energy E of a signal. One reason is that, in some cases, the equation to be used for a specific analysis (autocorrelation, for example) differs depending if P or E are not finite. This section assumes continuous-time but the concepts are also valid for discrete-time signals.



If E is the energy dissipated by a signal during a time interval Î”t, the average power along Î”t is






 P = E Î”t. 






If p(t) = |x(t)|2 is the instantaneous power of x(t), E can be calculated as









 E = âˆ« âŸ¨Î”tâŸ©p(t)dt. 


(1.40)






If the interval Î”t is not specified, it is implicitly assumed (by default) the whole time axis ] âˆ’âˆ,âˆ[ and






 E = âˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆp(t)dt. 






In this case, P is defined as the limit









 P = lim â¡  Î”tâ†’âˆ  [ 1 Î”tâˆ« âˆ’Î”tâˆ•2Î”tâˆ•2p(t)dt]. 


(1.41)






Note that, because the time interval goes to infinite (denominator), P is zero unless the energy E (numerator) also goes to infinite. This situation suggests the definition of power and energy signals, which have finite power and energy, respectively. Their characteristics are
summarized in TableÂ 1.8, which also indicates that there is a third category for signals that have neither finite power or energy.







TableÂ 1.8: Total energy E and average power P for two kinds of signal assuming an infinite time interval.

The most common power signals are periodic. In this case, the energy ET  in one period T






 ET  = âˆ« âŸ¨TâŸ©p(t)dt 






can be used to easily calculate






 P = ET  T 






because what happens in one period is replicated along the whole time axis.



The most common energy signals have a finite duration, such as x(t) = t2[u(t) âˆ’ u(t âˆ’ 5)]. Assuming the signals have finite amplitude, their energy in a finite time interval cannot be infinite. Note that infinite duration signals, such as x(t) = eâˆ’tu(t), can also have a finite energy in case their amplitude decay over time.



It is assumed throughout this text that the signals are currents i(t) or voltages v(t) over a resistance R, such that the instantaneous power is






 p(t) = v(t)i(t) = 1 Rv2(t) = i2(t)R. 






Besides, to deal with signals x(t) representing both currents and voltages without bothering about the normalization by R, it is assumed that R = 1 Ohm. Hence, the instantaneous power is p(t) = x2(t) for any real x(t) and, more generally, p(t) = |x(t)|2 in case x(t) is complex-valued.



Throughout the book, unless stated otherwise, x(t) is assumed to be in Volts, p(t) and P in Watts and E in Joules. A dimensional analysis of p(t) = x2(t) should not be interpreted directly as Watts = Volts2, but Watts = Volts2/Ohm, where the normalization by 1 Ohm is implicit. Two examples are provided in the sequel.



 Example 1.47. Sinusoid power. Sinusoids and cosines can be represented by x(t) = Acos â¡ (Ï‰0t + ğœƒ) and are power signals with average power P = A2 2 . The phase ğœƒ does not influence the power calculation. The proof follows.



The angular frequency is Ï‰0 = 2Ï€ T  rad/s, where T is the period in seconds.






 ET  = âˆ« âŸ¨TâŸ©p(t)dt = âˆ« âŸ¨TâŸ©x2(t)dt = A2 âˆ« âŸ¨TâŸ©cos â¡ 2(Ï‰ 0t + ğœƒ)dt. 






Using the identity cos â¡ 2a = 1 2(cos â¡ (2a) + 1) (see Appendix):






 ET  = A2 2 âˆ« âŸ¨TâŸ©(cos â¡ (2Ï‰0t + 2ğœƒ) + 1)dt = A2T 2 . 






The first parcel of the integral is zero, independent of 2ğœƒ because T corresponds exactly to two periods of the cosine with angular frequency 2Ï‰0, while the second parcel is T. The average power is









 P = ET  T = A2 2 , 


(1.42)






which is a result valid for any sinusoid or cosine. This discussion assumed continuous-time signals, but Eq.Â (1.42) is also valid for discrete-time sinusoids. Â  Â â–¡



 Example 1.48. Power of a DC signal. A constant signal x(t) = K (i. e., a DC signal) has power P = K2 because the energy at any interval Î”t is E = K2Î”t. Â  Â â–¡



The root-mean-square (RMS) value xrms of any signal x(t) is the DC value that corresponds to the same power P of x(t), i. e., xrms2 = P or, equivalently, xrms = P. For example, the RMS value of a cosine x(t) = Acos â¡ (Ï‰0t + ğœƒ) is xrms = A 2 because a DC signal y(t) = A 2 has the same average power as x(t).



As discussed in SectionÂ B.26.4, Î´(t) is a distribution and it is tricky to define the energy or power of a sampled signal, which is the topic of SectionÂ 3.5.2.


 

12Â As usually done for signals with many samples, the discrete-time x[n] was depicted as a continuous-time signal with the plot function instead of stem.

 

13Â When mâˆ•N0 is not a rational number, the discrete-time sinusoid is called almost-periodicÂ Â [?,?].

 

14Â See, e. g.,Â [?,?] to see the importance of almost periodic signals in random processes.

           </div>

title: 10Â  Power and Energy in Discrete-Time
text:
The concepts of power and energy are better defined for continuous-time than for discrete-time signals and vectors. Dealing with the concept of power of a discrete-time signal x[n] requires some caution because n does not have the dimension of time. In contrast to x[n], the notation xi is used when i should not be interpreted as â€œtimeâ€ but, for example, as the i-th element of a set.





1.10.1Â Â Power and energy of discrete-time signals



The following definition of average power will be adopted in this text









 P â‰œ lim â¡  Nâ†’âˆ 1 2N + 1âˆ‘ n=âˆ’NN|x[n]|2. 


(1.43)






and interpreted as Watts given that x[n] is assumed to be in Volts. This is a sensible definition, as will be discussed in SectionÂ 1.11.



Accordingly, the energy E of a discrete-time signal is









 E â‰œâˆ‘ n=âˆ’âˆâˆ|x[n]|2. 


(1.44)






such that P = Eâˆ•N when the support of x[n] are N samples.



A similar situation occurs when dealing with vectors.





1.10.2Â Â Power and energy of signals represented as vectors



Here, x[n] denotes the n-th element of a vector x. The order of these elements is assumed to correspond to a time evolution, such that a finite-dimension vector is equivalent to a finite-duration discrete-time sequence. Hence, the energy E of vector x is its squared Euclidean norm:









 E = âˆ‘ n=1N|x[n]|2 = ||x||2, 


(1.45)






where N is the dimension of x. Accordingly, the power of such finite-dimension vector is









 P = E N = 1 Nâˆ‘ n=1N|x[n]|2. 


(1.46)








1.10.3Â Â Power and energy of vectors whose elements are not time-ordered



In contrast to the previous equations, there are cases in which the vector elements are not indexed according to a time evolution.



It should be noticed that the average of the squared norms of several vectors should be interpreted as their average energy, not power. For example, assuming there are M vectors x1,â€¦,xM of dimension N, an average energy is obtained with









 EÂ¯ = 1 Mâˆ‘ i=1ME i = 1 Mâˆ‘ i=1M||x i||2, 


(1.47)






and interpreted in Joules.



Eq.Â (1.46) and Eq.Â (1.47) are similar due to the connection between vectors and finite-duration discrete-time signals. The distinction that allows to observe their results as â€œpowerâ€ or â€œenergyâ€ relies on interpreting the index

i as â€œtimeâ€ or not. In Eq.Â (1.46), an average of instantaneous power values |x(i)|2 along the â€œtimeâ€ i leads to an estimate of power. But when taking an average EÂ¯ over vectors of energy Ei in Eq.Â (1.47), the result is (average) energy.



To make sure the concepts are clear, applying Eq.Â (1.46) to each vectors xi and taking the average of their power Pi leads to






 P = 1 Mâˆ‘ i=1MP i = 1 MNâˆ‘ i=1M âˆ‘ j=1N|x i(j)|2 = EÂ¯ N. 








1.10.4Â Â Power and energy of discrete-time random signals



If x[n] represents a random signal, with samples x[n0] corresponding to outcomes of a random variable X, an alternate definition is






 P â‰œ ğ”¼[|X|2] = ğ”¼[|x[n]|2], 






where ğ”¼[â‹…] is the expectation operator.



The power of a random signal x[n] (or x(t)) can be decomposed into two parcels as follows:









 P = ğ”¼[X2] = Ïƒ x2 + Î¼ x2, 


(1.48)






where the variance Ïƒx2 and the squared-mean Î¼x2 correspond to the powers of the AC and DC components of a real x[n], respectively. The proof is derived in Eq.Â (B.66).



Most of the signals in telecommunications and other applications have zero mean (Î¼ = 0). In this case, Eq.Â (1.48) shows that the power P = Ïƒx2 coincides with the variance of the random signal and the standard deviation Ïƒx with its RMS value.

title: 11Â  Relating Power in Continuous and Discrete-Time
text:
The goal here is to relate the power of a discrete-time x[n] to the power of a continuous-time x(t) where these signals are related by an A/D or D/A conversion. A possible processing chain relating these signals with their associated power in parenthesis is:









 x(t)(Pc)â†’Â sampling â†’xs(t)â†’Â S/D â†’x[n](Pd) = x(nTs). 


(1.49)






Another processing chain of interest is the reconstruction of a continuous-time signal:









 x(nTs) = x[n](Pd)â†’Â D/S â†’xs(t)â†’Â h(t) â†’x(t)(Pc) 


(1.50)






which will be discussed in SectionÂ 3.5.7.



Special interest lies on systems that have equivalence between power in discrete and continuous-time, such that









 Pd = Pc, 


(1.51)






where Pd and Pc are given by Eq.Â (1.43) and Eq.Â (1.41), respectively.15



Eq.Â (1.51) is further discussed in SectionÂ 3.5.3, but here it is derived16 using the rectangle method to approximate the integral of p(t) = |x(t)|2 as a sum of rectangles with bases Ts and heights |x[n]|2, as follows:



 Pc  = lim â¡  Nâ†’âˆ  [ 1 (2N + 1)Ts âˆ« âˆ’NTsNTs |x(t)|2dt]     â‰ˆ lim â¡  Nâ†’âˆ  [ 1 (2N + 1)Ts âˆ‘ n=âˆ’NNT s|x(nTs)|2]     = lim â¡  Nâ†’âˆ  [ 1 (2N + 1)âˆ‘ n=âˆ’NN|x[n]|2]     = Pd. (1.52)  

In summary, when the sampling theorem is obeyed, the signal processing chains (filtering, amplification, etc.) associated to the A/D and D/A processes are assumed here not to alter the power of x(t) and x[n], such that Eq.Â (1.51) holds.


 

15Â This is not the same, but similar to the energy-conservation property of Fourier transforms (e. g., Eq.Â (B.51), or its version for periodic signals Eq.Â (B.52)).

 

16Â Eq.Â (1.51) can also be obtained by assuming the zero-order hold (ZOH) reconstruction of FigureÂ 1.23.

title: 12Â  Correlation: Finding Trends
text:
It is often useful to infer whether or not random variables are related to each other via correlation. For example, height and weight are quantities that present positive correlation for the human population. However, happiness and height are uncorrelated. There are measures other than correlation to detect similarities among variables, such as the mutual information, but correlation is simple and yet very useful. Correlation is called a second-order statistics because it considers only pairwise or quadratic dependence. It does not detect non-linear relations nor causation, that is, correlation cannot deduce cause-and-effect relationships. But correlation helps to indicate trends such as one quantity increasing when another one decreases.



The correlation C for two complex-valued random variables X and Y is defined as






 C = cor(X,Y) = ğ”¼[XYâˆ—], 






where âˆ— denotes the complex conjugate. The correlation coefficient, which is a normalized version of the covariance (not correlation), is defined as






 Ï = cov(X,Y) ÏƒxÏƒy , 






where the covariance is given by









 cov(X,Y) = ğ”¼[(X âˆ’ Î¼x)(Y âˆ’ Î¼y)âˆ—]. 


(1.53)






Note that, when one wants to fully identify the statistical moments of two complex random variables, it is convenient to separately identify the interactions among their real and imaginary parts and organize the partial results of Eq.Â (1.53) as a 2 Ã— 2 matrix. Real-valued random variables are assumed hereafter. When the random variables are real-valued, Eq.Â (1.53) simplifies to






 cov(X,Y) = ğ”¼[XY] âˆ’ Î¼xÎ¼y. 






Two real-valued random variables are called uncorrelated if, and only if, cov(X,Y) = 0, which is equivalent to









 ğ”¼[XY] = Î¼xÎ¼y. 


(1.54)






As mentioned, Ï is calculated by extracting the means ğ”¼[X] = Î¼x and ğ”¼[Y] = Î¼y, i. e., using cov(X,Y) instead of cor(X,Y), and is restricted to  âˆ’ 1 â‰¤ Ï â‰¤ 1 when the random variables are real-valued. ApplicationÂ 1.9 gives an example of using correlation to perform a simple data mining.





1.12.1Â Â Autocorrelation function



Autocorrelation functions are extension of the correlation concept to signals. TableÂ 1.9 summarizes the definitions that will be explored in this text.







TableÂ 1.9: Autocorrelation functions and their respective equation numbers.










Type of process or signal 


Equation

(1.55)

(1.56)

(1.59)

(1.63) 







The existence of distinct autocorrelation definitions for power and energy signals illustrate the importance of distinguishing them, as discussed in SectionÂ 1.9.4.


Definitions of autocorrelation for random signals



An autocorrelation function (ACF) defined for stochastic processes (see AppendixÂ B.20) is









 RX(s,t) = ğ”¼[X(s)Xâˆ—(t)], 


(1.55)






which corresponds to the correlation between random variables X(s) and X(t) at two different points s and t in time of the same random process where Xâˆ—(t) is the complex conjugate of X(t). The purpose of the ACF is to determine the strength of relationship between amplitudes of the signal occurring at two different time instants.



For wide-sense stationary (WSS) processes, the ACF is given by









 RX(Ï„) = ğ”¼[X(t + Ï„)Xâˆ—(t)], 


(1.56)






where the time difference Ï„ = s âˆ’ t is called the lag time.



The random process formalism is very powerful and allows for representing complicated processes. But in many practical cases only one realization x(t) (or x[n]) of the random process X(t) is available. The alternative to deal with the signal without departing from the random process formalism is to assume that X(t) is ergodic. In this case, the statistical (or ensemble) average represented by ğ”¼[â‹…] is substituted by averages over time.



The definitions of autocorrelation given by Eq.Â (1.55) and Eq.Â (1.56) are the most common in signal processing, but others are adopted in fields such as statistics. Choosing one depends on the application and the model adopted for the signals.



When dealing with a simple signal, one can naturally adopt one of the definition of autocorrelation for deterministic signals discussed in the sequel.





Definitions of autocorrelation for deterministic signals



A definition of ACF tailored to a deterministic (non-random) energy signal x(t), which does not use expected values as Eq.Â (1.55), is









 RX(Ï„) = âˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆx(t + Ï„)xâˆ—(t)dt = âˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆxâˆ—(t âˆ’ Ï„)x(t)dt, 


(1.57)






such that









 RX(0) = âˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆ|x(t)|2dt = E, 


(1.58)






where E is the signal energy. It should be noted that this definition of autocorrelation cannot be used for power signals. Power signals have infinite energy and using Eq.Â (1.57) for Ï„ = 0 leads to RX(0) = âˆ in the case of power signals, which is uninformative.



If x(t) is a deterministic power signal, an useful ACF definition is









 RX(Ï„) = lim â¡  Tâ†’âˆ 1 2Tâˆ« âˆ’T T x(t + Ï„)xâˆ—(t)dt, 


(1.59)






such that









 RX(0) = lim â¡  Tâ†’âˆ 1 2Tâˆ« âˆ’T T |x(t)|2dt = P, 


(1.60)






where P is the signal average power. Eq.Â (1.59) can also be used when x(t) is a realization of an ergodic stochastic process.



Similarly, there are distinct definitions of autocorrelation for deterministic discrete-time signals. For example, when x[n] is a finite-duration real signal with N samples, the (unscaled or not normalized) autocorrelation can be written as









 R^X[i] = âˆ‘ n=iNâˆ’1x[n]x[n âˆ’ i], 


(1.61)






which has a minus in n âˆ’ i that does not lead to reflecting the signal.17



As an alternative to use expressions more similar to the ones for signals with infinite duration, the (unscaled or not normalized) autocorrelation can be expressed as






 RX[i] = âˆ‘ nx[n + i]xâˆ—[n],i = âˆ’(N âˆ’ 1),â€¦,âˆ’1,0,1,â€¦,N âˆ’ 1 






and computed assuming a zero value for x[n] when its index is out of range. This corresponds to assuming the signal is extended with enough zeros (zero-padding) to the right and to the left. For example, assuming x[n] = Î´[n] + 2Î´[n âˆ’ 1] + 3Î´[n âˆ’ 2], which can be represented by the vector [1,2,3], its autocorrelation would be [3,8,14,8,3],
for the lags i = âˆ’2,âˆ’1,0,1,2, respectively.

Another observation of interest is that for real signals, RX(Ï„) = RX(âˆ’Ï„). In general, for complex-valued signals, RX(Ï„) = RXâˆ—(âˆ’Ï„), which is called Hermitian symmetry. TableÂ 1.11 provides an example. It can also be noted that, for a given lag i, the subtraction of the indexes of all parcels in valid products is (n + i) âˆ’ n = i.



 Example 1.49. Software implementation of autocorrelation. The definitions of RX[i] used a generic summation âˆ‘ â¡ n over n. To be more concrete, an example of Matlab/Octave code to calculate the unscaled autocorrelation RX[i] is given in ListingÂ 1.20. It can be seen that the property RX(Ï„) = RXâˆ—(âˆ’Ï„) is used to obtain the autocorrelation values for negative Ï„.

10Â Â Â Â end

The function xcorr in Matlab/Octave uses a much faster implementation based on the fast Fourier transform (FFT), to be discussed in ChapterÂ 2. When comparing the results of the two methods, the discrepancy is around 10âˆ’14, which is a typical order of magnitude for numerical errors when working with Matlab/Octave. Â  Â â–¡



When infinite duration power signals can be assumed, it is sensible to define









 RX[i] = lim â¡  Nâ†’âˆ 1 2Nâˆ‘ n=âˆ’NNx[n + i]xâˆ—[n]. 


(1.63)





Examples of some signals autocorrelations






Two examples of autocorrelation are discussed in the sequel.



 Example 1.50. Autocorrelation of white signal. A signal is called â€œwhiteâ€ when it has an autocorrelation R[i] = AÎ´[i] in discrete-time, or R(Ï„) = AÎ´(Ï„) in continuous-time, where A âˆˆ â„ is an arbitrary value. In other words, a white signal has an autocorrelation that is nonzero only at the origin, which corresponds to having samples that are uncorrelated and, consequently, statistically independent.



This nomenclature will be clarified in ChapterÂ 4 but it can be anticipated that such signals have their power uniformly distributed over frequency and the name is inspired by the property of white light, which is composed by a mixture of color wavelengths.



As mentioned, the samples of a white signal are independent and, if the are also identically distributed according to a Gaussian PDF, the signal is called white Gaussian noise (WGN). More strictly, a WGN signal can be modeled as a realization of a wide-sense stationary process. In this case, WGN denotes the stochastic process itself. Using Matlab/Octave, a discrete-time realization of WGN can be obtained with function randn, as illustrated in SectionÂ 1.9.2. Â  Â â–¡



 Example 1.51. Autocorrelation of sinusoid. Using Eq.Â (1.59), the autocorrelation of a sinusoid x(t) = Asin â¡ (Ï‰t + Ï•) can be calculated as follows:



 R(Ï„)  = lim â¡  Tâ†’âˆ  [ 1 2Tâˆ« âˆ’T T Asin â¡ (Ï‰t + Ï•)Asin â¡ (Ï‰t + Ï‰Ï„ + Ï•)dt].    

We now assume a = Ï‰t + Ï• for simplicity and use Eq.Â (B.4) to expand sin â¡ (Ï‰t + Ï• + Ï‰Ï„):



 R(Ï„)  = lim â¡  Tâ†’âˆ  [A2 2Tâˆ« âˆ’T T sin â¡ (a)  [sin â¡ (a)cos â¡ (Ï‰Ï„) + sin â¡ (Ï‰Ï„)cos â¡ (a)]dt]     = A2 lim â¡   Tâ†’âˆ  [cos â¡ (Ï‰Ï„) 2T âˆ« âˆ’T T sin â¡ 2(a)dt + sin â¡ (Ï‰Ï„) 2T âˆ« âˆ’T T sin â¡ (a)cos â¡ (a)dt]     = A2 lim â¡   Tâ†’âˆ  [cos â¡ (Ï‰Ï„) 4T âˆ« âˆ’T T [1 âˆ’ cos â¡ (2a)]dt + sin â¡ (Ï‰Ï„) 4T âˆ« âˆ’T T sin â¡ (2a)dt]     = A2 lim â¡   Tâ†’âˆ  [cos â¡ (Ï‰Ï„) 2T 1 2âˆ« âˆ’T T dt]     = A2 cos â¡ (Ï‰Ï„) 2 . (1.64)  

The third equality used Eq.Â (B.9) and Eq.Â (B.5), and it was simplified because the integrals of both cos â¡ (2a) and sin â¡ (2a) are zero given the integration interval is an integer number of their periods. The final result indicates that the autocorrelation of a sinusoid or cosine does not depend on the phase Ï• and is also periodic in Ï„, with the same period 2Ï€âˆ•Ï‰ that the sinusoid has in t. Therefore, the frequencies contained in the realizations of a stationary random process can be investigated via the autocorrelation R(Ï„) of this process.








FigureÂ 1.51: A sinusoid of period N=8 samples and its autocorrelation, which is also periodic each 8 lags. The cosine corresponding to Rx[l] has amplitude A2âˆ•2 = 42âˆ•2 = 8.





A simulation with Matlab/Octave can help understanding this result. FigureÂ 1.51 was generated with ListingÂ 1.21.

n=0:numSamples-1; %indices

FigureÂ 1.52 was obtained by changing the sinusoid period from N=8 to N=15 and illustrates the effects of dealing with finite-duration signals. Note that both the unbiased and unscaled versions have diminishing values at the end points. Â  Â â–¡



Using Eq.Â (1.63) and a calculation similar to the one used in Eq.Â (1.64), one can prove that the autocorrelation of x[n] = sin â¡ (Î©n + Ï•) is RX[i] = cos â¡ (Î©i)âˆ•2.


1.12.2Â Â Cross-correlation






The cross-correlation function (also called correlation) is very similar to the ACF but uses two distinct signals, being defined for deterministic energy signals as






 Rxy(Ï„) â‰œâˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆx(t + Ï„)yâˆ—(t)dt = âˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆx(t)yâˆ—(t âˆ’ Ï„)dt. 






Note the adopted convention with respect to the complex conjugate.



Some important properties of the cross-correlation are:
