title: 34Â  Linear Time-Invariant Systems
text:
3.4Â Â Linear Time-Invariant Systems



This section is dedicated to the study of linear and time-invariant (LTI) systems.








FigureÂ 3.9: Diagram of systems, emphasizing the linear and time-invariant (LTI) systems and the systems described by linear, constant-coefficient differential (or difference) equations (LCCDE).





FigureÂ 3.9 depicts the position of LTI systems and also includes the important subset of systems described by linear, constant-coefficient differential (or difference, in discrete-time) equations (LCCDE). In this text, it is assumed that the LCCDE systems have zero initial conditions or, equivalently, that the system is at rest.


3.4.1Â Â Impulse response and convolution for LTI systems



A LTI system is completely characterized by its impulse response.5 This fact is illustrated in the sequel using a simple example. Assume that a system H is LTI and its impulse response h[n] = 2Î´[n] + 5Î´[n âˆ’ 1] is obtained by imposing an input x[n] = Î´[n]. For example, assuming x[n] = 4Î´[n] âˆ’ 3Î´[n âˆ’ 1], one has



 y[n]  = H{x[n]} = H{4Î´[n] âˆ’ 3Î´[n âˆ’ 1]}     = 4H{Î´[n]}âˆ’ 3H{Î´[n âˆ’ 1]} (usingÂ linearity)   = 4h[n] âˆ’ 3h[n âˆ’ 1] (usingÂ time-invariance)   = 4(2Î´[n] + 5Î´[n âˆ’ 1]) âˆ’ 3(2Î´[n âˆ’ 1] + 5Î´[n âˆ’ 2])     = 8Î´[n] + 14Î´[n âˆ’ 1]) âˆ’ 15Î´[n âˆ’ 2].    

This example illustrates that, knowing h[n] and using linearity and time-invariance, one can calculate the output.



In general, the input/output relation of a LTI depends on two facts:





As indicated by Eq.Â (1.3), any signal can be decomposed as the sum of impulses Î±Î´[n âˆ’ n0] that are shifted in time (by n0) and scaled (by Î±)
 in amplitude.
 </p></li>
 <li class="itemize">
 <!--l. 291--><p class="noindent" >By time-invariance, each impulse <!--l. 291--><math 
xmlns=â€œhttp://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathMLâ€
display=â€œinlineâ€ >Î´[n âˆ’ n0] generates a sequence h[n âˆ’ n0] at the output and by linearity these sequences Î±h[n âˆ’ n0] can be scaled and summed to composed the output y[n].





These two key facts lead to the convolution operation:



 y[n]  = H{x[n]} = H{âˆ‘ k=âˆ’âˆâˆx[k]Î´[n âˆ’ k]}     = âˆ‘ k=âˆ’âˆâˆx[k]H{Î´[n âˆ’ k]} (usingÂ linearity)   = âˆ‘ k=âˆ’âˆâˆx[k]h[n âˆ’ k]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (usingÂ time-invariance) (3.3)  

Note how linearity and time-invariance were both invoked in this proof. The continuous-time convolution is similar:









 y(t) = âˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆx(Ï„)h(t âˆ’ Ï„)dÏ„. 


(3.4)






The convolution is so important that it is represented by the operator âˆ—. For example, y[n] = x[n]âˆ—h[n] denotes the convolution of x[n] and h[n]. Because âˆ—
is the same symbol used for multiplication in programming languages, the context has to distinguish them.








FigureÂ 3.10: Example of convolution between x[n] = 2Î´[n] âˆ’ 3Î´[n âˆ’ 1] and h[n] = Î´[n] âˆ’ 2Î´[n âˆ’ 1] + Î´[n âˆ’ 2]. The top-left and top-right plots are x[n] and y[n], respectively, while the other plots are the parcels of x[n] (left) and the corresponding parcels of y[n] (right).





FigureÂ 3.10 illustrates the convolution between two sequences. The interpretation is that y[n] is composed by the sum of several scaled and shifted impulse responses. The plots at the right in FigureÂ 3.10 indicate that y[n] is the sum of the two parcels 2h[n] and  âˆ’ 3h[n âˆ’ 1]. The ListingÂ 3.3 provides an example of implementing convolution of discrete-time sequences,6 which gives the same result as the (faster) conv function in Matlab/Octave.



ListingÂ 3.3: MatlabOctaveFunctions/ak_convolution.m


function y=ak_convolution(x,h) 
% function y=ak_convolution(x,h) 
%convolution between sequences x and h 
N1=length(x); %get the number of samples in x 
5N2=length(h); 
N=N1+N2-1; %this is the number of samples in the output y 
y=zeros(1,N); %pre-allocate space for y[n] 
for i=1:N1 %calculate y[n]= sum_k x[k] h[n-k] 
Â Â Â Â y(i:i+N2-1)=y(i:i+N2-1)+x(i)*h; %scaling h by x(i) 
10end
  


Note that if the samples of x[n] and h[n] are organized as elements of vectors of polynomial coefficients, convolving them is equivalent to multiplying the two polynomials. For the example in FigureÂ 3.10 one can obtain the convolution result by multiplying the equivalent polynomials 2x âˆ’ 3 and x2 âˆ’ 2x + 1, which leads to 2x3 âˆ’ 7x2 + 8x âˆ’ 3, i. e., the coefficients are the samples of y[n].



If the impulse response completely characterizes a LTI system, all its properties can be inferred from the corresponding impulse response. This is discussed in AppendixÂ B.27.7.


3.4.2Â Â Convolution properties



The convolution is:





Commutative: aâˆ—b = bâˆ—a





Associative: aâˆ—(bâˆ—c) = (aâˆ—b)âˆ—c





Distributive: aâˆ—(b + c) = aâˆ—b + aâˆ—c





Some other facts about the convolution:





If N1 and N2 are the duration in samples of two finite-length discrete-time sequences a and b, then aâˆ—b has duration N1 + N2 âˆ’ 1 samples





The expression Eq.Â (1.57) can also be written as RX(Ï„) = x(Ï„)âˆ—xâˆ—(âˆ’Ï„)





If a[n] = b[n]âˆ—c[n], to obtain a[na] for a specific instant na, one sums all products b[nb]c[nc] for na = nb + nc





An example of this last fact is appropriate: if x1[n] = Î´[n] + 2Î´[n âˆ’ 1] + 3Î´[n âˆ’ 2] and x2[n] = 5Î´[n] + 6Î´[n âˆ’ 1] + 7Î´[n âˆ’ 2] + 8Î´[n âˆ’ 3], the output y[n] = x1[n]âˆ—x2[n] is given by

y[0]Â =Â x1[0]Â x2[0]Â =Â 5
y[1]Â =Â x1[0]Â x2[1]Â +Â x1[1]Â x2[0]Â =Â 16
y[2]Â =Â x1[0]Â x2[2]Â +Â x1[1]Â x2[1]Â +Â x1[2]Â x2[0]Â =Â 34
y[3]Â =Â x1[0]Â x2[3]Â +Â x1[1]Â x2[2]Â +Â x1[2]Â x2[1]Â =Â 40
y[4]Â =Â x1[1]Â x2[3]Â +Â x1[2]Â x2[2]Â =Â 37
y[5]Â =Â x1[2]Â x2[3]Â =Â 24



where one can note that the indexes of the input sequences sum up to the index of the output. Hence, one can alternatively implement convolution as in ListingÂ 3.4.



ListingÂ 3.4: MatlabOctaveFunctions/ak_convolution2.m


function [y,n]=ak_convolution2(x1,x2,n1,n2) 
% function [y,n]=ak_convolution2(x1,x2,n1,n2) 
%calculate the convolution between the sequences x1 and x2 
%that start at index n1 and n2, respectively 
5%Example: [y,n]=ak_convolution2(1:3,5:8,-3,2); stem(n,y) 
N1=length(x1); %get the number of samples in x1 
N2=length(x2); %get the number of samples in x2 
N=N1+N2-1; %this is the number of samples in the output y 
y=zeros(1,N); %pre-allocate space for y[n] 
10for i=0:N1-1 %calculate y[n] = sum_k x1[k] x2[n-k] 
Â Â Â Â for j=0:N2-1 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â y(i+j+1) = y(i+j+1) + x1(i+1)*x2(j+1); %update 
Â Â Â Â end 
end 
15n=n1+n2:n1+n2+N-1; %generate the "time" indices
  


Note that ListingÂ 3.4 allows to explicitly deal with sequences that do not start at n = 0. When using Matlab/Octave, it is often necessary to explicitly deal with and generate the time indexes.



It can be observed from ListingÂ 3.4 that the first non-zero sample of the convolution between two sequences x1[n] and x2[n] is located at n = n1 + n2, which are assumed to be the indexes of the first non-zero samples of the two sequences. Similarly, the last non-zero sample of the convolution is the sum of the indexes of the last non-zero samples of x1[n] and x2[n]. This can be seen by running ListingÂ 3.5.



ListingÂ 3.5: MatlabOctaveCodeSnippets/snip_systems_ak_convolution.m


x1=1:3; %define sequence x1 
x2=5:8; %define sequence x2 
nx1=-3:-1; %define abscissa for x1 
nx2=2:5; %define abscissa for x2 
5subplot(311); stem(nx1,x1) 
subplot(312); stem(nx2,x2) 
[y,n]=ak_convolution2(x1,x2,-3,2); %calculate convolution 
subplot(313); stem(n,y) %show result with proper time axis
  




3.4.3Â Â Convolution via correlation and vice-versa



Given that convolution and cross-correlation are tightly related, ListingÂ 3.6 illustrates how the Matlab/Octave functions xcorr and conv can be used to calculate the other operation.



ListingÂ 3.6: MatlabOctaveCodeSnippets/snip_systems_convolution_correlation.m


x=(1:4)+j*(4:-1:1); %define some complex signals as row vectors, such 
y=rand(1,15)+j*rand(1,15); %that fliplr inverts the ordering 
%% Correlation via convolution 
Rref=xcorr(x,y); %reference of a cross-correlation 
5xcorrViaConv=conv(x,conj(fliplr(y))); %use the second argument 
%% Convolution via correlation 
Cref=conv(x,y); %reference of a convolution 
convViaXcorr=xcorr(x,conj(fliplr(y))); %using the second argument 
%convViaXcorr=conj(fliplr(xcorr(conj(fliplr(x)),y))); %alternative 
10%% Make sure they have the same length and compare the results 
if length(x) ~= length(y) %this case requires post-processing because 
Â Â Â Â %xcorr assumes the sequences have the same length and uses 
Â Â Â Â %zero-padding if they do not. We treat the effect of these zeros: 
Â Â Â Â convolutionLength=length(x)+length(y)-1; 
15Â Â Â Â correlationLength=2*max(length(x),length(y))-1; 
Â Â Â Â if length(x) < length(y) %zeros at the end 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â convViaXcorr = convViaXcorr(1:convolutionLength); 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â xcorrViaConv = [xcorrViaConv zeros(1,correlationLength- ... 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â length(xcorrViaConv))]; 
20Â Â Â Â elseif length(x) > length(y) %zeros at the beginning 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â convViaXcorr = convViaXcorr(end-convolutionLength+1:end); 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â xcorrViaConv = [zeros(1,correlationLength- ... 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â length(xcorrViaConv)) xcorrViaConv]; 
Â Â Â Â end 
25end 
ErroXcorr= max(abs(Rref - xcorrViaConv)) %calculate maximum errors 
ErroConv = max(abs(Cref - convViaXcorr)) %should be small numbers
  


As indicated in ListingÂ 3.6, the key step to mimic a convolution via correlation or vice-versa is to flip the signal using x(âˆ’t), use its complex conjugate and eventually shift by t0 as indicated in









 x^(t) = xâˆ—(âˆ’t + t 0). 


(3.5)








3.4.4Â Â Discrete-time convolution in matrix notation



Convolution can be denoted in matrix notation. This is especially convenient when dealing with finite-duration discrete-time signals. When these signals are represented by column vectors x1 and x2, a convolution matrix H1 allows to obtain the convolution result y = x1âˆ—x2 as









 y = H1x2, 


(3.6)






where H1 is composed by the elements of x1. It is also possible to create H2 from the elements of x2 and use y = H2x1.



This can be better understood with examples. Considering the goal is to obtain the convolution of two column vectors x1=[1; 2; 3] and x2=[5; 6; 7; 8] (previous example), instead of using y=conv(x1,x2), one can create a matrix

hmatrixÂ =Â [
Â Â Â Â Â 1Â Â Â Â Â 0Â Â Â Â Â 0Â Â Â Â Â 0
Â Â Â Â Â 2Â Â Â Â Â 1Â Â Â Â Â 0Â Â Â Â Â 0
Â Â Â Â Â 3Â Â Â Â Â 2Â Â Â Â Â 1Â Â Â Â Â 0
Â Â Â Â Â 0Â Â Â Â Â 3Â Â Â Â Â 2Â Â Â Â Â 1
Â Â Â Â Â 0Â Â Â Â Â 0Â Â Â Â Â 3Â Â Â Â Â 2
Â Â Â Â Â 0Â Â Â Â Â 0Â Â Â Â Â 0Â Â Â Â Â 3]



with the command hmatrix = convmtx(x1,length(x2)), and then calculate the convolution with y=hmatrix * x2. Note that when using row vectors, the commands could be hm = convmtx(x1,length(x2)); x2*hm (in this case, hm would be the transpose of hmatrix). ApplicationÂ 3.11 discusses the issue of repeatedly processing blocks of samples using the convolution in matrix notation. The matrices created by convmtx are Toeplitz matrices and the command toeplitz.m can also be useful to compose convolution matrices.





3.4.5Â Â Approximating continuous-time via discrete-time convolution



Some situations require approximating the continuous-time convolution denoted by Eq.Â (3.4) via the discrete-time convolution in Eq.Â (3.3). In such cases, the sampling interval Ts should be used as a normalization factor, as indicated in Eq.Â (B.31). This factor is adopted in the next example.



 Example 3.5. Convolution of a pulse with itself leads to a triangular waveform. Assume a pulse p(t) = 4rect(5t âˆ’ 0.1) (see rect(â‹…) in SectionÂ 1.3.6) with amplitude A = 4Â V and support T0 = 0.2Â s. The convolution p(t)âˆ—p(t) corresponds to a triangular waveform: it is 0 for t < 0 and assumes its maximum value at A2T0 = 42 Ã— 0.2 = 3.2 at 0.2Â s, which corresponds to the time that the two pulses overlap completely and A2T0 is the area of p2(t). FigureÂ 3.11 depicts both the pulse and continuous-time convolution p(t)âˆ—p(t).








FigureÂ 3.11: Convolution of a pulse p(t) = 4rect(5t âˆ’ 0.1) with itself, obtained with ListingÂ 3.7.





But FigureÂ 3.11 was in fact obtained by representing p(t) via its discrete-time version p[n], and approximating the convolution p(t)âˆ—p(t) with the scaled discrete-time convolution Ts(p[n]âˆ—p[n]), i. e., Eq.Â (B.31). ListingÂ 3.7 shows the first lines of the script that generated FigureÂ 3.11. After running ListingÂ 3.7, the vectors pulse and triangle are shown in FigureÂ 3.11 with the proper time axes.



ListingÂ 3.7: MatlabOctaveCodeSnippets/snip_systems_continuous_discrete_conv


T0=0.2; %pulse "duty cycle" (interval with non-zero amplitude): 0.2 s 
Ts=2e-3; %sampling interval: 2 ms 
N=T0/Ts; %number of samples to represent the pulse "duty cycle" 
A=4; %pulse amplitude: 4 Volts 
5pulse=A*[zeros(1,N) ones(1,N) zeros(1,4*N)]; %pulse 
triangle=Ts*conv(pulse,pulse); %(approximated) continuous convolution 
disp(['Convolution peak at ' num2str(T0) ' is ' num2str(A^2*T0)])
  


Note in line 6 the scaling factor Ts, which leads to the correct values, as indicated by the datatip in FigureÂ 3.11. Â  Â â–¡


3.4.6Â Â Frequency response: Fourier transform of the impulse response



As indicated in TableÂ 3.1, the frequency response of an LTI system is the Fourier transform of its impulse response. In continuous-time it will be denoted by H(f) (f in Hz) or H(Ï‰) (Ï‰ in rad/s), while in discrete-time the notation is H(ejÎ©) (Î© in rad). The frequency response is particularly useful because complex exponentials are eigenfunctions of LTI systems as explained in the sequel.





Eigenfunctions



Eigenfunctions are closely related to eigenvectors. if A is a matrix (a linear transformation), a non-null vector x is an eigenvector
of A if there is a scalar Î» such that






 Ax = Î»x. 






The scalar Î» is an eigenvalue of A corresponding to the eigenvector x. In general, the matrix A generates a completely new vector y = Ax, i. e., y and x have different directions and magnitudes. However, if x is an eigenvector of A, then y = Î»x, which means that the operation changed only the magnitude of x, leaving its direction unchanged (or possibly reversing it in case Î» < 0).



Similarly, for any LTI system H (continuous-time is assumed here), a complex exponential is an eigenfunction because the output is y(t) = Î»ejÏ‰0t when the input is x(t) = ejÏ‰0t. The frequency response is useful because the eigenvalue Î» = H(Ï‰0) is the value of the frequency response H(Ï‰) at the specific frequency Ï‰ = Ï‰0. This implies that an LTI never creates new frequencies, because it can simply change the magnitude and phase of frequencies that were presented at its input. This fact can be represented as






 ejÏ‰0tâ†’<mstyleÂ  mathvariant=â€œscriptâ€>H â†’H(Ï‰ 0)ejÏ‰0t. 






It is then possible to analyze an LTI in the frequency domain by following the steps:



f 1.


Decompose the input as a sum (if the signal is periodic) or integral of complex exponentials. For that, one can use the Fourier series or transform X(Ï‰) = F{x(t)}


f 2.


Obtain the frequency response, which provides the eigenvalues for all frequencies: H(Ï‰) = F{h(t)}


f 3.


Conceptually, multiply each complex exponential ejÏ‰0t by its eigenvalue H(Ï‰0) and add the partial results to obtain the system output y(t). In practice, this step is performed by Y (Ï‰) = H(Ï‰)X(Ï‰) and then using the inverse transform to obtain y(t) = Fâˆ’1{Y (Ï‰)}.









FigureÂ 3.12: Frequency response of H(Ï‰) = 1 jÏ‰+2 represented in polar form: magnitude (top) and phase (bottom). The data tips indicate the values for Ï‰ = Â±4Â rad/s.





 Example 3.6. LTI filtering of continuous-time complex exponential. For example, consider that x(t) = 6ej4t + 6eâˆ’j4t = 12cos â¡ (4t) is the input of an LTI with h(t) = eâˆ’2tu(t). The eigenvalues corresponding to each the complex exponential eigenfunctions with frequencies Ï‰ = Â±4 rad/s can be obtained from the frequency response H(Ï‰) = F{h(t)} = 1 jÏ‰+2. The Matlab/Octave commands Omega=4; H=1/(j*Omega+2) calculate H(Ï‰)|Ï‰=4 = 0.1 âˆ’ 0.2j for the positive frequency. Because h(t) is real-valued, the frequency response presents Hermitian symmetry and H(Ï‰)|Ï‰=âˆ’4 = Hâˆ—(Ï‰)|Ï‰=4, i. e., H(Ï‰)|Ï‰=âˆ’4 = 0.1 + 0.2j. The commands abs(H), angle(H) can transform from Cartesian to polar: H(Ï‰)|Ï‰=4 â‰ˆ 0.2236eâˆ’j1.107 and H(Ï‰)|Ï‰=âˆ’4 â‰ˆ 0.2236ej1.107. Therefore, the output is y(t) = (0.2236eâˆ’j1.107)6ej4t+(0.2236ej1.107)6eâˆ’j4t = 1.32ej(4tâˆ’1.11)+1.32ej(âˆ’4t+1.11) = 2.64cos â¡ (4tâˆ’1.11).



The effect of the LTI system was to impose a gain of |H(4)| = 0.2236 and a phase of âˆ H(4) = âˆ’1.107 rad. FigureÂ 3.12 depicts the frequency response for a range Ï‰ = 2Ï€[âˆ’3,3] rad/s. Because of the Hermitian symmetry (when h(t) is real), it is common to plot only the positive frequencies. For example, investigate the command freqs(1,[1 2]), which shows the frequency response of H(Ï‰) = 1 jÏ‰+2 in a different format. Â Â â–¡



The previous discussion was restricted to exponentials of the form ejÏ‰0t, but a general complex exponential est (with Ïƒâ‰ 0) is also an eigenfunction of any LTI and the eigenvalue is given by the Laplace transform H(s), as represented by






 es0tâ†’<mstyleÂ  mathvariant=â€œscriptâ€>H â†’H(s 0)es0t. 






The frequency response H(ejÎ©) of discrete-time LTI systems is also very useful. When the time axis t is discretized by sampling, i. e., t = nTs, the complex exponential est becomes esnTs, which is more conveniently represented by zn, where






 z = esTs  






with z,s âˆˆ â„‚.



The discrete-time complex exponential zn is an eigenfunction of discrete-time LTI systems. To prove that, consider x[n] = (z0)n,z0 âˆˆ â„‚, then



 y[n]  = âˆ‘ k=âˆ’âˆâˆ(z 0)kh[n âˆ’ k] = âˆ‘ k=âˆ’âˆâˆh[k](z 0)nâˆ’k = (z 0)n âˆ‘ k=âˆ’âˆâˆh[k](z 0)âˆ’k     = (z0)nH(z)| z=z0.   


The eigenvalue H(z)|z=z0 can be obtained from the transfer function






 H(z) = âˆ‘ n=âˆ’âˆâˆh[n]zâˆ’n, 






which is the Z-transform of the systemâ€™s impulse response. As a special case, when |z| = 1, the eigenfunction ejÎ©n has its amplitude and phase eventually modified by a LTI as depicted by:






 ejÎ©0nâ†’<mstyleÂ  mathvariant=â€œscriptâ€>H â†’H(ejÎ©0 )ejÎ©0n. 






 Example 3.7. LTI filtering of discrete-time complex exponentials. This example describes how an LTI system filters a complex exponential. Consider that x[n] = 4ej0.5Ï€n + 4eâˆ’j0.5Ï€n = 8cos â¡ (0.5Ï€n) is the input of an LTI with h[n] = 0.7nu[n]. The eigenvalues can be obtained from H(ejÎ©) = F{h[n]} = 1 1âˆ’0.7eâˆ’jÎ© when Î© = 0.5Ï€ rad. The Matlab/Octave commands omega=pi/2; H=1/(1-0.7exp(-jomega)) calculate H(ejÎ©)|Î©=0.5Ï€ = 0.6711 âˆ’ 0.4698j. Because h[n] is real-valued, the frequency response presents Hermitian symmetry. The commands abs(H), angle(H) can transform from Cartesian to polar: H(ejÎ©)|Î©=0.5Ï€ â‰ˆ 0.8192eâˆ’j0.6107. Therefore, the output is y[n] = (0.8192eâˆ’j0.6107)4ej0.5Ï€n+(0.8192ej0.6107)4eâˆ’j0.5Ï€n = 3.2769ej(0.5Ï€nâˆ’0.6107)+3.2769ej(âˆ’0.5Ï€n+0.6107) = 6.5539cos â¡ (0.5Ï€nâˆ’0.6107).
The effect of the LTI system was to impose a gain of 0.8192 and a phase of  âˆ’ 0.6107 rad.








FigureÂ 3.13: Frequency response of H(ejÎ©) = 1 1âˆ’0.7eâˆ’jÎ© represented in polar form: magnitude (top) and phase (bottom). The data tips indicate the values for Î© = Ï€âˆ•2 rad.










FigureÂ 3.14: Version of FigureÂ 3.13 obtained with the command freqz(1,[1 -0.7]).





FigureÂ 3.13 depicts the frequency response for a range Î© = [âˆ’15,15] rad. As expected, H(ejÎ©) is periodic because H(ejÎ©) = H(ej(Î©+2Ï€)). Given this periodicity and the Hermitian symmetry (when h[n] is real), it is common to plot only the positive frequencies in the range Î© = [0,Ï€]. For example, FigureÂ 3.14 shows the plots obtained with the command freqz(1,[1 -0.7]), which shows the frequency response of H(ejÎ©) with the magnitude in dB, the phase in degrees (instead of rad) and the abscissa in a â€œnormalized frequencyâ€ Î©âˆ•Ï€ that maps [0,Ï€] into [0,1]. Â  Â â–¡


3.4.7Â Â Fourier convolution property



The convolution property of Fourier transforms states that the convolution between two signals has a Fourier transform given by the multiplication of their Fourier transforms. In other words, the convolution between these signals by can be obtained as the inverse Fourier transform of the multiplication of their Fourier transforms. For example, assuming continuous-time, the convolution y(t) = x1(t)âˆ—x2(t) can be obtained with









 y(t) = Fâˆ’1{X 1(f)X2(f)}, 


(3.7)






where X1(f) and X2(f) are the corresponding Fourier transforms. Similarly, in discrete-time, the convolution result y[n] can be
written as









 y[n] = x1[n]âˆ—x2[n] = DTFTâˆ’1{X 1(ejÎ©)X 2(ejÎ©)}, 


(3.8)






where X1(ejÎ©) and X2(ejÎ©) are the corresponding DTFTs and, in this case, Fâˆ’1 denotes the inverse DTFT.



 Example 3.8. Convolution using DTFTs and inverse DTFT. For example, if x1[n] = Î±1nu[n] and x2[n] = Î±2nu[n] are two discrete-time complex exponentials with |Î±1| < 1 and |Î±2| < 1, their DTFTs are Xi(ejÎ©) = 1 âˆ’ Î±ieâˆ’jÎ©,i = 1,2, respectively. The convolution result is









 y[n] = x1[n]âˆ—x2[n] = 1 Î±1 âˆ’ Î±2  (Î±1n+1u[n] âˆ’ Î± 2n+1u[n]) 


(3.9)






and can be obtained via the inverse DTFT of Y (ejÎ©), which is given by









 Y (ejÎ©) = X 1(ejÎ©)X 2(ejÎ©) = 1 (1 âˆ’ Î±1eâˆ’jÎ©)(1 âˆ’ Î±2eâˆ’jÎ©). 


(3.10)






Eq.Â (3.9) can be obtained by using partial fraction expansion of Eq.Â (3.10). Â  Â â–¡



Due to the duality of Fourier transforms, the multiplication in time-domain corresponds to convolution in frequency-domain between the respective spectra. This is called the multiplication property and corresponds to









 x1(t)x2(t) â‡” X1(f)âˆ—X2(f) = âˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆX 1(p)X2(f âˆ’ p)dp. 


(3.11)






in continuous-time.



In discrete-time, one needs to take in account that the spectra are periodic and the conventional convolution is not adequate when both signals are periodic. Hence, the multiplication property for discrete-time signals is









 x1[n]x2[n] â‡” 1 2Ï€âˆ« <2Ï€>X(ejÎ©)X 2(ej(Î©âˆ’ğœƒ))dğœƒ. 


(3.12)






The integral in Eq.Â (3.12) differs from a conventional convolution because it is calculated over only one period (2Ï€ rad in this case) and the result is normalized by this period. This modified convolution is denoted as âŠ› and is called periodic, cyclic or circular convolution. As in a Fourier series expansion to obtain coefficients ck, the associated period must be known in order to properly use âŠ›. The normalization by the period can be incorporated in its definition, which leads to the following expression for the periodic convolution:









 x1(t)âŠ›x2(t) = 1 Tâˆ« <T>x1(Ï„)x2(t âˆ’ Ï„)dÏ„, 


(3.13)






where both signals are periodic in T.



The definition of Eq.Â (3.13) allows to write Eq.Â (3.12) as









 x1[n]x2[n] â‡” X(ejÎ©)âŠ›X 2(ejÎ©), 


(3.14)






where the period 2Ï€ is implicit.



The periodic convolution corresponds to performing the conventional convolution (called â€œlinearâ€ convolution, in contrast to â€œcircularâ€) between x1(t) and xÂ â€²2(t), where xÂ â€²2(t) is a single period of x2(t) that is normalized
by the period T. The interval to define xÂ â€²2(t) can be conveniently chosen as x2â€²(t) = x2(t)âˆ•T,0 â‰¤ t < T, or 0 otherwise, or x2â€²(t) = x2(t)âˆ•T,âˆ’Tâˆ•2 â‰¤ t < Tâˆ•2, or 0 otherwise.



As discussed in the sequel, the periodic convolution is typically associated to FFT-based processing.





3.4.8Â Â Circular and fast convolutions using FFT



Recalling that the FFT corresponds to sampling the DTFT, Eq.Â (3.8) suggests that FFTs can be used to efficiently compute a convolution. However, even if x[n] were not periodic, when its DTFT X(ejÎ©) is sampled (in frequency domain) by the FFT, the FFT values X[k] are representing the spectrum of a periodic version of x[n]. Consequently, when FFTs substitute DTFTs in Eq.Â (3.8), the result is not the linear but the circular convolution represented as









 y[n] = x1[n]âŠ›x2[n] = FFTâˆ’1{X 1[k]X2[k]}, 


(3.15)






where both FFTs must have the same length N, which plays the whole of the period of a circular convolution.



ListingÂ 3.8 provides an example of using Eq.Â (3.15). Note how zero-padding is used to assure the element-wise multiplication fft(x,N).*fft(h,N) uses arrays with the same length. The result of ListingÂ 3.8 confirms that, in general, linear and circular convolution differ.



ListingÂ 3.8: MatlabOctaveCodeSnippets/snip_systems_circularConvolution.m


x=[1 2 3 4]; h=[.9 .8]; %signals to be convolved 
shouldMakeEquivalent=0 %in general, linear and circular conv. differ 
if shouldMakeEquivalent==1 
Â Â Â Â N=length(x)+length(h)-1; %to force linear and circular coincide 
5else 
Â Â Â Â N=max(length(x),length(h)); %required for FFT zero-padding 
end 
linearConv=conv(x,h) %linear convolution 
circularConv=ifft(fft(x,N).*fft(h,N)) %circular convolution, N=4 
10%circularConv=cconv(x,h,N) %note that Matlab has the cconv function
  


If the value of shouldMakeEquivalent is made equal to 1, ListingÂ 3.8 returns the same results for both linear and circular convolutions. In fact, when the FFT length is at least the number of non-zero samples of the convolution output, the circular and linear convolution results coincide. This suggests that Eq.Â (3.15) can be used to calculate a linear convolution, provided that the FFT length is made long enough.



Obtaining a linear convolution via FFTs is trickier when one of the signals to be convolved has infinite duration. In this case, it is obviously not possible to find a large enough FFT length to use Eq.Â (3.15). However, if the other signal has finite duration, it is feasible and often used in practice to segment the long signal into blocks and calculate the linear convolution by sequentially calculating one FFT per block and properly combining the results. There are basically two alternatives to combine the intermediate results that are called overlap-add and overlap-save methods, and are roughly equivalent. ListingÂ 3.9 illustrates the former.



ListingÂ 3.9: MatlabOctaveCodeSnippets/snip_systems_overlapAdd.m


x=1:1000; %infinite duration (or "long") input signal 
h=ones(1,3); %non-zero samples of finite-length impulse response 
Nh=length(h); %number of impulse response non-zero samples 
Nb=5; %block (segment) length 
5Nfft=2^nextpow2(Nh+Nb-1); %choose a power of 2 FFT size 
Nx = length(x); %number of input samples 
H = fft(h,Nfft); %pre-compute impulse response DFT, with zero-padding 
beginIndex = 1; %initialize index for first sample of current block 
y = zeros(1,Nh+Nx-1); %pre-allocate space for convolution output 
10while beginIndex <= Nx %loop over all blocks 
Â Â Â Â endSample = min(beginIndex+Nb-1,Nx);%last sample of current block 
Â Â Â Â Xblock = fft(x(beginIndex:endSample),Nfft); %DFT of block 
Â Â Â Â yblock = ifft(Xblock.*H,Nfft); %get circular convolution result 
Â Â Â Â outputIndex Â = min(beginIndex+Nfft-1,Nh+Nx-1); %auxiliary variab. 
15Â Â Â Â y(beginIndex:outputIndex) = y(beginIndex:outputIndex) + ... 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â yblock(1:outputIndex-beginIndex+1); %add parcial result 
Â Â Â Â beginIndex = beginIndex+Nb; %shift begin of block 
end 
stem(y-conv(x,h)) %compare the error with result from conv
  


A typical application of the overlap-add and overlap-save methods is to compute the output of a LTI system represented by a finite-duration impulse response (i. e., a FIR filter, as will be discussed in SectionÂ 3.13). ListingÂ 3.9 provides an example where the impulse response has only three non-zero samples, and the long input signal is segmented in blocks of Nb=5 samples.


 

5Â As explained to me by a student: Say you meet a person that tells you he/she is a LTI system. You should then ask his/her impulse response. If you know it, just relax because you can perfectly calculate the personâ€™s reaction (output) to any situation (input).

 

6Â On the Web one can find applets instructing about continuous and discrete convolution (see, e. g., [url3jhu]).

Having established the fundamentals of convolution and Fourier transforms, it is possible now to sketch a proof of the sampling theorem (TheoremÂ 1) without difficulties.





3.5.1Â Â A proof sketch of the sampling theorem



Sampling a signal x(t) at each Ts seconds (periodic and uniform sampling) can be modeled as the multiplication of x(t) by a periodic function p(t) with fundamental period Ts. For example, p(t) can be a train of pulses with duty cycle T1. However, it is mathematically convenient7 to adopt an impulse train









 p(t) = âˆ‘ k=âˆ’âˆâˆÎ´(t âˆ’ kT s), 


(3.16)






which allows to model the sampled signal as









 xs(t) = x(t)p(t) = âˆ‘ k=âˆ’âˆâˆx(kT s)Î´(t âˆ’ kTs), 


(3.17)






as anticipated in Eq.Â (1.17).



From Eq.Â (3.17) and the Fourier convolution property discussed in SectionÂ 3.4.7, the Fourier transform of xs(t) is









 Xs(f) = X(f)âˆ—P(f), 


(3.18)






where X(f) = F{x(t)} and P(f) = F{p(t)} is another impulse train, but in frequency domain. As indicated by Eq.Â (B.60), the impulses in P(f) are spaced by Fs = 1âˆ•Ts and have area Fs = 1âˆ•Ts.



The convolution of X(f) with the impulses in P(f) creates infinite replicas of X(f) at frequencies values that are multiples of Fs as depicted in FigureÂ 3.15. As well-discussed in textbooks, if Fs is not sufficiently large, these replicas will overlap and create aliasing. But in case Fs > 2Fmax, all replicas are â€œperfectâ€ copies of X(f) scaled by Ts. The original spectrum can then be recovered by keeping one replica and eliminating the others. This filtering procedure is assumed here to be done with an ideal lowpass filter with bandwidth BW = Fmax and gain Ts.
This ideal filter will then cancel the undesired replicas of Xs(f) and recover X(f) using precisely the scaling factor Ts.








FigureÂ 3.15: Spectrum Xs(f) of a sampled signal xs(t) obtained by the convolution between X(f) and P(f) as indicated in Eq.Â (3.18).





In summary, a lowpass signal x(t) with maximum frequency Fmax, can be perfectly reconstructed from its sampled version xs(t) if the sampling frequency obeys Fs > 2Fmax (TheoremÂ 1) and the reconstructed signal x^(t) = x(t) is obtained by passing xs(t) through an ideal lowpass filter with frequency response H(f) having gain Ts over the passband.



The spectrum X^(f) of x^(t) corresponds to X^(f) = Xs(f)H(f). The multiplication of Xs(f) by H(f) in frequency-domain corresponds to the convolution of xs(t) with the filterâ€™s impulse response h(t) = F{H(f)}. From Eq.Â (B.54) and the duality property, h(t) = sinc(tâˆ•Ts) in this case. Hence, this convolution is written as









 x^(t) = xs(t)âˆ—h(t) = âˆ‘ n=âˆ’âˆâˆx sa(nT s)sinc  ( t Ts âˆ’ n), 


(3.19)






which corresponds to the convolution of the scaled sinc h(t) with impulses8 of area xsa(nTs). The time shift by n in Eq.Â (3.19) positions the sincs at nTs, and was discussed in ExampleÂ 1.5.



Eq.Â (3.19) represents the reconstruction of a band-limited signal by the sinc interpolation of its samples and is called the Whittaker-Shannon interpolation formula.



Hence, when the sampling theorem is obeyed, the whole chain is as follows (the signals are depicted with their associated power in parenthesis as in BlockÂ (1.49)):









 x(t)(Pc)â†’Â sampling â†’xs(t)(Ps)â†’Â S/D â†’x[n](Pd)â†’Â D/S â†’xs(t)(Ps)â†’Â h(t) â†’x^(t)(Pc) = x(t) 


(3.20)






where h(t) = sinc(tâˆ•Ts) is the discussed ideal filter.



Using the notation suggested by BlockÂ (3.20), the samples x(nTs) were converted to areas xsa(nTs), which are converted to x[n] = xsa(nTs). Hence, Eq.Â (3.19) can be conveniently rewritten as









 x^(t) = xs(t)âˆ—h(t) = D/S{x[n]}âˆ—h(t) = âˆ‘ n=âˆ’âˆâˆx[n]sinc  ( t Ts âˆ’ n). 


(3.21)





3.5.2Â Â Energy and power of a sampled signal



The squared of the continuous-time impulse Î´2(t) is not defined. This creates a problem when one considers the energy or power of Î´(t). When Î´(t) is interpreted as a pulse p(t) with unit area and amplitude 1âˆ•Î”, one
can argue that when lim â¡  Î”â†’0 as in Eq.Â (B.120), the resulting area of the squared pulse p2(t) is 1âˆ•Î”, which leads to Î´2(t) = âˆ. However, this would not be mathematically rigorous given that Î´(t) is a distribution. Hence, the following route is taken here: instead of defining new transformations9 on the distribution Î´(t), the instantaneous power of a sampled signal xs(t) is defined as the instantaneous power of its equivalent discrete-time signal x[n] obtained via a S/D conversion, normalized by the associated Ts, i. e.









 Ps=defPd Ts . 


(3.22)






For example, the pulse train of Eq.Â (3.16) has average power Ps = 1âˆ•Ts because when converted to discrete-time its power is Pd = 1.



The same reasoning can be applied to sampled signals for which the independent variable is not t. The Fourier transform P(f) = {p(t)} of Eq.Â (3.16) has power 1âˆ•Ts because its discrete-frequency version has power 1âˆ•Ts2 and the normalizing factor is 1âˆ•Ts in this case. Note that, with this definition of instantaneous power of a sampled signal, the power of the impulse trains p(t) and P(f) are the same, as expected from Eq.Â (B.52).





3.5.3Â Â Energy / power conservation after sampling and reconstruction



With the help of Eq.Â (3.21), it is possible to sketch a proof for Eq.Â (1.51), which is valid when the sampling theorem is obeyed.



Eq.Â (3.21) states that any band-limited signal x(t) can be represented by its samples x[n]. The interest here is to relate their respective power values Pc and Pd. Assuming x(t) is an energy signal and from Eq.Â (B.28), its energy Ec can be written as









 Ec = âˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆ|x(t)|2dt = âˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆ  |âˆ‘ n=âˆ’âˆâˆx[n]sinc(tâˆ•T s âˆ’ n)|2dt = T s âˆ‘ n=âˆ’âˆâˆ|x[n]|2 = T sEd, 


(3.23)






where Ed is the energy of x[n]. A similar reasoning can be applied to power signals. Rewriting Eq.Â (1.41) with Î”t = NTs leads to



 Pc  = lim â¡  Nâ†’âˆ  [ 1 (2N + 1)Ts âˆ« âˆ’NTsNTs  |âˆ‘ n=âˆ’NNx[n]sinc(tâˆ•T s âˆ’ n)|2dt]     = lim â¡  Nâ†’âˆ  [ Ts (2N + 1)Ts âˆ‘ n=âˆ’NN|x[n]|2]     = Pd. (3.24)  

From Eq.Â (3.24) and Eq.Â (3.22), BlockÂ (3.20) can be simplified as









 x(t)(P)â†’Â sampling â†’xs(t)(Pâˆ•Ts)â†’Â S/D â†’x[n](P)â†’Â D/S â†’xs(t)(Pâˆ•Ts)â†’Â h(t) â†’x^(t)(P) = x(t), 


(3.25)






where P = Pc = Pd.





3.5.4Â Â Sampling theorem uses a strict inequality



Some authors state this theorem as Fs â‰¥ 2Fmax, but in this case Fmax would have to be interpreted as the frequency for which X(f) does not have a discrete frequency component Î´(f âˆ’ Fmax). The confusion often arises when textbooks pictorially represent X(f) with a triangle shape as in FigureÂ 3.15 and, in this case, Fmax is the â€œmaximumâ€ but X(Fmax) = 0 such that Fs â‰¥ 2Fmax â€œworksâ€. However, as the exercise of Eq.Â (1.19) suggests, it is not guaranteed to reconstruct a cosine of frequency fc if one takes its samples at rate Fs = 2fc.



Another source of confusion with respect to Fs â‰¥ 2Fmax or

Fs > 2Fmax is that when processing a signal sampled at Fs with an FFT, the maximum frequency is the so-called Nyquist frequency Fsâˆ•2 of TableÂ 1.4. Taking that Fmax = Fsâˆ•2, it seems reasonable to adopt Fs â‰¥ 2Fmax. Note however that the FFT bin corresponding to the Nyquist frequency is representing all signal components within its width Î”f and that, unless X(f) has a discrete frequency component Î´(f âˆ’ Fmax) to create ambiguity as exemplified in Eq.Â (1.19), there is no major practical issue.





3.5.5Â Â Undersampling or passband sampling



Most digital signal processing (DSP) systems are designed to combat aliasing but there are exceptions. In digital communications, it is common to use aliasing to lower the frequency of a signal x(t) in an operation known as undersampling or passband sampling. Among other conditions, x(t) has to be a passband signal with spectrum centered at (a relatively high) frequency fc, but with (a relatively small) bandwidth BW < fc, such that Fs > 2BW. In this case, even if Fs < 2fmax, where the maximum frequency is fmax = fc + 0.5BW, x(t) can still be reconstructed from a replica of its spectrum that was shifted in frequency.



For example, consider a passband signal x(t) with spectrum X(f) with BW = 25Â Hz and center frequency fc = 70Â Hz, as depicted in FigureÂ 3.16. This signal has fmax = fc + 0.5BW = 82.5Â Hz and using the sampling theorem as applied to lowpass signals one would be compeled to use Fs > 2 Ã— 82.5 = 165Â Hz. However, using Fs = 56Â Hz, for example, one can still recover the signal.








FigureÂ 3.16: Passband signal with BW = 25Â Hz and center frequency fc = 70Â Hz.





According to the classic model for the sampling operation, it corresponds to the convolution of X(f) with an impulse train P(f) such that Xd(f) = X(f)âˆ—P(f) and P(f) has impulses separated by Fs = 56. Hence, the sampled signal has spectrum Xd(f) as depicted in FigureÂ 3.17.



Assuming x(t) is real and X(f) has Hermitian symmetry, any of the two â€œreplicasâ€ in FigureÂ 3.16 could be used to reconstruct x(t). Similarly, any of the six (among the infinite) replicas that are shown in FigureÂ 3.17 could be used to reconstruct x(t).








FigureÂ 3.17: Result of sampling X(f) in FigureÂ 3.16 with Fs = 56Â Hz, which places replicas at f = Â±14,Â±42,Â±,70,Â±98,â€¦, with only the first six shown in this figure.





For example, placing an ideal lowpass filter with cutoff frequency Fsâˆ•2 would obtain a version of x(t) corresponding to a frequency downconversion of its spectrum X(f) from 70 to 14Â Hz.



The theory about undersampling indicates the range of Fs that can be used in each situation and can be found in DSP textbooks.10


3.5.6Â Â Sampling a complex-valued signal



The sampling theorem (TheoremÂ 1) assumed a real-valued signal, which consequently, allowed to assume the spectrum magnitude is even (symmetric). In the more general case of a complex-valued signal, the same principle of having spectrum replicas that cannot overlap is valid, but the â€œmaximum positive frequencyâ€ is not enough to determine the minimum Fs.



FigureÂ 3.18 suggests an example where a complex-valued signal has spectrum X(f) with support from  âˆ’ 300 to 100Â Hz. A careless interpretation of the sampling theorem could lead to the erroneous conclusion that Fs > 2 Ã— 100Â Hz suffices to avoid aliasing. But in this case Fs > 400Â Hz is required to avoid the overlap of spectrum replicas. FigureÂ 3.18 adopts Fs = 450Â Hz.








FigureÂ 3.18: Sampling with Fs = 450Â Hz a complex-valued signal with non-symmetrical spectrum.





Stating the sampling theorem for complex-valued signals requires more elaborated definitions of bandwidth (this is discussed in SectionÂ 3.7.2.0). But FigureÂ 3.18 (and FigureÂ 3.15) indicate that an efficient strategy is to follow the basic principle of avoiding aliasing after convolving the original spectrum with the train of impulses spaced by Fs.


3.5.7Â Â Signal reconstruction and D/S conversion revisited



Similar to sampling, the D/S conversion can now be better understood. After that, the important topic of signal reconstruction is discussed.





D/S conversion revisited






When a discrete-time signal x[n] with DTFT X(ejÎ©) is converted into a sampled signal xs(t) with Fourier transform Xs(Ï‰) via a D/S conversion, as discussed in SectionÂ 1.6.6, it has a frequency-domain description given by









 Xs(Ï‰) = X(ejÎ©)| Î©=Ï‰Ts = X(ejÏ‰Ts ). 


(3.26)






In other words, the value of Xs(Ï‰0) for a specific frequency Ï‰0 rad/s is obtained from X(ejÎ©0) where Î©0 = Ï‰0Ts rad, as dictated by Eq.Â (1.22).



The notation is such that the subscript in Xs(Ï‰) indicates the Fourier transform of a â€œsampledâ€ signal or, alternatively,

X(ejÏ‰Ts) can be used. In both cases, the reader should have in mind that a sampled signal has a periodic spectrum.



Eq.Â (3.26) corresponds to scaling the abscissa of X(ejÎ©), originally specified in rad, to create X(ejÏ‰Ts) with an abscissa Ï‰ = Î©Fs in rad/s. FigureÂ 3.19 provides an example of the spectra involved in this D/S conversion.








FigureÂ 3.19: Result of converting x[n] with spectrum X(ejÎ©) into xs(t) with Xs(Ï‰) = X(ejÏ‰Ts) via a D/S conversion using Fs = 10Â Hz.





The datatips in FigureÂ 3.19 highlight that the value |X(ejÎ©0)| = 18.86 at Î©0 = 1.571Â rad was converted to |X(Ï‰0)| where Ï‰0 = Î©0Fs = 15.71Â rad/s.



The replicas that occur in the spectrum of a sampled signal are located in Nyquist zones, which are intervals of Fsâˆ•2 when the frequency f is specified in Hertz. For example, the first Nyquist zone is [0,Fsâˆ•2[, the second is [Fsâˆ•2,Fs[ and so on. When the frequencies Ï‰ and Î© are specified in rad/s and rad, the bandwidths of the Nyquist zones are Ï€Fs and Ï€, respectively.



In summary, Xs(Ï‰) inherits the periodicity of X(ejÎ©) in spite of the notation indicating it only by the subscript s of â€œsampledâ€. Therefore, in some situations, it is convenient to denote the spectrum of xs(t) as X(ejÏ‰Ts), which indicates that the independent variable Ï‰ is in rad/s and makes explicit that this spectrum is periodic. An alternative to describing the sampled-signal spectrum X(ejÏ‰Ts) in rad/s is to use Ï‰ = 2Ï€f and represent X(ej2Ï€fTs) in Hz.



The adoption of a filter to eliminate or attenuate the periodic replicas of a sampled signal X(ejÏ‰Ts) is discussed in the sequel.


Signal reconstruction



Digital signal processing systems that interface with the analog world typically require two analog filters: the anti-aliasing and reconstruction, as indicated in FigureÂ 3.7.



The reconstruction process, which converts a sampled signal xs(t) into a continuous-time signal x(t), is mathematically
modeled by convolving xs(t) with a signal h(t) to obtain x(t) = xs(t)âˆ—h(t). As discussed along the text, the signal h(t) can be interpreted as the impulse response of a system and the reconstruction process can be pictorially depicted as:









 xs(t) â†’Â h(t) â†’ x(t). 


(3.27)






When one starts with the discrete-time signal x[n], the D/A process has two stages: D/S conversion, that transforms the discrete-time x[n] into a continuous sampled signal xs(t) and then processing (or â€œfilteringâ€) with h(t) to obtain x(t).



There are two important options for h(t):

As illustrated in FigureÂ 1.23, D/S followed by zero-order hold reconstruction is a simplified model for the actual process executed by a DAC chip. It is adopted here for simplicity. A consequence of ZOH is that Eq.Â (1.51) holds, and the power in continuous Pc of x(t) and
discrete-time Pd of x[n] are the same.



In practice, the reconstruction process heavily depends on the respective analog filter and the DAC sampling frequency Fs. It is often necessary to use Fs higher than the one suggested by the sampling theorem, to simplify the job that must be done by the reconstruction filter H(f) = F{h(t)}.



For a signal with approximate bandwidth BW, it is tempting to use Fs = 2BW, which is denoted as Nyquist sampling. In this case the signal is called critically-sampled and the reconstruction should be done by an ideal lowpass filter with passband from 0 to Fsâˆ•2. Even when Fs > 2BW, the transition band of the reconstruction filter should be small enough to significantly attenuate the neighboring spectrum replicas of the sampled signal at the output of the D/S conversion.



Recall that the spectrum replicas of X(ejÏ‰Ts) are located at multiples of 2Ï€FsÂ rad/s (see, e. g., FigureÂ 3.19), which correspond to replicas at multiples of Fs when considering X(ej2Ï€fTs) with the frequency f in Hz.



FigureÂ 3.20 presents an extended version of FigureÂ 1.24 that incorporates the filters A(s) and R(s) (these two analog filters are also indicated in FigureÂ 3.7). While FigureÂ 1.24 assumed ZOH reconstruction, FigureÂ 3.20 illustrates the general case of an arbitrary reconstruction filter h(t).








FigureÂ 3.20: Extended version of FigureÂ 1.24 using an arbitrary reconstruction filter h(t) and incorporating the filters A(s) and R(s).





Note that there are two reconstruction filters in FigureÂ 1.24, represented by h(t) and R(s). Their effect could be combined in only one filter with impulse response hr(t) = h(t)âˆ—r(t), where r(t) is the inverse Laplace transform of R(s), but it is often pedagogical to distinguish them as follows.



The internal filter h(t) represents the filtering process that occurs within a DAC chip. Modern DACs can already incorporate a sophisticated h(t), but is is assumed here that this is not the case, and h(t) may implement ZOH or a filter with small order. The â€œexternalâ€ reconstruction filter R(s) complements h(t) and provides improved rejection of the undesired spectrum replicas of ys(t) that may still be present in y(t). In summary, the main role of h(t) is the conversion of the sampled signal ys(t) into an analog signal y(t), while R(s) aims at achieving the specified level of performance with respect to filtering out the replicas in ys(t). The following example illustrates how signal reconstruction can be challenging in practice.



 Example 3.9. Examples of signal reconstruction. FigureÂ 3.21 is the result of an example11 where a random signal y[n] with BW = 25Â kHz and Fs = 200Â kHz, is converted to an analog signal y(t). The reconstruction is performed by a DAC followed by a 5-th order analog filter H(f), with cutoff frequency fc = BW. This analog filter combines the effects of h(t) and R(s) in FigureÂ 3.20.



The top plot in FigureÂ 3.21 shows the magnitude of the DTFT Y (e2Ï€Tsf) of ys(t) = D/S{y[n]}, superimposed to the frequency
response |H(f)| of the reconstruction filter. The multiples of Fs are identified in the grid of dashed lines. The bottom plot shows the magnitude of the resulting Fourier transform Y (f) = F{y(t)}.








FigureÂ 3.21: Reconstruction of a digital signal with BW = 25Â kHz and Fs = 200Â kHz using an analog filter with cutoff frequency fc = 25Â kHz.





FigureÂ 3.22 was obtained under the same conditions used for FigureÂ 3.21 but the signal bandwidth increased from 25 to 80Â kHz. In this case, the filter did not significantly attenuate the two spectrum replicas in Y (e2Ï€Tsf) that are neighbors of the one centered at f = 0. Thinking of an asymptotic Bode-diagram, one can expect the fifth-order |H(f)| to drop at 6Â dB/octave per pole and, from 80 to 160Â kHz, reach 5 Ã— (âˆ’6) = âˆ’30Â dB. The replica centered at 200Â kHz, for example, has its band starting at 120Â kHz, and the reconstruction filter has an attenuation of only (approximately) 20Â dB at 120Â kHz.








FigureÂ 3.22: Same as FigureÂ 3.21, but for a signal with BW = fc = 80Â kHz. In this case, the reconstruction generates significant out-of-band power due to the spectrum replicas.





As illustrated by FigureÂ 3.22, in practice, it is typically adopted a value for Fs large enough due to the non-ideal reconstruction filter. In the example corresponding to FigureÂ 3.21, in which the reconstruction seems adequate, the Nyquist frequency Fsâˆ•2 is four times the signal BW. Â Â â–¡


Combined digital filtering and D/S steps



When a digital filter Hz(z) (subindices will be used here to avoid confusion and disambiguate H(z) and H(s)) is part of an analog signal processing scheme such as the one depicted in FigureÂ 3.20, it is sometimes useful to combine the roles of Hz(z) and D/S into one â€œanalogâ€ filter with frequency response Hz(ejÏ‰Ts). This can be interpreted as a simple abscissa scaling in graphs such as FigureÂ 3.19. Another view is that, while Eq.Â (3.26) refers to a sampled signal, a corresponding version of an equivalent (analog) â€œsystemâ€ is









 Hs(Ï‰) = Hz(ejÎ©)| Î©=Ï‰Ts = Hz(ejÏ‰Ts ). 


(3.28)

title: 36Â  Facts About First and Second-Order Systems
text:
Because they are basic building blocks for higher-order filters, first and second-order systems are discussed in the sequel.





3.6.1Â Â First-order systems



If the coefficients are real, a first-order system H(s) = 1âˆ•(s + a),a âˆˆ â„, (as the one whose frequency response is depicted in FigureÂ 3.12) is restricted to have a lowpass frequency response. This H(s) has a pole at s = âˆ’a and a zero at s = âˆ. Using H(s) = aâˆ•(s + a) leads to a unitary gain at DC. Placing a zero at s = 0 leads to H(s) = sâˆ•(s + a), which has a highpass response.



A system H(s) = 1âˆ•(s + a) with ROC given by Ïƒ > âˆ’a has an inverse Laplace transform h(t) = eâˆ’atu(t), which can be written as h(t) = eâˆ’tâˆ•Ï„u(t) where Ï„ is the well-known time constant [url3mit]. After an interval of one time constant, the impulse response has decayed to 36.8% of its initial value.



If the ROC of H(s) = aâˆ•(s + a) includes s = jÏ‰, the frequency response in this case is H(Ï‰) = aâˆ•(jÏ‰ + a). As illustrated by Eq.Â (3.36), the magnitude |H(Ï‰)| = aâˆ•a2   + Ï‰2 at Ï‰ = a is then |H(a)| = 1âˆ•2, which is the cutoff frequency Ï‰c = a because it corresponds to a decrease of 3Â dB in power.





3.6.2Â Â Second-order systems



The system function H(s) of a second-order system (SOS), also called a two-pole resonator, has a denominator that can be written as s2 + 2Î±s + Ï‰n2. When there are two zeros at âˆ and the gain at DC is unitary (H(s)|s=0 = 1), the SOS is:









 H(s) = Ï‰n2 s2 + 2Î±s + Ï‰n2, 


(3.29)






where Ï‰n is the natural frequency and Î± the decay rate parameter, which is useful for defining the damping ratio Î¶ = Î±âˆ•Ï‰n. Hence, Eq.Â (3.29) can be rewritten as:









 H(s) = Ï‰n2 s2 + 2Î¶Ï‰ns + Ï‰n2. 


(3.30)






The values of Î±, Î¶ and Ï‰n can be related to several characteristics of a SOS. For example,

Î± represents the rate of exponential decay of oscillations when the system input is a unit step u(t). And depending on Î¶, three categories of second-order systems are defined:

title: 37Â  Bandwidth and Quality Factor
text:
3.7.1Â Â Bandwidth and Quality Factor of Poles



The overall behavior of a filter is dictated by the combined effect of its poles and zeros. The position of a pole in the s or Z plane determines how it influences the overall system function (H(s) or H(z), respectively).



It can be shown that asymptotically each pole contributes with a roll-off of 20Â dB per decade (equivalent to 6 dB per octave) and a zero with an increase of 20Â dB per decade. This asymptotic behavior is used to obtain graphs known as Bode diagrams. This clearly indicates that the sharpness of a frequency response (shorter transition regions) can be improved by increasing the order of the corresponding system function H(s) (or H(z)), i. e., adding poles and/or zeros. However, increasing the order of an analog filter requires more components (capacitors, opamps, etc.) and for a digital filter it requires more multiplications and additions. Hence, it is important to make the best use of poles (and zeros) and, motivated by that, to have figures of merit for them.



Besides its frequency, the bandwidth and quality factor of a single pole or zero are important to assess its influence. Poles will be emphasized in this section, but similar definitions are applied to zeros. This section discusses characteristics of a single pole while SectionÂ 3.7.2 extends the definitions to filters.





Bandwidth of a pole



The bandwidth of a pole is illustrated in FigureÂ 3.26 and defined here as BW = f2 âˆ’ f1, where the cutoff frequencies f1 and f2 are those in which the gain

|H(f0)| at the center frequency f0 (that may be different than the natural frequency fn) has decreased to |H(f0)|âˆ•2. The factor 1âˆ•2 corresponds to 20log â¡ 10(1âˆ•2) âˆ’ 3.0103Â dB, or approximately  âˆ’ 3Â dB. Therefore, this definition is called the 3-dB bandwidth or half-power BW.








FigureÂ 3.26: Bandwidth BW = f2 âˆ’ f1 defined by the cutoff frequencies where the gain falls  âˆ’ 3Â dB below the reference value at f0.




Pole bandwidth in continuous-time



Assuming a first-order system H(s) = âˆ’Î±âˆ•(s âˆ’ p), where p = Î± + jÏ‰0 is the pole, the bandwidth of p in Hz is given by









 BW = |Î±| Ï€ . 


(3.35)






This result can be obtained by noting that for any frequency Ï‰






 |H(Ï‰)| = |Î±| (Ï‰ âˆ’ Ï‰0   )2   + Î±2. 






Hence, the squared gain at the specific pole frequency Ï‰ = Ï‰0 is






 |H(Ï‰0)|2 = Î±2 (Ï‰0 âˆ’ Ï‰0)2 + Î±2 = 1 






and the squared gains at cutoff frequencies Ï‰ = Ï‰0 Â± Î± fall to 1âˆ•2 as required by the definition of cutoff frequency:









 |H(Ï‰0 Â± Î±)|2 = Î±2 (Ï‰0 Â± Î± âˆ’ Ï‰0)2 + Î±2 = 1 2. 


(3.36)






Hence, a range from Ï‰0 âˆ’ Î± to Ï‰0 + Î± is determined by the two cutoff frequencies of a pole at Ï‰0 such that its bandwidth BW is 2|Î±| rad/s. Dividing by 2Ï€ leads to BW = 2|Î±|âˆ•(2Ï€) in Hz, as indicated in Eq.Â (3.35). A similar relation holds in discrete-time, as follows.





Pole bandwidth in discrete-time



Using the previous results and assuming the transformation z = esTs of Eq.Â (2.48), the pole p = Î± + jÏ‰0 in the plane s is mapped
into the pole z = rejÎ©0 in the plane Z via






 rejÎ©0  = epTs  = e(Î±+jÏ‰0)Ts  = eÎ±Ts ejÏ‰0Ts . 






Hence, r = eÎ±Ts and Î©0 = Ï‰0Ts. Assuming Î± < 0 for a causal and stable H(s), Eq.Â (3.35) indicates that Î± = âˆ’BWÏ€, such that r = eÎ±Ts = eâˆ’BWÏ€Ts and









 BW = âˆ’ln â¡ (r) Ï€Ts 


(3.37)






in Hz for a pole rejÎ©0 in the Z plane with r < 1.



One can rewrite Eq.Â (3.37) as ln â¡ (r) = âˆ’BWÏ€Ts and use the Taylor series expansion of ln â¡ (â‹…) around a value x = a






 ln â¡ (x) = ln â¡ (a) + 1 a(x âˆ’ a) âˆ’ 1 2a2(x âˆ’ a)2 + 1 3a3(x âˆ’ a)3 âˆ’â€¦ â¡ , 






with a = 1, to keep only the first two terms and achieve






 ln â¡ (r) â‰ˆ ln â¡ (1) + 1 1(r âˆ’ 1) = r âˆ’ 1. 






Hence, the approximation r âˆ’ 1 â‰ˆâˆ’BWÏ€Ts allows to write









 BW â‰ˆ (1 âˆ’ r)Fs Ï€ , 


(3.38)






which can be used when r is close to 1.





Quality factor of poles



Besides the number of poles and zeros, another factor that influences the sharpness of a frequency response is the quality factor (or Q-factor) of each pole, which is defined as









 Q=def fn BW, 


(3.39)






where fn = Ï‰nâˆ•(2Ï€) is the natural frequency in Hz and BW = f2 âˆ’ f1 is the 3-dB bandwidth (also in Hz), as indicated in FigureÂ 3.26.



For a second-order resonator, such as Eq.Â (3.29), the quality factor can be shown [url3dsp] to be









 Q = Ï‰n 2Î±. 


(3.40)






AppplicationÂ 3.6 presents a discussion on the influence of the Q-factor in frequency responses.





3.7.2Â Â Bandwidth and Quality Factor of Filters



The previous definitions of bandwidth and Q-factor of poles can be extended to systems, especially frequency-selective filters such as bandpass and lowpass.





Bandwidth definitions for signals and systems






For a generic system there are definitions for the bandwidth (BW) other than the 3-dB bandwidth of FigureÂ 3.26. In all cases, if the frequency response has Hermitian symmetry, only the positive frequencies are taken in account.



A generalization of BW is to adopt the X-dB bandwidth where X is the attenuation of interest, such as 1Â dB.



Alternatively, the absolute bandwidth can be applied when the signal is bandlimited. It is simply defined as the frequency range in which the spectrum is non-zero. For example, H(f) = rect(f) has BW = 0.5. Note that in this case the 3-dB BW definition would not be appropriate.



Another alternative definition of BW is the so-called null-to-null or zero-crossing BW. In the case of a lowpass spectrum, the BW is determined by the first null of |H(Ï‰)| (or |H(Î©)| in discrete-time). For example, a frequency response given by the H(f) = sinc(fT) of Eq.Â (B.54) has BW = 1âˆ•T according to this definition. For a passband spectrum, the two neighbor nulls of the center frequency determine BW. For example, the BW of H(f) = sinc(fT âˆ’ 5T) is BW = 2âˆ•T.



When a signal is complex-valued, its spectrum X(f) does not have to exhibit Hermitian symmetry. In this case, the sampling theorem and other results depend on the double-sided or bilateral bandwidth, which takes in account the support of X(f) from negative to positive frequencies.



For example, first consider the â€œconventionalâ€ case of X(f) corresponding to a real-valued ideal lowpass filter with unitary gain from  âˆ’ 200 to 200Â Hz: its BW is 200Â Hz, and its double-sided bandwidth is 400Â Hz. Contrast now with a complex-valued signal
with X(f) being a square pulse from  âˆ’ 300 to 100Â Hz as depicted in FigureÂ 3.18. In the latter case, the double-sided bandwidth continues to be 400Â Hz but the conventional BW fails to indicate, for example, the minimum Fs according to the sampling theorem. In this case, the sampling theorem could be stated with respect to the double-sided bandwidth.



Another approach when dealing with complex-valued signals is to assume that X(f) is zero for negative frequencies (such signals are called â€œanalyticâ€). In this case, the bandwidth BW takes in account only positive frequencies, as usual, but it may be misleading the fact that the sampling theorem in this case of an analytic signal can be stated as









 Fs > BW. 


(3.41)






For example, if X(f) is non-zero from DC to 300Â Hz, sampling the corresponding complex-valued (analytic) time-domain signal x(t) at Fs = 350Â Hz suffices to avoid aliasing. In this case, the first spectrum replica at positive frequencies has support from 0 to 300Â Hz, the second one from 350 to 650Â Hz, and so on, indicating that there is no aliasing.



A bandwidth definition very useful when dealing with filtered white noise is the equivalent noise bandwidth (ENBW). The ENBW of a filter H(f) is the bandwidth of a fictitious ideal (e. g., lowpass or bandpass) filter He(f) with rectangular spectrum that obeys









 âˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆ|H(f)|2df = âˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆ|H e(f)|2df 


(3.42)






and has the maximum value Hmax of |He(f)| is equal to the maximum of |H(f)|. The name ENBW is because both filters lead to the same output power when the input is white noise (discussed in details later, in SectionÂ 4.5.2 ) such that the equivalent filter can substitute the original (and more complicated one) while leading, for instance, to the same SNR in a simulation or theoretical development.



An example is provided in FigureÂ 3.27, which was obtained with Matlabâ€™s function13 enbw as informed in ListingÂ 3.11. In this case, the ENBW was 102.4âˆ•50 â‰ˆ 2 times larger than the cutoff frequency.



ListingÂ 3.11: Code/MatlabBookFigures/figs_digicomm_enbw


Fs = 1000; %sampling frequency in Hz 
fc = 50; %filter cutoff frequency in Hz 
[B,A]=butter(4,fc/(Fs/2)); %4-th order Butterworth filter 
N=100; %number of samples in impulse response hn 
5hn = impz(B,A,100); %impulse response 
Hf = fftshift(fft(hn)); %sampled DTFT 
equivalentBW = enbw(hn,Fs); %estimate equivalent noise bandwidth 
%code to plot the figure continues from here...
  







FigureÂ 3.27: DTFT magnitude in dB of a 4-th order Butterworth filter with cutoff frequency of 50Â Hz and the equivalent ideal filter with absolute bandwidth of 102.4 Hz.





Observing FigureÂ 3.27, due to the rectangular shape of |He(f)|,






 âˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆ|H e(f)|2df = 2Â ENBW Ã— Hmax2. 






Hence, using Eq.Â (3.42) this can be written as:









 ENBW = âˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆ|H(f)|2df 2Hmax2 , 


(3.43)






which for real signals simplify to









 ENBW = âˆ« 0âˆ|H(f)|2df Hmax2 . 


(3.44)





Quality factor for filters






The Q-factor of a pole, as defined in Eq.Â (3.39), can be easily adapted to a system with a frequency response that allows obtaining its 3-dB bandwidth BW (see FigureÂ 3.26) such as a bandpass filter.14 In this case, the pole natural frequency fn in Eq.Â (3.39) is substituted by the filterâ€™s center frequency fc such that









 Q=def fc BW. 


(3.45)






The inverse of Q, i. e., BWâˆ•fc is called fractional bandwidth and often specified in percentage.


 

13Â The function enbw was designed for lowpass (windows) spectra with the maximum value at DC. It does not work for passband spectra.

 

14Â Actually, the Q factor is used in several areas of engineering and physics.

                          </div>

title: 38Â  Importance of Linear Phase (or Constant Group Delay)
text:
In some applications such as analog signal transmission and audio amplification, the system should ideally have an output y(t) identical to its input x(t). Given that obtaining y(t) = x(t) is often unfeasible due to propagation delays inherent of communication channels and electronic systems, a more realistic target is to obtain y(t) = x(t âˆ’ t0), a delayed version of the input. From the time-shift Fourier property (see AppendixÂ B.17), the delay by t0 corresponds to a linear phase eâˆ’j2Ï€ft0 in frequency domain. Hence, having a linear phase is an important property of a system to achieve distortionless transmission, i. e., letting a signal pass without distortion.



A linear phase filter with frequency response H(Ï‰) has a phase Î˜ = âˆ H(Ï‰) that corresponds to a line segment in the passband (the phase behavior in the stopband is considered irrelevant). In practice, the line has a negative slope because a positive slope would correspond to a non-causal behavior (the output would be an anticipated version x(t + t0) of the input signal). Hence, it is convenient to define the group delay as:









 Ï„g(Ï‰) = âˆ’dÎ˜ dÏ‰. 


(3.46)






Similarly, the discrete-time version is









 Ï„g(ejÎ©) = âˆ’dÎ˜ dÎ© 


(3.47)






with Î˜ = âˆ H(ejÎ©).



 Example 3.11. Impact of the system phase on the output signal. To help understanding the practical importance of a system with linear phase, it is adopted a periodic pulse x[n] with N1 = 15 (number of non-zero samples in a period) and period N = 50 (see ExampleÂ 2.12). The experiment is to obtain Y [k] by multiplying the DTFS X[k] of x[n] by eâˆ’j2Ï€N0kâˆ•N, where N0 = 4. ListingÂ 3.12 carries out the operation, including the conversion of Y [k] to y[n].



ListingÂ 3.12: MatlabOctaveCodeSnippets/snip_systems_linear_phase_system.m


%Specify: N-period, N1/N-duty cicle, N0-delay, k-frequency 
N=50; N1=15; N0=4; k=0:N-1; 
xn=[ones(1,N1) zeros(1,N-N1)]; %x[n] 
Xk=fft(xn)/N; %calculate the DTFS of x[n] 
5phase = -2*pi/N*N0*k; %define linear phase 
Yk=Xk.*exp(j*phase); %impose the linear phase 
yn=ifft(Yk)*N; %recover signal in time domain
  


FigureÂ 3.28 illustrates the result: y[n] = x[n âˆ’ N0] is a perfect delayed version of x[n]. The middle plot shows the phase that was added to the original phase of X[k]. The magnitude of X[k] was left unchanged but that would not be enough to keep the shape of x[n] in case the phase was not linear with frequency.








FigureÂ 3.28: Effect of adding a linear phase eâˆ’j2Ï€N0kâˆ•N (N0 = 4 and N = 50) to the DTFS of x[n] resulting in a delayed version y[n] = x[n âˆ’ 4] .





To be contrasted with the linear phase case, FigureÂ 3.29 provides an example where the phase is 0, 2 or  âˆ’ 2 rad, as depicted in the top-most plot. In order to assure that y[n] is real, the phase is an odd function to preserve the Hermitian symmetry.








FigureÂ 3.29: Effect of adding the specified nonlinear phase (top) to the pulse in FigureÂ 3.28, which leads to a distorted signal (bottom).





Note that in the case of FigureÂ 3.29, the pulses in x[n] are severely distorted due to the effect of a non-linear phase. Â  Â â–¡



Considering continuous-time (same is valid for discrete-time), a linear phase eâˆ’j2Ï€ft0 avoids distorting an input signal x(t) because the system delays all components of x(t) by the same time interval t0. To obtain that, a linear phase system adds to the input signal component with frequency fi, a phase Î˜i = âˆ’2Ï€fit0 that is proportional to fi (the larger fi, the larger the phase Î˜i added by the system). The following example concerns this aspect.



 Example 3.12. A linear phase allows components with distinct frequencies to be delayed by the same angle. For example, assume components corresponding to Ï‰ = 200 and 400 rad/s with t0 = 4Â s. The phases Î˜ = Ï‰t0 are 800 and 1600 rad, respectively. On the other hand, if these two components pass a system that adds a fixed phase Î˜ = 1200 rad to both, the delays would be 6 and 3 s, respectively, which would potentially distort the delayed version with respect to the original signal x(t). Â  Â â–¡



For non-linear phase filters, the group delay must be interpreted as an average delay that is frequency-dependent (compare FigureÂ 3.49 and FigureÂ 3.50).15



 Example 3.13. Gaussian filter and minimum group delay. In some applications, such as digital communications, minimizing the group delay is important to achieve low latency. In this case, the Gaussian filter is competitive because it has the minimum possible group delay. As a consequence, this filter has no overshoot to an input u(t) while minimizing the rise and fall time intervals. Its non-causal (and ideal, which requires truncation in practice) impulse response is









 h(t) = Ï€ Î± eâˆ’ (Ï€t Î± )2 , 


(3.48)






where Î± controls the 3-dB bandwidth BW. More specifically, Î± depends on the product of BW and the symbol period Tsym as follows:









 Î± = 1 BWTsym ln â¡   2 2 . 


(3.49)






The frequency response of this filter is H(f) = eâˆ’Î±2f2  and decreases with f but is not zero for finite f. Â Â â–¡


 

15Â After discussing digital filters, their phase and group delay will be exemplified in FigureÂ 3.49 and FigureÂ 3.50.

                                                                                                              </div>

title: 39Â  Filtering technologies: Surface acoustic wave (SAW) and others
text:
There are several technologies to build an electronic filter. The options include ceramic, microelectromechanical system (MEMS), yttrium iron garnet (YIG), SAW and many others. Even if the scope is reduced to radio-frequency (RF) communications, the diversity of filters is huge. Consequently, parameters such as the Q-factor, center frequency fc and insertion loss IL(f) (which is the inverse of the insertion gain IG(f) = 1âˆ•IL(f), as discussed in SectionÂ B.25), vary widely. This section provides some practical examples.



 Example 3.14. Performance of commercial SAW filter. FigureÂ 3.30 illustrates the typical performance of a commercial SAW filter16 with some of its specifications listed in TableÂ 3.4. The insertion gain IG(f) is shown in FigureÂ 3.30 at 1 and 10Â dB per division (div) at the left plot and superimposed (at 1Â dB per division) to the group delay at the right plot.

The insertion loss IL(f)|f=fc at fc = 70.12Â MHz is 24.7Â dB. The group delay plot only shows the variation at the order of ns, but TableÂ 3.4 indicates the delay as 1.6Â Î¼s.
