2Â Similar to the amplitudes, the absolute power values inferred from of an FFT-based analysis require correctionÂ Â [?].

 

3Â See, e. g., the presentation by Matt Ettus at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wqKNUXDdIvU.

title: 53Â  The ESD, PSD and MS Spectrum functions
text:
4.4.1Â Â Energy spectral density (ESD)



The ESD is a convenient tool for analyzing energy signals, informing how the total energy E is distributed over frequency. The (Parseval) TheoremÂ 2 (at page Â§) for block transforms can be extended to continuous and discrete-time signals. For continuous-time, together with Eq.Â (1.40), one has









 E = âˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆ|x(t)|2dt = âˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆ|X(f)|2df, 


(4.11)






stating that the energy is the same in both time and frequency domains. This suggests defining G(f) = |X(f)|2 as the ESD in continuous-time because G(f) describes how the signal energy E is spread over frequency and its integral is E. The adopted units for the ESD are Joules/Hz.



 Example 4.5. ESD of a real-valued exponential. Consider the signal x(t) = eâˆ’atu(t) in Volts, where a = 0.9. Its Fourier transform is X(f) = 1âˆ•(j2Ï€f + a) and the ESD in Joules/Hertz is






 G(f) = |X(f)|2 = 1 (2Ï€f)2 + a2. 






The signal energy is E = âˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆ|x(t)|2dt = âˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆG(f)df â‰ˆ 0.55556. ListingÂ 4.6 illustrates how E can be estimated in time-domain and also using G(f). In this case, the range ] âˆ’âˆ,âˆ[ is simulated as [0,30]Â s and [âˆ’1000,1000]Â Hz in time and frequency-domain, respectively.



ListingÂ 4.6: MatlabOctaveCodeSnippets/snip_frequency_exp_esd.m


%% Generate time-domain signal 
Ts=0.0001; %defines resolution in time 
t=0:Ts:30; %time axis 
a=0.9; %constant 
5x=exp(-a*t); %signal 
subplot(211), plot(t,x) 
xlabel('t (s)'); ylabel('x(t) amplitude') 
%% Generate ESD 
f=linspace(-2,2,1000); %frequency axis 
10Gf= 1 ./ ((2*pi*f).^2 + a^2); %ESD 
subplot(212) 
plot(t,x), plot(f,Gf) 
xlabel('f (Hz)'); ylabel('ESD (J/Hz)') 
%% Confirm Parseval theorem 
15energy_equation = 1/(2*a); %theoretical 
energy_time = sum(abs(x).^2)*Ts; %integration 
df=0.0001; %defines resolution in frequency 
min_f = -1000; %range of interest 
max_f = 1000; 
20f=min_f:df:max_f; %frequency axis 
Gf= 1 ./ ((2*pi*f).^2 + a^2); %recalculate ESD 
energy_frequency = sum(Gf)*df; %integration 
disp(['Theoretical energy =' num2str(energy_equation) ' Joules']) 
disp(['Integration in time =' num2str(energy_time) ' Joules']) 
25disp(['Integration in frequency =' num2str(energy_frequency) ' J']) 
%% Energy in given frequency band 
min_f = 0.2; max_f = 1; %range of interest 
f=min_f:df:max_f; %new frequency axis 
Gf= 1 ./ ((2*pi*f).^2 + a^2); %recalculate ESD 
30energy_band = 2*sum(Gf)*df; %integration using 2 times 
disp(['Energy in band =' num2str(energy_band) ' Joules'])
  


ListingÂ 4.6 also illustrates how G(f) can be conveniently used to estimate the energy within a given frequency band. In this example, the energy within the range from 0.2 to 1Â Hz, considering both negative and positive frequencies, is Er = 2âˆ« 0.21G(f)df â‰ˆ 0.16954Â J. Â  Â â–¡



 Example 4.6. ESD of a sinc in time-domain. Now consider the signal is x(t) = 400sinc(100t) in Volts. According to Eq.Â (B.55) and using the linearity of the Fourier transform to take in account a factor of 4, one has X(f) = 4 for |f|â‰¤ 50Â Hz and 0 otherwise. Hence, the ESD of x(t) is G(f) = 16 for |f|â‰¤ 50Â Hz and 0 otherwise. In this case, using the ESD instead of x(t), it is easy to conclude that the total signal energy is

E = 16 Ã— 100 = 1600Â Joules. Â  Â â–¡



There is a subtle issue when using radians per second instead of Hertz. In this case, G(Ï‰) = |X(Ï‰)|2 and the factor 1âˆ•(2Ï€) must be taken in account, such that:









 E = âˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆ|x(t)|2dt = 1 2Ï€âˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆ|X(Ï‰)|2dÏ‰ = 1 2Ï€âˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆG(Ï‰)dÏ‰. 


(4.12)






As a consequence of these definitions and taking in account that G(Ï‰) = G(2Ï€f), the unit of G(Ï‰) is Joules/Hz, not Joules/(rad/s). This issue is similar to the one discussed in SectionÂ 2.5.4 for the Fourier transforms X(f) and X(Ï‰).



 Example 4.7. The unit of G(Ï‰) is Joules/Hz, not Joules/(rad/s). For instance, take the sinc signal of ExampleÂ 4.6, which has a flat ESD given by G(f) = 16Â J/Hz within the range [âˆ’50,50]Â Hz and zero otherwise. The representation G(Ï‰) of this ESD in rad/s has the same constant value G(Ï‰) = 16 but now over the range [âˆ’100Ï€,100Ï€]Â rad/s. For the sake of argument, let us assume G(Ï‰) = 16 were interpreted as indicating values in J/(rad/s). Within the range [âˆ’100Ï€,100Ï€], one would have 16 Ã— 200Ï€ = 3200Ï€Â J. But we know the correct value is 1600Â J. Â Â â–¡



It is then more adequate to interpret that G(Ï‰) provides the same numerical values of G(f)
in J/Hz, but when G(Ï‰) is shown in a plot or integrated, its abscissa range is enlarged by a factor of 2Ï€ to indicate angular frequency Ï‰ = 2Ï€f.



One could eventually adopt a definition G~(Ï‰) = 1 2Ï€|X(Ï‰)|2 that incorporates the 1âˆ•(2Ï€) factor such that G~(Ï‰) would be given in J/(rad/s). But this would break the connection between G(f) and G(Ï‰) and is not adopted. This reasoning is also applied when dealing with the power spectral density.



In continuous-time spectral analysis, the linear frequency in Hertz is more convenient and angular frequencies are seldom adopted. But this is not an option in discrete-time processing, given that Î© is an angle (assumed in radians) and does not have a counterpart in Hertz. Hence, the ESD in discrete-time









 G(ejÎ©) = |X(ejÎ©)|2 


(4.13)






is given in Joules per normalized frequency rad/(2Ï€), such that









 E = âˆ‘ n=âˆ’âˆâˆ|x[n]|2 = 1 2Ï€âˆ« <2Ï€>|X(ejÎ©)|2dÎ©. 


(4.14)






 Example 4.8. Creation of digital frequency Dhertz (DHz) such that the unit of G(ejÎ©) is Joules/DHz. Assume a normalized digital frequency ğ”½ defined as









 ğ”½=def Î© 2Ï€, 


(4.15)






where Î© is the discrete-time angular frequency in radians. The digital linear frequency ğ”½ is also an angle but we will interpret its unit as Dhertz (Dhz), the digital Hertz. The continuous-time Hertz can be seen as the number of occurrences in one second, while Dhertz is interpreted as the number of occurrences between two neighboring discrete-time samples n and n + 1. Similar to Ï‰0 = 2Ï€f0 = 2Ï€âˆ•T0, the discrete-time versions are Î©0 = 2Ï€ğ”½0 = 2Ï€âˆ•N0.



An analogy follows. The continuous-time signal x(t) with fundamental period T0 = 4Â s has frequency f0 = 1âˆ•T0 = 0.25Â Hz. The interpretation is that in one second, there are 0.25 occurrences of a period of x(t). A discrete-time signal x[n] with fundamental period N0 = 4 samples has frequency ğ”½ = 1âˆ•N0 = 0.25Â Dhz. The interpretation is that between the occurrence of two consecutive samples of x[n], there are 0.25 occurrences of its period. Instead of Dhz, Matlab/Octaveuses the notation â€œper sampleâ€.



Using Eq.Â (4.15), one can have an ESD G(ejğ”½) with unit Joules / Dhertz and the following property:









 E = âˆ« 01G(ejğ”½)dğ”½. 


(4.16)






Similar to what was discussed in ExampleÂ 4.7, the units of both G(ejğ”½) and G(ejÎ©) is Joules / Dhertz, with the abcissas being ğ”½ in Dhz and Î© in radians, respectively. Â Â â–¡



In most cases, the signal under analysis has infinite energy, such as a power signal (e. g. a periodic signal) or realizations of a stationary random process. Therefore, the main interest in spectral analysis relies not on the ESD but on the PSD, which is the next subject. Noticing from Eq.Â (4.11) and (4.14) that squared magnitudes provide the energy distribution over frequency, to obtain the power distribution one can intuitively consider dividing the ESD by â€œtimeâ€, via a normalization factor that converts energy into power.





4.4.2Â Â Power spectral density (PSD)



The PSD has the important property that the average power P can be obtained in continous-time by









 Pc = âˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆS(f)df, 


(4.17)






with S(f) in Watts/Hz, or in discrete-time by









 Pd = âˆ« <1>S(ejğ”½)dğ”½, 


(4.18)






with S(ejğ”½) in Watts/Dhz (or Watts/â€œnormalized frequencyâ€).



Similar to the reasoning associated to Eq.Â (4.12), the version of Eq.Â (4.17) when the continuous-time PSD S(Ï‰) is a function of Ï‰ = 2Ï€f in rad/s is









 Pc = 1 2Ï€âˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆS(Ï‰)dÏ‰. 


(4.19)






The equivalent in discrete-time is









 Pd = 1 2Ï€âˆ« <2Ï€>S(ejÎ©)dÎ©. 


(4.20)






In all four equations, the PSDs describe the distribution of power over frequency or a normalized frequency.





PSD of Random Signal



Random signals are important in many applications, such as in digital communications. One useful model for these signals is the wide-sense stationary (WSS) random process with autocorrelation R(Ï„).



The PSD S(f) for a continuous-time power signal x(t) corresponding to a realization of a WSS stochastic process X(t) is defined as









 S(f)=deflim â¡  Tâ†’âˆğ”¼[|XT (f)|2] T , 


(4.21)






where XT (f) is the Fourier transform of a truncated (windowed) version of x(t) with duration T. In other words, XT (f) = F{xT (t)} where xT (t) = x(t) for  âˆ’ Tâˆ•2 â‰¤ t â‰¤ Tâˆ•2 or zero otherwise.



An alternative to obtaining a PSD via Eq.Â (4.21) is using the Wiener-Khinchin theorem,4 which states that the power spectral density (PSD) S(f) of a WSS process is the Fourier transform of the corresponding autocorrelation function, i. e.









 S(f) = F{R(Ï„)}. 


(4.22)






Similar expressions exist in discrete-time and even for deterministic signals.



For example, in discrete-time processing, the PSD is the DTFT of the autocorrelation function:









 S(ejÎ©) = âˆ‘ â„“=âˆ’âˆâˆR[â„“]eâˆ’jÎ©â„“, 


(4.23)






where â„“ âˆˆ â„¤ is the lag, and the inverse DTFT gives









 R[â„“] = 1 2Ï€âˆ« âˆ’Ï€Ï€S(ejÎ©)ejÎ©â„“dÎ©. 


(4.24)






Similar to Eq.Â (4.21), the PSD S(ejÎ©) for a discrete-time power signal x[n] corresponding to a realization of a WSS stochastic process X[n] is defined as









 S(ejÎ©)=deflim â¡   Nâ†’âˆ 1 Nğ”¼  [ |âˆ‘ n=0Nâˆ’1x[n]eâˆ’jÎ©n| 2] = lim â¡   Nâ†’âˆ 1 Nğ”¼  [ |XN(ejÎ©)|2] . 


(4.25)






where XN(ejÎ©) is the DTFT of xN[n], a truncated version of x[n] obtained via a rectangular window of N non-zero samples. The unit of S(ejÎ©) is Watts per normalized frequency Î©âˆ•(2Ï€).



In practice, there is a finite number of realizations of X[n] and often only one realization x[n] is available. Fortunately, ergodicity of the autocorrelation can be assumed in many cases and the ensemble averages substituted by averages taken over time (see AppendixÂ B.19). Besides, the number of samples (the duration of x[n]) is often limited to a given value that can be determined, for example, by the time over which the process can be considered stationary. For example, in speech analysis applications, it is typically assumed the process of vowel production is quasi-stationary over segments with durations from 40 to 80Â ms. With limited-duration signals, the challenge for spectral analysis is to obtain accurate estimates, as discussed in this chapter.



For both Eq.Â (4.21) and Eq.Â (4.25), windows other than the rectangular can be used. But the rectangular window is used in the definition of a PSD.





PSD of Deterministic and Periodic Signal






When adapted to deterministic signals, which do not require the expected value, Eq.Â (4.21) is written as S(f) = lim â¡  Tâ†’âˆ|XT(f)|2 T , which is the ESD normalized by the time interval T, as expected. A special case of deterministic signals are the periodic ones.



Assuming a continuous-time signal x(t) with period T0, its PSD is









 S(f) = âˆ‘ k=âˆ’âˆâˆ|c k|2Î´(f âˆ’ kF 0), 


(4.26)






where ck are the Fourier Series coefficients and F0 = 1âˆ•T0 is the fundamental frequency. Similarly, for S(Ï‰), the expression is









 S(Ï‰) = 2Ï€âˆ‘ k=âˆ’âˆâˆ|c k|2Î´(f âˆ’ kÏ‰ 0), 


(4.27)






where Ï‰0 = (2Ï€)âˆ•T0Â rad/s.



In summary, the PSD of a deterministic (non-random) periodic signal is composed by impulses with areas determined by the squared magnitude of Fourier series coefficients.



 Example 4.9. PSD of a continuous-time sinusoid. If x(t) = Acos â¡ (2Ï€fct), then S(f) = A2 4  [Î´(f + fc) + Î´(f âˆ’ fc)] and the average power is âˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆS(f)df = A2âˆ•2. Â Â â–¡



When considering a discrete-time periodic signal x[n], its PSD S(ejÎ©) can be obtained by first considering an expression SÂ â€²(ejÎ©) for the frequency range [0,2Ï€[:









 SÂ â€²(ejÎ©) = 2Ï€âˆ‘ k=0N0 âˆ’1|X~[k]|2Î´(Î© âˆ’ kÎ© 0), 


(4.28)






where N0 is the period, Î©0 = (2Ï€)âˆ•N0 is the fundamental frequency, and X~[k] the DTFS of x[n]. Finally, the PSD S(ejÎ©) is simply the periodic repetition of SÂ â€²(ejÎ©):









 S(ejÎ©) = âˆ‘ p=âˆ’âˆâˆSÂ â€²(ej(Î©+p2Ï€)). 


(4.29)






 Example 4.10. PSD of a discrete-time sinusoid. If x[n] = Acos â¡ (Î©1n) (assume Î©1 obeys Eq.Â (1.39) to have x[n] periodic), then SÂ â€²(ejÎ©) = Ï€A2 2  [Î´(Î© + Î©1) + Î´(Î© âˆ’Î©1)] and






 S(ejÎ©) = âˆ‘ p=âˆ’âˆâˆÏ€A2 2  [Î´(Î© + Î©1 + p2Ï€) + Î´(Î© âˆ’Î©1 + p2Ï€)] 






provides its PSD, which has period 2Ï€, as expected. Â Â â–¡





4.4.3Â Â Fourier Modulation Theorem Applied to PSDs



If Sx(f) is the PSD of a WSS random process X(t), the PSD Sy(f) of a new process Y (t) = X(t)ej2Ï€fct is









 Sy(f) = Sx(f âˆ’ fc). 


(4.30)






Similarly, if Y (t) = X(t)cos â¡ (2Ï€fct), then









 Sy(f) = 1 4  [Sx(f + fc) + Sx(f âˆ’ fc)]. 


(4.31)






To observe why Eq.Â (4.30) (and, consequently, Eq.Â (4.31)) is true, recall the Wiener-Khinchin theorem of Eq.Â (4.22) and the autocorrelation definition of Eq.Â (1.56). Generally speaking, when modifying a WSS process X(t), the effect on its PSD can be obtained by checking how the modification affects its autocorrelation, and then relating this to frequency domain using Eq.Â (4.22). For example, multiplying X(t) by a scalar Î± corresponds to scaling its autocorrelation Rx(Ï„) by Î±2 and leads to a PSD Î±2Sx(f) given the linearity of the Fourier transform.



According to this reasoning, a proof sketch of Eq.Â (4.30) follows:



 Sy(f)  = F{Ry(Ï„)}     = F{ğ”¼[Y (t + Ï„)Y âˆ—(t)]}     = F{ğ”¼[X(t + Ï„)ej2Ï€fc(t+Ï„)Xâˆ—(t)eâˆ’j2Ï€fct]}     = F{ej2Ï€fcÏ„ğ”¼[X(t + Ï„)Xâˆ—(t)]}     = F{ej2Ï€fcÏ„R x(Ï„)}     = Sx(f âˆ’ fc).    

Eq.Â (4.31) can be obtained by decomposing the cosine cos â¡ (2Ï€fct) = 1âˆ•2(ej2Ï€fct + eâˆ’j2Ï€fct) into two complex exponentials and taking in account that the factor Î± = 1âˆ•2 leads to the 1âˆ•4 in the PSD expression. Eq.Â (4.31) allows to observe that the result of a signal multiplied by a cosine of unitary amplitude has half of the original signal power.





4.4.4Â Â Mean-square (MS) spectrum



The PSD is very useful especially when dealing with random signals and the power of the signal over a frequency range is obtained by integrating the PSD over that range. However, in some cases it is desired to use a function that allows to directly infer the average power of sinusoid components of a periodic signal, without the integration step. In these cases, the so-called MS or power spectrum is more convenient.5



While in continuous-time the PSD S(f) unit is Watts/Hz, the mean-square spectrum is given directly in Watts and, assuming a periodic signal, corresponds to the squared magnitude of its DTFS:









 Sms[k] = |DTFS{x[n]}|2, 


(4.32)






with the property









 âˆ‘ k=0Nâˆ’1Sms[k] = P, 


(4.33)






where P is the signal power and N is the FFT-size.



Recall from the discussion associated to Eq.Â (2.44) that, if x[n] is periodic with fundamental period N0, its DTFS X~[k] can be obtained with an N0-point FFT:









 X~[k] = FFT{x[n]} N0 . 


(4.34)






One often uses Eq.Â (4.34) even for a non-periodic x[n], but then the result spectrum must be properly interpreted: as if the signal were a periodic version âˆ‘ â¡ p=âˆ’âˆâˆxN[n âˆ’ pN] of the windowed version xN[n] of x[n] using N samples.



If the FFT size N is chosen as N = N0, the k-th FFT value corresponds exactly to the k-th DTFS coefficient, that is, they both represent the same frequency k(2Ï€âˆ•N) = k(2Ï€âˆ•N0). In case Nâ‰ N0, Eq.Â (4.33) is still a valid way to obtain the average power P, but the frequencies must be interpreted according to the FFT grid k(2Ï€âˆ•N).



In general, an estimate Åœms[k] of the MS spectrum of a discrete-time signal x[n] can be obtained from its N-length windowed version xN[n] with









 Åœms[k] = |DTFS{xN[n]}|2 =  |FFT{xN[n]} N |2. 


(4.35)






As mentioned, the power distribution of a deterministic signal such as a sum of sinusoids is more conveniently analyzed via its MS spectrum. However, in many practical engineering applications, there is some random noise involved and, even when the signal of interest is deterministic, its noisy version (such as sinusoids contaminated by AWGN) suggests using the PSD representation instead of the MS spectrum.


 

4Â See, e. g. [url3wie] and note that a realization x(t) of a WSS process X(t) is not square integrable and does not have a Fourier transform.

 

5Â Matlab (but not Octave) has a msspectrum spectral estimator and the private functions welch.m and computeperiodogram.m can be studied.

                                                                           </div>

title: 54Â  Filtering Random Signals and the Impact on PSDs
text:
This section investigates the result of processing a random input signal through a system, and how the output PSD relates to the input.





4.5.1Â Â Response of LTI systems to random inputs



An important result of stochastic processes theory is that when the input of a LTI system is a WSS process X(t), the corresponding output is also a WSS process Y (t), as indicated below






 X(t)â†’Â h(t) â†’Y (t), 






where h(t) is the impulse response of the LTI system.



Given that H(f) = F{h(t)} is the frequency response of the system, the relationship between the PSDs Sy(f) and Sx(f) of Y (t) and X(t), respectively, is given by









 Sy(f) = |H(f)|2S x(f). 


(4.36)






Similarly, if a discrete-time WSS random process X[n] is filtered by a LTI with impulse response h[n] as in






 X[n]â†’Â h[n] â†’Y [n], 






the PSD of the WSS output process Y [n] is given by









 Sy(ejÎ©) = |H(ejÎ©)|2S x(ejÎ©), 


(4.37)






where H(ejÎ©) is the DTFT of h[n].





4.5.2Â Â Continuous-time signals with a white PSD and their filtering



A signal model that is used in several applications is the white noise, previously discussed in SectionÂ 1.12.1.0. A realization Î½(t) of a continuous-time white noise process has autocorrelation









 R(Ï„) = ğ”¼[Î½(t)Î½(t âˆ’ Ï„)] = N0 2 Î´(Ï„) 


(4.38)






and zero mean Î¼ = ğ”¼[Î½(t)] = 0.



Using Eq.Â (4.22), the bilateral PSD of a white noise is









 S(f) = F  {N0 2 Î´(Ï„)} = N0 2 ,Â Â Â âˆ€ â¡f. 


(4.39)






When a unilateral representation is adopted, the white PSD is conveniently denoted as S(f) = N0. For instance, if N0 = 6Â W/Hz is the constant level of a unilateral PSD, its bilateral representation has a constant level of N0âˆ•2 = 3Â W/Hz. Writing N0âˆ•2 and N0 for the bilateral and unilateral PSDs, respectively, the average power over a given frequency band6 BW is always









 P = N0BW 


(4.40)






for both representations, given that in the case of a bilateral PSD one needs to multiply it by 2BW to find the average power.



Note from Eq.Â (4.38) and Eq.Â (1.60) that the continuous-time white noise power is R(0) = âˆ because there is an impulse in Ï„ = 0 (the area is N0âˆ•2 but the amplitude goes to infinite). Another way of observing that the continuous time WGN has infinite power is looking at the frequency domain: its PSD is S(f) = N0 2 , such that from Eq.Â (4.17), the area under the curve goes to infinite.



With infinite power, a white noise cannot be measured (it would damage the measuring equipment!). But white noise is a very good model for many practical applications, with an implicit assumption that limits the frequencies to some bandwidth of interest and makes measurements and simulations feasible. In other words, the noise can have a flat PSD only over a given finite bandwidth but, for the purpose of the experiment / simulation, be conveniently modeled as white noise.



Because power can be written as P = Ïƒ2 + Î¼2, and Î¼ = 0, the continuous-time white noise variance Ïƒ2 is infinite.



If the input X(t) is white noise with autocorrelation R(Ï„) = (N0âˆ•2)Î´(Ï„) and PSD N0âˆ•2, Eq.Â (4.36) informs that the PSD at the output of the LIT system is









 Sy(f) = |H(f)|2N0 2 , 


(4.41)







e., Sy(f) is a scaled version of |H(f)|2.




A special case of white noise is the Gaussian or WGN, introduced earlier in SectionÂ 1.12.1.0.





4.5.3Â Â Discrete-time signals with a white PSD and their filtering



It is important to distinguish the continuous-time white noise, which has a flat bilateral PSD with value N0âˆ•2 Watts/Hz and infinite power, from the discrete-time white noise that has finite power typically denoted by Ïƒ2. To emphasize the similarities and differences between continuous and discrete-time white noise, the goals here are to discuss how to: 1) generate a discrete-time white noise, 2) interpret the conversion of a continuous-time white noise into a discrete-time version and 3) its conversion back to continuous-time.





Discrete-time white noise



As mentioned, a discrete-time white process X[n] has its power ğ”¼[X2[n]] = Ïƒx2 coinciding with the variance Ïƒx2 because the mean Î¼x has to be zero for white processes. Moreover, its bilateral PSD level Sx(ejÎ©) = Ïƒx2 Watts per normalized frequency (or Dhertz) coincides with its variance in Watts. To observe that, denote the constant PSD value as Î± and note from Eq.Â (4.20) that






 P = Ïƒ2 = 1 2Ï€âˆ« <2Ï€>S(ejÎ©)dÎ© = 1 2Ï€2Ï€Î± = Î±. 






In other words, the constant PSD level Î± has the same numerical value of the power Ïƒ2 in Watts, but should be interpreted as having unit of Watts per normalized frequency, as discussed in ExampleÂ 4.7 and ExampleÂ 4.8. In case of a unilateral PSD, the constant value Î± = 2Ïƒ2 would be twice the power.



Therefore, a discrete-time bilateral white PSD (with a constant level) can be denoted as:









 S(ejÎ©) = N0 2 = Ïƒx2 = P. 


(4.42)






This result may be confusing because the values of power and spectral density coincide.



Denoting as Sx(ejÎ©) = Ïƒx2 the PSD of a white noise at the input of a filter H(ejÎ©), Eq.Â (4.37) leads to an output PSD given by









 Sy(ejÎ©) = Ïƒ x2|H(ejÎ©)|2. 


(4.43)






Eq.Â (4.43) suggests that the output PSD Sy(ejÎ©) has its shape |H(ejÎ©)|2 imposed by the filter, given that the input PSD Ïƒx2 is simply a scaling factor.



 Example 4.11. Generation of uniform and Gaussian white noise using Matlab/Octave. A discrete-time white noise with i. i. d.Â samples is relatively easy to generate in Matlab/Octave using functions that implement random number generators. For example, x=rand(1,1000)-0.5 creates a signal with an autocorrelation that approximates an impulse at the origin and 1,000 samples that are uniformly distributed. The subtraction of 0.5 is necessary to make Î¼ = 0. Similarly, a discrete-time version of WGN (Gaussian, not a uniform distribution) can be generated with x=randn(1,1000). Â Â â–¡





Converting white noise from continuous to discrete-time



The signals discussed in the previous section were already created in discrete-time. But in some cases the discrete-time white noise is obtained from a continuous-time version or should be interpreted as such.



For example, assume Î½(t) is a continuous-time WGN submitted to filtering by an ideal lowpass filter and A/D conversion, as illustrated by the following block diagram:



 Î½(t) â†’Â h(t)â†’Â A/D â†’Î½[n].   


From Eq.Â (4.36), the PSD at the output of h(t) is S(f) = |H(f)|2N0âˆ•2. If the filter is ideal and the A/D conversion does not incur in aliasing, the PSD S(ejÎ©) of Î½[n] is a scaled and periodic version of S(f). Therefore, it is white in discrete-time.



Assuming that h(t) is an ideal lowpass filter of bandwidth BW = Fsâˆ•2 (gain equal to 1 over the band  âˆ’ Fsâˆ•2 to Fsâˆ•2Â Hz and zero otherwise), where Fs is the A/D sampling frequency, then the PSD of the continuous-time signal at the output of h(t) is S(f) = N0âˆ•2 over BW and its power is P = (2BW)(N0âˆ•2) = BWN0. Under the same assumptions of Eq.Â (1.51), the power values in discrete and continuous-time are the same, such that the power of Î½[n] is denoted by its variance Ïƒ2 = BWN0.



 Example 4.12. Discretizing white noise. For example, given that white noise with N0âˆ•2 = 3 W/Hz is converted to a discrete-time signal Î½[n] via the cascade of an ideal lowpass filter h(t) with passband BW = Fsâˆ•2 and an A/D process with Fs = 200Â Hz, the power of the signal at the output of the ideal lowpass filter h(t) is






 BWN0 = Fs 2 N0 = 100 Ã— 6 = 600W 






and the power of Î½[n] is Ïƒ2 = BWN0 = 600Â W.



                                   <div class='center'>








FigureÂ 4.7: PSD Sx(f) of a continuous-time white noise with N0âˆ•2 = 3 W/Hz (top) and its discrete-time counterpart Sx(ejÎ©) obtained with Fs = 200Â Hz (bottom). 


                                   </div>
                                                                          
                                                                          



FigureÂ 4.7 depicts the PSD for both continuous and discrete-time signals. Note that the abscissa of Sx(ejÎ©), which is periodic, is represented from 0 to 2Ï€. As indicated by Eq.Â (4.20), the power Ïƒx2 can be obtained by integrating Sx(ejÎ©) = 600Â Watts per normalized frequency (Dhertz) over the range [0,2Ï€[ and dividing the result by 2Ï€. Â Â â–¡



 Example 4.13. Filtering white noise through systems with unitary-energy impulse responses. Another situation of interest is when white noise is filtered by an LTI that has impulse response h(t) with energy Eh = âˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆ|h(t)|2dt = 1Â Joule, as depicted in:



 Î½(t) â†’Â h(t) â†’ x(t)â†’Â A/D â†’x[n].    

In this case, the Parseval relation of Eq.Â (B.51) indicates that Eh = âˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆ|H(f)|2df = 1 and from Eq.Â (4.41), the power of x(t) is









 Px = âˆ« âˆ’âˆâˆ|H(f)|2N0 2 df = N0 2 . 


(4.44)






Therefore, the power of x[n] is Ïƒ2 = N0âˆ•2, independent of h(t) (or its transform H(f)). However, x[n] will not have a flat PSD unless h(t) is an ideal lowpass filter as in ExampleÂ 4.12. Â Â â–¡


Gaussian signal filtered by LTI system remains Gaussian



If the system is LTI and its input is a realization of a WGN process, then it is well-known from random processes textbooks that the filter output is another Gaussian process. In other words, a Gaussian signal filtered by a linear system remains Gaussian but, in the general case, with a non-white PSD that was shaped by the filter.



When the LTI is an ideal lowpass filter such as in ExampleÂ 4.12, besides being Gaussian, the output is also flat within the filter passband (or â€œwhiteâ€ within this band). Hence, when the input is WGN, and h(t) an ideal lowpass filter with passband frequency Fsâˆ•2 that has its output converted to discrete-time, the resulting Î½[n] is a white and Gaussian process with PSD S(ejÎ©) (again, â€œwhiteâ€ within the band  âˆ’ Ï€ to Ï€ rad) and power Ïƒ2 = BWN0 Watts.





Converting white noise from discrete to continuous-time



The conversion of a discrete-time white noise Î½[n] into a continuous-time signal x(t) is depicted as:



 Î½[n]â†’Â D/A â†’h(t) â†’ x(t).    

Similar to the previous discussion about white noise C/D conversion in this section, if h(t) is an ideal lowpass filter with passband frequency Fsâˆ•2, x(t) has a flat PSD Sx(f) with value N0âˆ•2 = Ïƒ2âˆ•Fs, where Ïƒ2 is the power of Î½[n] and Fs the sampling frequency. Note that Sx(f) = 0 for f > |Fsâˆ•2|. Therefore, x(t) is not a continuous-time WGN, but has a flat PSD within the band [âˆ’Fsâˆ•2,Fsâˆ•2].


 

6Â Unless otherwise stated, the bandwidth is assumed to be over non-negative frequencies.

       </div>

title: 55Â  Nonparametric PSD Estimation via Periodogram
text:
The ESD, PSD and MS spectrum were defined without a discussion on how to estimate them. This section will exclusively concern this estimation using the FFT.



The periodogram Åœ[k] is a classical approach for PSD estimation. There are distinct definitions in the literature and here, especially for consistency with Matlab/Octave, the periodogram is an approximation of S(f) and defined as









 Åœ[k]=def 1 NÂ BW|FFT{xN[n]}|2, 


(4.45)






where xN[n] is the N-samples windowed version of x[n] and BW the assumed frequency bandwidth. If the window is other than the rectangular, Åœ[k] is called the modified periodogram.



When compared to the actual PSD S(f), notice that the periodogram Åœ[k] may present aliasing in case xN[n] was obtained by sampling a continuous-time x(t). It may also present leakage due to windowing. Besides, the periodogram inherits the properties and pitfalls of an FFT, such as a frequency resolution Î”Î© = 2Ï€âˆ•N that may not be enough to distinguish peaks separated by less than Î”Î© due to the picket-fence effect.



Based on the definition of Åœ[k], the signal power P can be conveniently obtained by approximating the integral of Eq.Â (4.17). For instance, using the rectangle method one obtains









 P â‰ˆÎ”fâˆ‘ k=0Nâˆ’1Åœ[k], 


(4.46)






where Î”f = BWâˆ•N is the FFT frequency spacing.



Some important facts related to this definition:

 <ul class='itemize1'>
 <li class='itemize'>The  periodogram  is  associated  by  definition  to  the  FFT  operation  and,
 consequently, operates in a finite-length discrete-time signal.
 </li>
 <li class='itemize'>The  periodogram  input  is  a  discrete-time  signal,  but  frequencies  can  be
 conveniently interpreted in Hertz (or rad/s) via <!-- l. 1041 --><math display='inline' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mrow><mi>Ï‰</mi> <mo class='MathClass-rel' stretchy='false'>=</mo> <msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub><mi mathvariant='normal'>Î©</mi></mrow></math>
 (Eq.Â (<a href='ak_dsp_bookse7.html#x14-39001r22'>1.22<!-- tex4ht:ref: eq:freqdiscrete2continuous  --></a>)) when the sampling frequency <!-- l. 1041 --><math display='inline' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub></math>
 is specified.
 </li>
 <li class='itemize'>The bandwidth <!-- l. 1042 --><math display='inline' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mstyle class='text'><mtext class='textrm' mathvariant='normal'>BW</mtext></mstyle></math>
 is   in   Hertz,   and   obtained   from   the   specified   sampling   frequency
 <!-- l. 1042 --><math display='inline' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub></math>.
 The <!-- l. 1042 --><math display='inline' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mstyle class='text'><mtext class='textrm' mathvariant='normal'>BW</mtext></mstyle></math>
 is assumed to be from <!-- l. 1042 --><math display='inline' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mrow> <mo class='MathClass-bin' stretchy='false'>âˆ’</mo> <msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub><mo class='MathClass-bin' stretchy='false'>âˆ•</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></math>
 to <!-- l. 1042 --><math display='inline' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub><mo class='MathClass-bin' stretchy='false'>âˆ•</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></math>
 for a bilateral or <!-- l. 1042 --><math display='inline' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>0</mn></math>
 to <!-- l. 1042 --><math display='inline' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub><mo class='MathClass-bin' stretchy='false'>âˆ•</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></math>
 for a unilateral periodogram.</li></ul>
                                                                          
                                                                          




4.6.1Â Â Discrete-time PSD estimation using the periodogram



The periodogram is an approximation of the continuous-time PSD S(f), but one can â€œtrickâ€ the software routine and obtain an estimate of S(ejÎ©) by imposing Fs = BW = 1Â Hz. In this case, the numerical values of the periodogram Åœ[k] provide an estimate Åœ(ejÎ©) of the discrete-time PSD S(ejÎ©) as follows:









 Åœ(ejÎ©)| Î©=k(2Ï€âˆ•N) = Åœ[k]. 


(4.47)






Having the periodogram calculated with Fs = 1, allows to interpret Åœ[k] in Watts/Dhertz (normalized frequency), as discussed in ExampleÂ 4.8.



However, when invoking a periodogram software routine for discrete-time signals without specifying Fs, the assumed default value is Fs = 2Ï€, not Fs = 1. The values of Åœ[k] will differ in these two cases by 2Ï€. But, independent on Fs, the signal average power can always be obtained with Eq.Â (4.46).





4.6.2Â Â Relation between MS spectrum and periodogram



The FFT-based estimation of both PSD and MS spectrum are closely related. From Eq.Â (4.35) and Eq.Â (4.45), one has:









 Åœms[k] = BW N Åœ[k] = Î”fÅœ[k]. 


(4.48)






Because Åœ[k] is a PSD estimate, the user of a PSD estimation routine that returns Åœ[k] just needs to know the bin width Î”f to be able to obtain the average power P from Åœ[k], and/or individual values of Åœms[k]. This reasoning is valid when P should be calculated over the whole frequency range, or shorter frequency intervals, because the amount of power Pk at a single FFT bin (the k-th bin) in a periodogram Åœ[k] is









 Åœms[k] = Pk = Î”fÅœ[k]. 


(4.49)






For discrete-time signals assuming BW = 2Ï€ or BW = 1, Pk = (BWâˆ•N)Åœ[k]. In both continuous and discrete-time cases, P = âˆ‘ â¡ k=0Nâˆ’1Pk.



ListingÂ 4.7 illustrates how Eq.Â (4.48) can be used to obtain Åœms[k].



ListingÂ 4.7: MatlabOctaveCodeSnippets/snip_frequency_mssFromPeriodogram.m


N=1024; n=(0:N-1)'; %number N of samples and column vector n 
A=10; x=A*cos((2*pi/64)*n); %generate cosine with period 64 
Sms = abs(fft(x)/N).^2; %MS spectrum |DTFS{x}|^2 
BW = 1; %assumed bandwidth is 2*pi 
5S = abs(fft(x)).^2/(BW*N); %Periodogram (|FFT{x}|^2)/(BW * N) 
Sms2=BW*S/N; %Example of obtaining MS spectrum from periodogram 
Power = sum(Sms) %Obtaining power from the MS spectrum 
Power2 = sum(S)*BW/N %Obtaining power from the periodogram
  


While the MS spectrum is a discrete function with the property specified by Eq.Â (4.33), the periodogram values Åœ[k] ideally coincide with a continuous function of frequency: the PSD S(f) or S(ejÎ©). Consequently, having an array of values Åœ[k], the property that should be obeyed depends on the integral Eq.Â (4.17) or Eq.Â (4.20), respectively, not a summation as in Eq.Â (4.33).



It is recommended to observe TableÂ B.1 and associated discussion, which summarizes an interesting analogy between the use of FFTs and histograms that helps understanding the difference betweeen Åœ[k] and Åœms[k].





Matlab/Octave adopted conventions for periodograms



Is should be noted that Matlab/Octave adopts the following:

 <ul class='itemize1'>
 <li class='itemize'>When the sampling frequency <!-- l. 1172 --><math display='inline' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub></math>
 is not specified, it is assumed <!-- l. 1172 --><math display='inline' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub> <mo class='MathClass-rel' stretchy='false'>=</mo> <mn>2</mn><mi>Ï€</mi></mrow></math>Â Hz
 and Eq.Â (<a href='ak_dsp_bookse53.html#x63-218001r17'>4.17<!-- tex4ht:ref: eq:psd_integration_continuousTime  --></a>) is adopted.
 </li>
 <li class='itemize'>When the signal is real, a unilateral PSD is adopted by default.
 </li>
 <li class='itemize'>By default, the <span class='ec-lmss-10x-x-109'>periodogram.m </span>function uses a power-of-two FFT-length with a
 minimum of 256, adopting zero-padding in case the input signal has less than
 256 samples.
 </li>
 <li class='itemize'>The periodogram values are converted to dB.</li></ul>


These conventions are discussed in the sequel.



A characteristic of Matlab/Octave is the adoption, by default, of a unilateral PSD when the signal is real and has a Hermitian-symmetric spectrum. In this case, only the nonnegative frequency range are used in the graphs and in the summation of the normalized periodogram to obtain P. For example, in continuous-time, instead of Eq.Â (4.46), one would have









 P = âˆ« 0âˆS(f)df â‰ˆÎ”fâˆ‘ k=0(Nâˆ•2)+1Åœ[k], 


(4.50)






assuming N is even. Hence, the values of Åœ[k] in a unilateral periodogram are twice the values in the corresponding bilateral representation, with exception of the DC and Nyquist frequencies. This can be seen in the result of ListingÂ 4.8, which avoids zero-padding via the third input argument of periodogram.m.



ListingÂ 4.8: MatlabOctaveCodeSnippets/snip_frequency_comparePeriodograms.m


N=1024; n=(0:N-1)'; %number N of samples and column vector n 
A=10; x=A*cos((2*pi/64)*n); %generate cosine with period 64 
BW = 2*pi; %assume defaut Fs=2*pi (bandwidth) in periodogram 
S = abs(fft(x)).^2/(BW*N); %Periodogram (|FFT{x}|^2)/(BW * N) 
5Nfft = N; %avoid zero-padding in periodogram below: 
[H,w]=periodogram(x,[],Nfft); %Using Matlab/Octave 
Power = sum(H)*BW/N %Power from unilateral periodogram 
Power2 = sum(S)*BW/N %Power from bilateral periodogram 
Sunilateral = [S(1); 2*S(2:N/2); S(N/2+1)]; %from bi to unilateral 
10plot(w,H,'-o',w,Sunilateral ,'-x') %Compare periodograms
  


As indicated in ListingÂ 4.8, to obtain the power P from the periodogram, the proper normalization factor is the bin width Î”f=BW/N, which in this case is Î”f = 2Ï€âˆ•1024 because Fs was not specified when calling the periodogram.m routine and Fs = 2Ï€ is assumed.



A minor detail is that when N is even and the periodogram is unilateral, w(end) is Fsâˆ•2 and length(H) is (Nâˆ•2) + 1. If a bilateral periodogram
is calculated, w(end) is (Fsâˆ•2) âˆ’Î”f and length(H) is N. ListingÂ 4.9 illustrates this point.



ListingÂ 4.9: MatlabOctaveCodeSnippets/snip_frequency_correctPeriodograms.m


N=1024; n=(0:N-1)'; %number N of samples and column vector n 
A=10; x=A*cos((2*pi/64)*n); %generate cosine with period 64 
Fs=500; BW = Fs; %Fs = BW = 500 Hz 
[H,f] = periodogram(x,[],N,Fs); %Unilateral periodogram 
5[H2,f2] = periodogram(x,[],N,Fs,'twosided'); %Bilateral periodogram 
Power = (BW/N)*sum(H) %Power for unilateral periodograma 
Power2 = (BW/N)*sum(H2) %Power for bilateral periodograma 
f(end), f2(end), length(f), length(f2) %values for N even
  


All the previous calculations (e. g., sum(H)) used the periodogram in linear scale. Another convention adopted by Matlab/Octave is to convert, by default, the periodogram values to dBW/Hz when the function periodogram.m is invoked without output parameters. However, as discussed in AppendixÂ B.24, the periodogram unit is informed to be dB/Hz instead of dBW/Hz.





4.6.3Â Â Periodogram of periodic or energy signals



A periodogram must be properly interpreted if applied to a periodic signal. Note that, as indicated in SectionÂ 4.4.2.0, while the PSD of a periodic signal is composed by impulses, the periodogram Åœ[k] obtained from a finite-duration window does not contain impulses due to the convolution with the window spectrum.



Similarly, care must be exercised when a periodogram is applied to an energy signal. As discussed in SectionÂ 4.4.1, an energy signal should be associated to an ESD, not PSD. The periodogram of an energy signal such as x[n] = u[n] âˆ’ u[n âˆ’ 5], for example, is implicitly assuming that x[n] is just a windowed version of a periodic signal.



Before discussing the more advanced Welch method for PSD estimation, few examples of periodograms are provided in the next section to consolidate the concepts.





4.6.4Â Â Examples of PSD and MS spectrum estimation



 Example 4.14. Using periodogram.m to approximate a continuous-time PSD S(f) of a sinusoid. When the sampling frequency Fs is specified as input argument and without output arguments, the periodogram
of Matlab/Octave indicates the abscissa in Hertz. For example, ListingÂ 4.10 was used to generate FigureÂ 4.8, which has the abscissa going from 0 to Fsâˆ•2Â Hz because the signal is real and the default periodogram is unilateral in this case.



ListingÂ 4.10: MatlabOctaveCodeSnippets/snip_frequency_normalized_periodogram.m


N=1024; A=10; x=A*cos(2*pi/64*(0:N-1));%generate cosine 
Fs=8000; %sampling frequency in Hz 
rectWindow=rectwin(N); %rectangular window 
rectWindow=rectWindow(:); x=x(:); %make sure both are column vectors 
5[P,f]=periodogram(x,rectWindow,N,Fs); %periodogram 
df = Fs/N; %FFT bin width to be used in power computation 
Power=sum(P)*df %calculate the average power 
plot(f/1000,10*log10(P)); grid, %convert to dBW/Hz
  







FigureÂ 4.8: Periodogram of x[n] = 10cos â¡ ((2Ï€âˆ•64)n) in dBW/Hz estimated by periodogram.m with a 1024-point FFT and assuming Fs = 8Â kHz.





The signal power is P = 50Â W. FigureÂ 4.8 indicates a peak at f = 125Â Hz, which corresponds to tone k = 16. This can be confirmed by observing that Î”f = Fsâˆ•N = 8000âˆ•1024 â‰ˆ 7.8125Â Hz, such that fk = kÎ”f = 16 Ã— 8000âˆ•1024 = 125Â Hz. Because there was no leakage in this case, the sinusoid power P = 50Â W is completely residing in bin k = 16. From Eq.Â (4.49), the expected PSD value at this bin is Åœ[k]|k=16 = Pâˆ•Î”f = 50âˆ•7.8125 = 6.4Â W/Hz. Converting it to dBW leads to 10log â¡ 106.4 â‰ˆ 8.062Â dBW/Hz, as indicated in FigureÂ 4.8.



One aspect of PSD graphs in dB scale is that dynamic ranges larger than hundreds of dB should be associated to numerical errors, given that 10*log10(eps)=-156.5. Â  Â â–¡



 Example 4.15. Discrete-time PSD of a sinusoid using the periodogram function. ListingÂ 4.11 uses the Matlab/Octave periodogram function to estimate the discrete-time PSD of a cosine and compares it with a periodogram directly calculated based on the definition adopted in this text. FigureÂ 4.9 depicts the result.



ListingÂ 4.11: MatlabOctaveCodeSnippets/snip_frequency_periodogram.m


N=16; alpha=2; A=10; n=0:N-1; 
x=A*cos((2*pi*alpha/N)*n); %generate cosine 
x=x(:); %Octave requires column vector 
BW=1; %it is a discrete-time signal, assume BW=1 Hz 
5Sk = (1/(N*BW))*abs(fft(x)).^2; %Periodogram as defined in text 
Power = (BW/N)*sum(Sk) %Obtain power from periodogram 
Smatlab=periodogram(x,[],N,BW,'twosided'); %from f=0 to 1 dHz 
M=length(Smatlab); %periodogram used zero-padding and unilateral PSD 
dhertz = (1/N)*(-N/2:(N/2-1)); %normalized frequency 
10Power2= (BW/N)*sum(Smatlab) %Power from periodogram function 
W=2*pi*dhertz; %convert abscissa to Omega in radians 
clf; subplot(211); h=stem(W,fftshift(Smatlab)); 
hold on; stem(W,fftshift(Sk),'xr')
  







FigureÂ 4.9: Discrete-time PSD of x[n] = 10cos â¡ ((2Ï€âˆ•8)n) in linear scale estimated with periodograms.





ListingÂ 4.11 returns the value P = 50Â W for both Power and Power2. The cosine angular frequencies are  Â± 0.7854Â rad as indicated in the top plot of FigureÂ 4.9 for the positive frequency. The periodogram values at k = âˆ’2 and k = 2 are Åœ[k]|k = Â±2 = (Pâˆ•2)âˆ•Î”f = 400, given that Î”f = BWâˆ•N and BW = 1.



There was no leakage in the top plot of FigureÂ 4.9. But in case one allows the periodogram.m routine to use zero-padding as in:


[Smatlab,f]=periodogram(x,[],[],BW,'twosided'); %zero-padding


the result is the bottom plot of FigureÂ 4.9. In this case, periodogram.m adopted zero-padding to reach N = 256 samples. This can be confirmed with


Power3= (BW/256)*sum(Smatlab) %Power from periodogram function


which returns Power3=50. Another discrepancy between the two plots in FigureÂ 4.9 is that the bottom plot uses the range Î© âˆˆ [0,2Ï€[ while the top plot adopted [âˆ’Ï€,Ï€[ via fftshift.m. Â Â â–¡



 Example 4.16. MS spectrum and PSD of a sum of sinusoids. A 1024-points DFT is adopted to inspect a signal composed by two discrete-time cosines that are not bin-centered and have amplitudes 10 and 1Â V, as indicated in ListingÂ 4.12.



ListingÂ 4.12: MatlabOctaveCodeSnippets/snip_frequency_not_bin_cent_cos.m


N=1024; n=(0:N-1)'; %number of samples and column vector 
dw=2*pi/N; %FFT bin width 
k1=115.3; k2=500.8; w1=k1*dw; w2=k2*dw;%define frequencies 
x=10*cos(w1*n) + 1*cos(w2*n); %generate sum of two cosines 
5Sms = abs(fft(x)/N).^2; %MS spectrum |DTFS{x}|^2 
[S,w] = periodogram(x); %Periodogram, frequency w=0 to pi 
Power = sum(Sms) %estimate the power in Watts = A^2/2 
k=0:N-1; %frequency index 
subplot(211), h=plot(k,10*log10(Sms)); %MS spectrum (dB) 
10subplot(212), h2=plot(w,10*log10(S)); %Periodogram (dB)
  


FigureÂ 4.10 depicts the obtained result. To obtain cosines that are not bin-centered, non-integer numbers k1=115.3 and k2=500.8 were specified to create the angular frequencies. Hence, each cosine has most of its power located at bins k = 115 and 501 as indicated by the data tips in FigureÂ 4.10.



The top graph shows the bilateral MS spectrum with the positive frequencies (the ones that have associated data tips), from

k = 0 to 512 preceding the â€œnegativeâ€ frequencies from k = 513 to 1023. The function fftshift could be used to make the â€œnegativeâ€ precede the positive frequencies. Note that the implicitly adopted rectangular window leads to considerable leakage. The bottom graph is a unilateral representation of the periodogram.








FigureÂ 4.10: Periodogram and MS spectrum for a sum of sinusoids. Both are in dB scale.





The Power calculated by the code was 50.5397Â W while the theoretical result is 102âˆ•2 + 12âˆ•2 = 50.5. The small discrepancy is due to the fact that the sinusoids are not bin-centered and the time-domain signal x itself has power P = 50.5397Â W.



Bin-centered cosines with power 50 and 0.5Â W would lead to values 10log â¡ 10(25) â‰ˆ 13.98Â dB and 10log â¡ 10(0.25) â‰ˆâˆ’6.02Â dB at their corresponding frequencies in a bilateral MS spectrum. Given that BW = 2Ï€ and the FFT bin width is BWâˆ•N = 2Ï€âˆ•1024 â‰ˆ 0.0061, the theoretical values for the unilateral periodogram are 10log â¡ 10(50âˆ•0.0061) â‰ˆ 39.11 and 10log â¡ 10(0.5âˆ•0.0061) â‰ˆ 19.11. FigureÂ 4.10 presents slightly smaller values for both MS spectrum and periodogram due to leakage. Because BW = 2Ï€ instead of BW = 1, the depicted values are not the ones of a discrete-time PSD S(ejÎ©).



An interesting aspect is that the relative difference in power between the two sinusoids can be obtained in both periodogram and MS spectrum, leading to 37.79 âˆ’ 18.63 â‰ˆ 19.2Â dB and 12.66 âˆ’ (âˆ’6.497) â‰ˆ 19.2Â dB, respectively. In other words, the PSD does not allow directly reading the absolute power values but can inform the relation between powers of signal components that reside in specific bins. Â Â â–¡



 Example 4.17. Periodogram variance does not decrease with number of samples. FigureÂ 4.11 illustrates the adoption of periodograms Åœ[k] to estimate the discrete-time PSD S(ejÎ©) of a white noise with power of 600Â W. The estimation used N = 300 (top) and N = 3000 (bottom) samples of the noise signal. The code for signal generation and periodogram estimation for N=300 (the same code was used for N=3000 samples) is:



ListingÂ 4.13: MatlabOctaveCodeSnippets/snip_frequency_noise_PSD.m


N = 300; % number of samples and FFT size 
power_x = 600; %desired noise power in Watts 
Fs = 1; %sampling frequency = BW = 1 Dhertz 
x=sqrt(power_x) * randn(1,N); %Gaussian white noise 
5actualPower = mean(x.^2) %the actual obtained power 
[Sk,F]=periodogram(x,[],[],Fs,'twosided'); %periodogram 
subplot(211), plot(2*pi*F,Sk); %plot periodogram 
Sx_th=power_x*ones(1,length(F)); %theoretical PSD 
mean(Sk) %in this case, it coincides with actualPower 
10disp(['Periodogram standard deviation=' num2str(std(Sk))]) 
hold on; h=plot(2*pi*F,Sx_th,'r:','lineWidth',3);
  


Note that due to the limited number N of samples, the actualPower values (e. g., 512.3 and
601.0Â W), may differ from the desired value power_x=600.








FigureÂ 4.11: Periodograms of a white noise with power equal to 600Â W estimated with N = 300 (top) and N = 3000 (bottom) samples.





Recall from Eq.Â (4.47), that in the case of Fs = 1, the periodogram coincides with the discrete-time PSD estimate Åœ(ejÎ©)|Î©=k(2Ï€âˆ•N).



This example illustrates that the periodogram values with Fs = 1 have an average mean(Sk) that coincides with actualPower (because Î”f = 1âˆ•N in this case). However, the variance of the estimate does not decrease with N. For N = 300 and 3000, the standard deviations are 593.1 and 599.4, respectively. This issue is discussed in SectionÂ 4.7, in which the Welchâ€™s PSD estimation method is presented. Â  Â â–¡



 Example 4.18. PSD of a sinusoid contaminated by AWGN. Special care must be exercised when interpreting a PSD that represents both broadband and narrowband signals. An example is when using the PSD to estimate the SNRs of sinusoids immersed in white noise. FigureÂ 4.12 shows the periodogram of a cosine contaminated by AWGN generated with ListingÂ 4.14.



ListingÂ 4.14: MatlabOctaveCodeSnippets/snip_frequency_noisy_cosine.m


N=1024; A=4; %# of samples and cosine amplitude of A Volts 
Fs=8000; Ts=1/Fs; %sampling frequency (Hz) and period (s) 
f0=915; %cosine frequency in Hz 
noisePower=16; %noise power in Watts 
5noise=sqrt(noisePower)*randn(1,N); 
t=0:Ts:(N-1)*Ts; %N time instants separated by Ts 
x=A*cos(2*pi*f0*t) + noise;%generate cosine with AWGN 
[P,f]=periodogram(x,[],N,Fs); %periodogram 
plot(f,10*log10(P)); %dB scale
  


ListingÂ 4.14 was used to generate the top plot with subplot(211). Then, the bottom plot was obtained by increasing N from 1024 to 16384. All the absolute values of the two periodograms differ due to their dependence on N.








FigureÂ 4.12: Periodograms of a cosine contaminated by AWGN at an SNR of  âˆ’ 3Â dB with an FFT of N = 1024 points (top plot) and 16384 (bottom). In this case the SNR cannot be inferred directly from the noise level.





It can be noticed from ListingÂ 4.14 that the cosine power is Pc = A2âˆ•2 = 8Â W while the noise power is 16Â W, leading to a SNR = 10log â¡ 10(8âˆ•16) â‰ˆâˆ’3.01Â dB. However, one may be tempted by FigureÂ 4.12 to erroneously infer that SNR is positive given that the noise level (sometimes called noise floor) is more than 20Â dB below the cosine peak for the top graph. Directly observing the ratio of powers in PSD graphs was valid in FigureÂ 4.10, but in that case, the cosines were assumed to have all power confined in their respective bins. This is not the case with signals that have power spread over several bins and especially with white noise.



Because the white noise power is spread over all bins of a periodogram, the larger the number N of FFT bins, the less noise power each bin carries and the larger the difference between the sinusoid power (assumed to be confined in a single bin) and the noise floor. In FigureÂ 4.10, the bottom plot shows that the cosine power is approximately 30Â dB above the noise level when N is increased to 16384. However, in both plots, the SNR is  âˆ’ 3Â dB as attested by ListingÂ 4.14.



In summary, the proper way of measuring the signal power is to account for the power in all bins that represent the signal.Â Â â–¡


4.6.5Â Â Estimating the PSD from Autocorrelation



An alternative way of estimating the PSD of a finite duration discrete-time signal is via the autocorrelation. The autocorrelation for such finite-duration signals can be obtained via Eq.Â (1.61), and then the PSD estimated with









 Åœ(ejÎ©) = âˆ‘ k=âˆ’N+1Nâˆ’1R^[k]eâˆ’jÎ©n. 


(4.51)






As previously done, an FFT can be used to obtain the values of Åœ(ejÎ©) at the FFT frequency grid.



 Example 4.19. PSD of filtered white-noise via its autocorrelation. ListingÂ 4.15 illustrates how Eq.Â (4.51) can be used to generate FigureÂ 4.13. The theoretical expression for the PSD in FigureÂ 4.13 was obtained from Eq.Â (4.41).



ListingÂ 4.15: MatlabOctaveCodeSnippets/snip_frequency_PSD_using_xcorr.m


N = 3000; %total number of signal samples 
L = 4; %number of non-zero samples of h[n] 
power_x = 600; %noise power in Watts 
x=sqrt(power_x) * randn(1,N); %Gaussian white noise 
5h=ones(1,L); %FIR moving average filter impulse response 
y=conv(h,x); %filtered signal y[n] = x[n] * h[n] 
H=fft(h,4*N); %DTFT (sampled) of the impulse response 
Sy_th=power_x*abs(H).^2; %theoretical PSD via sampling DTFT 
M=256; %maximum lag chosen as M < N 
10[Ry,lags]=xcorr(y,M,'biased'); %estimating autocorrelation 
Sy_corr=abs(fft(Ry)); %PSD estimate via autocorrelation
  







FigureÂ 4.13: PSD of a filtered white noise x[n] estimated via the autocorrelation.





Note that for an input signal with N samples, the function xcorr would, by default, output an autocorrelation with lags from  âˆ’ N to N. However, to avoid noisy estimations at the autocorrelation tails, it is a good strategy to use a maximum lag M Â« N, if possible. There is a rule of thumb that suggests adopting M = Nâˆ•10. This was used in ListingÂ 4.15, where Ry was calculated for a maximum lag of M=256 while the signal had N=3000 samples. Â Â â–¡



 Example 4.20. PSD of a discrete-time impulse. Let x[n] = AÎ´[n âˆ’ n0] be a discrete-time impulse with amplitude A that is multiplied by a rectangular window of N samples for FFT-based spectral analysis. For example, with N = 5 and A = 6 and x=[6, 0, 0, 0, 0] is the vector representing xw[n]. Because the PSD disregards the phase information, the value of n0 and the position of the peak with amplitude A within the windowed signal xw[n] is not relevant. For the given example, using x=[0, 0, 0, 6, 0] would lead to the same results. This signal xw[n] also has an autocorrelation that is an impulse and a white spectrum. Its PSD has a constant value of S(ejÎ©) = P = 36âˆ•5 = 7.2Â W/Dhertz (normalized frequency), as indicated in Eq.Â (4.42). ListingÂ 4.16 calculates the periodogram and MS spectrum.



ListingÂ 4.16: MatlabOctaveCodeSnippets/snip_frequency_impulse_PSD.m


N=5; %number of FFT points 
M=2; %maximum number of autocorrelation lags 
BW=1; %BW in normalized frequency (digital Hertz) 
x=[6 0 0 0 0]; %impulse signal truncated in N samples 
5Sms=abs(fft(x)/N).^2 %MS spectrum: all values are 2.25 Watts 
Sk=periodogram(x,[],length(x),1,'twosided') %periodogram 
[R,lags]=xcorr(x,M,'biased'); %estimating autocorrelation 
Sxcorr=abs(fft(R)); %PSD via autocorrelation 
Power=sum(Sms) %power (9 W) obtained from MS spectrum 
10Power2=(BW/N)*sum(Sk) %power (9 W) from 
Power3=(BW/N)*sum(Sxcorr) %power (9 W) from periodogram via xcorr
  


The last commands obtain the average power equal to 7.2Â W using three distinct alternatives. All elements of Sms have a value of 7.2âˆ•5 = 1.44Â W, given that the power was uniformly distributed over the five discrete frequency values. The bilateral periodogram was calculated assuming a bandwidth

BW = 1 (in normalized frequency, or Dhertz) such that the returned value has all values equal to 7.2, coinciding with S(ejÎ©) = 7.2 (see Eq.Â (4.47)). Â Â â–¡

title: 56Â  Nonparametric PSD Estimation via Welchâ€™s method
text:
This section discusses Welchâ€™s method, one of the most popular nonparametric PSD Estimation method.





4.7.1Â Â The periodogram variance does not decrease with N



It may seem counterintuitive but, as FigureÂ 4.11 indicates, increasing the number N of samples does not decrease the variance of the periodogram estimates Åœ[k].



In fact, it is well-known in spectral analysis theory7 that the periodogram Åœ[k] is an unbiased estimator of the true PSD S(f), i. e.,






 lim â¡  Nâ†’âˆğ”¼[Åœ[k]] = S(f). 






In other words, the average periodogram converges to the right values as N increases.



However, the variance of the periodogram estimator is approximately S2(f) even for large N. This is a consequence of a result that is valid under mild conditions:









 ğ”¼[(Åœ[k] âˆ’ S(f))2] = S2(f) + R N, 


(4.52)






where RN tends to zero when N â†’âˆ. In other words, the standard deviation of the periodogram is approximately as large as the spectrum it should estimate. Using windows such as Hamming and Hann can improve the spectral analysis, but do not help with respect to the variance of the periodogram.



One may expect that increasing the number N of samples would lead to a better estimate of the PSD. In fact, the estimation does improve, but with respect to its frequency resolution Î”f = Fsâˆ•N, not the variance.





4.7.2Â Â Welchâ€™s method for PSD estimation



The main strategy to decrease the variance of a PSD estimation is to split the available data into K segments of M samples each, calculate the periodogram for each segment and then take their average. Methods such as Bartlettâ€™s and Welchâ€™s are based on this principle. The disadvantage of using less (M < N) samples is that the frequency resolution Î”f decreases (from Î”f = Fsâˆ•N to Fsâˆ•M).



The main distinction between Bartlettâ€™s and Welchâ€™s methods is that the latter tries to combat the decrease in Î”f by overlapping segments, such that for a given K, the value of M can be larger than M = Nâˆ•K, where N is the total number of available samples. For example, an overlap of 50% of segments of length M = 4 means that the first segment corresponds to samples with indices

n = 0,1,2,3, the second segment has samples with n = 2,3,4,5, the third with n = 4,5,6,7 and so on.



In Matlab/Octave, the command Sx=pwelch(x) estimates a PSD via Welchâ€™s method using default values (K = 8, Hamming window and an overlap of 50%). An example of a complete command is


[Sx,w] = pwelch(x,window,Num_overlap,N_fft,Fs,'twosided')


where window is the window, Num_overlap is the number of samples that are shared between two neighboring segments, N_fft is the number N of FFT points used for calculating the periodograms, Fs is the sampling frequency and â€™twosidedâ€™ can be used to force pwelch to return values from 0 to 2Ï€, even if the signal is real. The number M of samples per segment corresponds to the window length. The companion function ak_psd.m illustrates how to invoke pwelch.m and is convenient when the sampling frequency is given in Hz.








FigureÂ 4.14: PSD of a white noise x[n] with power equal to 600Â W estimated by Welchâ€™s method with M = 32 (top) and M = 256 (bottom) samples per segment.





 Example 4.21. Variance reduction with Welchâ€™s method. ListingÂ 4.17 provides an example of using pwelch for PSD estimation of the same signal as FigureÂ 4.11 and leads to FigureÂ 4.14. The top plot was obtained with Nfft=32 and then, the code was modified to use Nfft=256 and generate the bottom plot. Note that the total number of samples is N=3000 in both cases. The standard deviations among the periodograms were 46.5 and 132.0, respectively. The smaller Nfft, a larger number of periodograms is calculated and their averaging reduces the variance.



ListingÂ 4.17: MatlabOctaveCodeSnippets/snip_frequency_pwelch.m


N = 3000; %total number of signal samples 
Nfft = 32; %segment length M and also FFT-length 
Fs = 1; %assumed bandwidth for discrete-time signal 
power_x = 600; %noise power in Watts 
5x=sqrt(power_x) * randn(1,N); %Gaussian white noise 
[Sk,F]=pwelch(x,hamming(Nfft),[],Nfft,Fs,'twosided'); %Parameter [] 
%is because in Matlab it is num. samples while Octave is percent (%) 
disp(['Periodogram standard deviation=' num2str(std(Sk))]) 
plot(2*pi*F,Sk) %periodogram with Fs=1 is discrete-time PSD 
10hold on, plot(w,power_x*ones(1,length(w)),'r') %PSD theoretical value
  


When comparing the plots in FigureÂ 4.14 with the bottom plot in FigureÂ 4.11, which also used N = 3000 samples, it is evident that averaging periodograms (for example, via Welchâ€™s method) decreases the variance. FigureÂ 4.14 also illustrates the tradeoff between variance reduction and frequency resolution as the top graph with Î”Î© = 2Ï€âˆ•32 is much smoother than the bottom one with Î”Î© = 2Ï€âˆ•256.



A detail is that ListingÂ 4.17 uses the default of the window overlap (the third argument of pwelch.m as []) because Octave assumes it is a percentage while Matlab assumes it is the number of samples. Â Â â–¡



 Example 4.22. Estimating the PSD of filtered white noise via Welchâ€™s method.








FigureÂ 4.15: PSD of a filtered white noise x[n] estimated by Welchâ€™s method.





ListingÂ 4.18 illustrates an application of Sy(ejÎ©) = Ïƒx2|H(ejÎ©)|2 (Eq.Â (4.43)), where the system impulse response is h=[1,1,1,1] and H(ejÎ©) is a sinc.



ListingÂ 4.18: MatlabOctaveCodeSnippets/snip_frequency_filtered_noise_PSD.m


N = 3000; %total number of signal samples 
L = 4; %number of non-zero samples of h[n] 
power_x = 600; %noise power in Watts 
x=sqrt(power_x) * randn(1,N); %Gaussian white noise 
5h=ones(1,L); %shaping pulse with square waveform 
y=conv(h,x); %filter signal x with filter 
Nfft = 256; %segment length M and also FFT dimension 
Fs = 2*pi; %sampling frequency for discrete-time PSD 
[Sy_pwelch,w]=pwelch(y,hamming(Nfft),[],Nfft,Fs,'twosided'); 
10H=fft(h,4*N); %DTFT (sampled) of the impulse response 
Sy_th=power_x*abs(H).^2; %PSD theoretical expression 
plot(w,2*pi*Sy_pwelch); hold on %scale by 2*pi to get disc.time PSD 
plot(linspace(0,2*pi,length(H)),power_x*abs(H).^2,'r')
  


ListingÂ 4.18 was used to generate FigureÂ 4.15, where one can notice that, even with the averaging used in pwelch, the variance continues proportional to the PSD magnitude, as indicated by Eq.Â (4.52). Â Â â–¡



 Example 4.23. Welchâ€™s method using the Goertzel algorithm. Note that in Matlab, when the call to pwelch specifies the frequency points, pwelch can use the Goertzel algorithm instead of an FFT. An example is the following code:


x=randn(1,10000); Fs=1e4; %some random vector and sampling freq. 
f=linspace(-Fs/2,Fs/2,1024); %create a frequency axis 
Px=pwelch(x,hamming(1024),512,f,Fs); %Octave has distinct syntax! 
plot(f,10*log10(Px)); %show PSD from -Fs/2 to Fs/2


The Goertzel algorithm can slow down the computations when compared to the FFT-based PSD estimation because it targets situations in which the frequencies are not uniformly spaced such as in DTMF detection algorithms (see FigureÂ 4.32). Â  Â â–¡


 

7Â See, e. g.,Â Â [?,?] and [url4spe].

                                                                                  </div>

title: 57Â  Parametric PSD Estimation via Autoregressive (AR) Modeling
text:
4.8Â Â Parametric PSD Estimation via Autoregressive (AR) Modeling



In SectionÂ 3.10.1, the terms AR and MA (autoregressive and moving-average, respectively) were associated to filters. Here they will also denote WSS random processes that have white noise as the input to a LTI filter H(z) that is AR or MA, respectively.



The periodogram and Welchâ€™s methods are categorized as â€œclassicalâ€ or â€œnonparametricâ€ spectral analysis. This section discusses a method from â€œmodernâ€ spectral analysis, which consists in indirectly estimating a PSD S(ejÎ©) = |H(ejÎ©)|2 by first estimating the parameters of the autoregressive model (or filter):









 H(z) = gzP   âˆ k=1P (z âˆ’ pk) = g A(z) = g 1 + a1zâˆ’1 + a2zâˆ’2 + â€¦ + aP zâˆ’P , 


(4.53)






which corresponds to Eq.Â (3.54), repeated here for the convenience of calling P (instead of N) the system order.



Such â€œparametricâ€ spectral estimator has the advantage that there are potentially fewer parameters to be estimated when compared to the values of a PSD. For example, when using an M-point FFT for PSD estimation using Welchâ€™s algorithm, M values need to be estimated. In contrast, the AR model requires estimating only P Â« M parameters and the gain g. On the other hand, if the assumed model is incorrect, the parametric estimator may lead to highly inaccurate results.



The goal of AR-based PSD estimation is to find H(z) = gâˆ•A(z) that, when excited
by white noise x[n] generates an output that has the same statistics of y[n], i. e.,






 x[n]â†’Â Â <mrowÂ  >gÂ  <mrowÂ  >A(z) â†’y[n]. 






Hence, it is assumed that y[n] is a realization of an ergodic autoregressive random process of order P, denoted as AR(P).



The problem is posed mathematically as finding the FIR filter A(z) = 1 + âˆ‘ â¡ i=1P aizâˆ’i that minimizes the energy âˆ‘ â¡ n|x[n]|2 of the output signal x[n] in






 y[n]â†’Â A(z) â†’x[n]. 






The filter A(z) = 1 âˆ’A~(z) is called the prediction-error filter because A~(z) = âˆ’âˆ‘ â¡ i=1P aizâˆ’i predicts an estimate y~[n] of y[n] as









 y~[n] = âˆ’âˆ‘ i=1P a iy[n âˆ’ i], 


(4.54)






based on the P past samples of y[n]. This is depicted in FigureÂ 4.16. The prediction error is x[n] = y[n] âˆ’y~[n] and, when A(z) is an optimum solution, x[n] has characteristics of white noise with power Ïƒx2. The signal x[n] is also called prediction error and, therefore, g2 is called the prediction error power.








FigureÂ 4.16: The prediction-error filter is A(z) = 1 âˆ’A~(z), where A~(z) provides a prediction y~[n] of the current n-th signal sample y[n], based on previous samples y[n âˆ’ 1],â€¦,y[n âˆ’ P].





AR-based modeling using Eq.Â (4.54) is widely used in speech coding and, because y~[n] in Eq.Â (4.54) is a linear combination of past inputs, it is called linear predictive coding (LPC).



The filter A(z) is often used to perform decorrelation of a signal (y[n] according to the adopted notation), while 1âˆ•A(z) is called the synthesis filter because it can generate a signal (y[n]) with a given PSD from white noise (x[n]).



 Example 4.24. Experimenting with Matlabâ€™s aryule function. Two examples of autoregressive modeling using Matlab are provided here. Similar commands can be used with Octave, as later suggested in ListingÂ 4.24.



The function aryule.m returns the filter A and the power Perror of the white noise signal x[n], corresponding to A(z) and g2, respectively. When a white signal with power Perror is used as input of the synthesis filter 1âˆ•A(z), the resulting signal has the power of y[n].



As an example, the result of the following code composes TableÂ 4.2.


y=(1:100)+randn(1,100); %signal composed by ramp plus noise 
for P=1:4 %vary the LPC order 
Â Â [A,Perror]=lpc(y,P) %estimate filter of order P 
end






TableÂ 4.2: LPC result for different orders P for a ramp signal with added noise.

102.1109 















4 


[1.0, -0.9884, 0.0082, -0.0138, 0.0092]

TableÂ 4.2 illustrates that the LPC filter A(z) = 1 âˆ’ 0.9849zâˆ’1 of order P = 1 can extract most of the correlation among the samples of the input signal y. For P > 1, the coefficients ai for i > 1 have relatively small values. Besides, Perror does not decrease significantly with P. A second example illustrates a situation where P = 2 outperforms P = 1. ListingÂ 4.19 is similar to the previous one, but simulates an AR(2) process and allows to create TableÂ 4.3.



ListingÂ 4.19: MatlabOctaveCodeSnippets/snip_frequency_aryule.m


N=1000; x=randn(1,N); %WGN with zero mean and unit variance 
Px=mean(abs(x).^2) %input signal power 
B=4; %filter numerator 
A=[1 0.5 0.98]; %filter denominator 
5Fs=1; %sampling frequency Fs = BW = 1 DHz 
y=filter(B,A,x); %realization of an AR(2) process 
Py=mean(abs(y).^2) %output power 
for P=1:4 %vary the filter order 
Â Â Â Â [Sy,f]=pwelch(y,rectwin(N),[],N,Fs,'twosided'); 
10Â Â Â Â [Hthe,w]=freqz(B, A,'twosided'); 
Â Â Â Â [Ahat,Perror]=aryule(y,P) %estimate filter of order P 
Â Â Â Â [Hhat,w]=freqz(sqrt(Perror), Ahat,'twosided'); 
Â Â Â Â clf, plot(2*pi*f,10*log10(Sy),'r'); hold on 
Â Â Â Â plot(w,10*log10(Px*abs(Hthe).^2),'k--'); 
15Â Â Â Â plot(w,10*log10(Px*abs(Hhat).^2),'b'); 
Â Â Â Â legend('Welch','Theoretical','AR') 
Â Â Â Â pause 
end
  






TableÂ 4.3: LPC result for different orders P for an AR(2) realization.



























Order P


Filter A(z)


Perror (g2) 















1

513.6893 















2 


[1.0, 0.5089, 0.9832]
