Two time instants: both absolute or one absolute and a relative (lag)



When characterizing second-order moments of a random process, instead of using two absolute time instants, it is sometimes useful to make one instant as a relative â€œlagâ€ with respect to the other. For example, take two absolute instants t = 4 and s = 7 in Eq.Â (B.69). Alternatively, the same pair of instants can be denoted by considering t = 4 as the absolute time that provides the reference instant and a lag Ï„ = s âˆ’ t = 3 indicating that the second instant is separated by 3 from the reference.



Using this scheme, Eq.Â (B.69) can be written as









 RX(t,Ï„) = ğ”¼[X(t + Ï„)X(t)]. 


(B.71)






Similarly, Eq.Â (B.70) can be denoted as









 RX[n,l] = ğ”¼  [X[n]X[n + l]], 


(B.72)






with n1 = n and n2 = n + l, where l is the lag in discrete-time.



 Example B.4. Contrasting two different representations of autocorrelations. FigureÂ B.13 is a graph that corresponds to Eq.Â (B.70), with two absolute time instants. When using the alternative representation of Eq.Â (B.72), with a lag, the resulting matrix is obtained by rearranging the elements of the autocorrelation matrix. FigureÂ B.15 compares the two cases. Note that the name autocorrelation matrix is reserved for the one derived from Eq.Â (B.70) (and Eq.Â (B.69)) that is, for example, symmetric.








FigureÂ B.15: Comparison between the 3-d representation of the autocorrelation matrix in FigureÂ B.13 and the one using lags as in Eq.Â (B.72).





FigureÂ B.16 is an alternative view of FigureÂ B.15, which makes visualization easier. It better shows that Eq.Â (B.72) leads to shifting the column of the autocorrelation matrix (FigureÂ B.13) corresponding to each value n = n1 of interest.








FigureÂ B.16: Comparison between autocorrelation representations using images instead of 3-d graphs as in FigureÂ B.15.





Properties such as the symmetry of the autocorrelation matrix may not be so evident from the right-side representation of FigureÂ B.16 as in the left-side representation, but both are useful in distinct situations. Â  Â â–¡


Covariance matrix



Similar to autocorrelation functions, it is possible to define covariance functions that expand the definition for random variables such as Eq.Â (1.53) and take as arguments two time instants of a random process. For example, for a complex-valued discrete-time process the covariance is









 cX[n,l] = ğ”¼  [(X[n] âˆ’ Î¼[n])(X[n + l] âˆ’ Î¼[n + l])âˆ—]. 


(B.73)








Stationarity, cyclostationarity and ergodicity

 

A random process is a powerful model. Hence, an important question is what information is necessary to fully characterize it. Take the 7 Ã— 5 matrix in ExampleÂ B.2: this data does not fully characterize the random process because it consists of only five realizations (tossing a coin five times does not allow to estimate its probability of heads robustly). We would need an infinite number of realizations if we insist in characterizing it in a tabular form. The most convenient alternative is to describe it through pdfs. We should be able to indicate, for all time t, the pdf of X(t). Besides, for each time pair (t,s), the joint pdf f(X(t),X(s)) should be known.
The same for the pdf f(X(t),X(s),X(r)) of each triple (t,s,r) and so on. It can be noted that a general random process requires a considerable amount of statistics to be fully described. So, it is natural to define particular and simpler cases of random processes as discussed in the sequel.



An important property of a random process is the stationarity of a statistics, which means this statistics is time-invariant even though the process is random. More specifically, a process is called n-th order stationary if the joint distribution of any set of n of its random variables is independent of absolute time values, depending only on relative time.



A first-order stationary process has the same pdf f(X(t)),âˆ€ â¡t (similar is valid for discrete-time). Consequently, it has a constant mean









 ğ”¼[X(t)] = Î¼,âˆ€ â¡t, 


(B.74)






constant variance and other moments such as ğ”¼[X4(t)].



A second-order stationary process has the same joint pdf f(X(t),X(s)) = f(X(t + Ï„),X(s + Ï„)),âˆ€ â¡t,s. Consequently, its autocorrelation is









 RX(Ï„) = ğ”¼[X(t + Ï„)X(t)], 


(B.75)






where the time difference Ï„ = s âˆ’ t is called the lag and has the same unit as t in X(t). Note that, in general, RX(t,Ï„) of Eq.Â (B.71) depends on two parameters: t and Ï„. However, for a stationary process, Eq.Â (B.75) depends only on the lag Ï„ because, given Ï„, RX(t,Ï„) = RX(Ï„) is the same for all values of t.



Similarly, if a discrete-time process is second-order stationary, RX[n,l] Eq.Â (B.72) can be simplified to









 RX[l] = ğ”¼[X[n]X[n + l]], 


(B.76)






where l = n2 âˆ’ n1 is the lag.



A third-order stationary process has joint pdfs f(X(t1),X(t2),X(t3)) that do not depend on absolute time values (t1,t2,t3) and so on. A random process X(t) is said to be strict-sense stationary (SSS) or simply stationary if any joint pdf f(X(t1),â€¦,X(tn)) is invariant to a translation by a delay Ï„. A random process with realizations that consist of i. i. d.Â random variables (called an i. i. d. process) is SSS. A random process that is not SSS is referred to as a non-stationary process even if some of its statistics have the stationarity property.



The SSS process has very stringent requirements, which are hard to verify. Hence, many real-world signals are modeled as having a weaker form of stationarity called wide-sense stationarity.



Basically, a wide-sense stationary (WSS) process has a mean that does not vary over time and an autocorrelation that does not depend on absolute time, as indicated in Eq.Â (B.74) and Eq.Â (B.75), respectively. Broadly speaking, wide-sense theory deals with moments
(mean, variance, etc.) while strict-sense deals with probability distributions. Note that SSS implies WSS but the converse is not true in general, with Gaussian processes being a famous exception.



For example, the process corresponding to FigureÂ B.13 is not WSS: its autocorrelation does not depend only on the time difference Ï„.



 Example B.5. The autocorrelation matrix of a WSS process is Toeplitz. For a WSS process, elements RX(i,j) of its autocorrelation matrix depend only on the absolute difference |i âˆ’ j| and, therefore, the matrix is Toeplitz. In this example, the function toeplitz.m is used to visualize the corresponding autocorrelation matrix as an image. For example, the command Rx=toeplitz(1:4) generates the following real-valued matrix:

Â Rx=[1Â Â Â Â Â 2Â Â Â Â Â 3Â Â Â Â Â 4
Â Â Â Â Â 2Â Â Â Â Â 1Â Â Â Â Â 2Â Â Â Â Â 3
Â Â Â Â Â 3Â Â Â Â Â 2Â Â Â Â Â 1Â Â Â Â Â 2
Â Â Â Â Â 4Â Â Â Â Â 3Â Â Â Â Â 2Â Â Â Â Â 1].



Usually, the elements of the main diagonal correspond to RX(0) = ğ”¼[X2[n]].



To visualize a larger matrix, FigureÂ B.17 was generated with Rxx=toeplitz(14:-1:4).








FigureÂ B.17: Representation of a WSS autocorrelation matrix that depends only on the lag l.





Given the redundancy in FigureÂ B.17, one can observe that for a WSS, it suffices to describe RX(l) for each value of the lag l. Â Â â–¡



A cyclostationary process is a non-stationary process having statistical properties that vary periodically (cyclically) with time. In some sense it is a weaker manifestation of a stationarity property. Cyclostationary processes are further discussed in AppendixÂ B.20.1.



A given statistics (variance, autocorrelation, etc.) of a random process is ergodic if its time average is equal to the ensemble average. For example, an i. i. d.Â random process is ergodic in the mean.6 And, loosely speaking, a WSS is ergodic in both mean and autocorrelation if its autocovariance decays to zero.7



A process could be called â€œergodicâ€ if all ensemble and time averages are interchangeable. However, it is more pedagogical to consider ergodicity as a property of specific statistics, and always inform them.8 Even non-stationary or cyclostationary processes can be ergodic in specific statistics such as the mean. FigureÂ B.18 depicts the suggested taxonomy of random processes using a Venn diagram.








FigureÂ B.18: Suggested taxonomy of random processes. SSS are sometimes called stationary and all processes that are not SSS are called non-stationary.





 Example B.6. Polar and unipolar bitstreams modeled as WSS processes. This example is based on processes used in digital communications to represent sequences of bits. Note that, after these bit streams are upsampled in order to create line codes, they become cyclostationary processes. This issue is discussed in AppendixÂ B.20.1, while here the sequences are not upsampled.



FigureÂ B.19 illustrates two processes for which the main diagonal RX[1,1] = RX[2,2] = RX[3,3]â€¦ has the same values. The process (a) (left-most) is called a unipolar line code and consists of sequences with equiprobable values 0 and 1, while for the second process (called polar) the values are  âˆ’ 1 and 1.



For the unipolar and polar cases, the theoretical correlations RX[n1,n2] for n1 = n2 are 0.5 and 1, respectively. The result is obtained by observing that RX[n1,n2] = RX[n1,n1] = ğ”¼[X[n1]2] and for the unipolar case, X[n1]2 is 0 or 1. Because the two values are equiprobable, ğ”¼[X[n1]2] = 0.5. For the polar case, X[n1]2 = 1 always and ğ”¼[X[n1]2] = 1. The values of RX[n1,n2] for n1â‰ n2 are obtained by observing the values of all possible products X[n1]X[n2]. For the unipolar case, the possibilities are 0 Ã— 0 = 0, 0 Ã— 1 = 0, 1 Ã— 0 = 0 and 1 Ã— 1 = 1, all with probability 1/4 each. Hence, for this unipolar example, ğ”¼[X[n1]X[n2]] = (3 Ã— 0 + 1 Ã— 1)âˆ•4 = 0.25,n1â‰ n2. For the polar case, the possibilities are  âˆ’ 1 Ã—âˆ’1 = 1,  âˆ’ 1 Ã— 1 = 1, 1 Ã—âˆ’1 = âˆ’1 and 1 Ã— 1 = 1, all with probability 1/4 each. Hence, for this polar example, ğ”¼[X[n1]X[n2]] = (2 Ã—âˆ’1 + 2 Ã— 1)âˆ•4 = 0,n1â‰ n2.



In summary, for the polar code RX[n1,n2] = 1 for n1 = n2 and 0 otherwise. For the unipolar code, RX[n1,n2] = 0.5 for n1 = n2 and 0.25 otherwise.








FigureÂ B.19: Correlation for random sequences with two equiprobable values: a) values are 0 and 1 (unipolar), b) values are  âˆ’ 1 and 1 (polar).





A careful observation of FigureÂ B.19 indicates that two dimensions are not necessary and it suffices to describe RX[l] as in Eq.Â (B.72). As discussed previously, in the case of WSS processes, the correlation depends only on the difference between the â€œtimeâ€ instants n1 and n2. FigureÂ B.20 emphasizes this aspect using another representation for the polar case in FigureÂ B.19.








FigureÂ B.20: Alternative representation of the correlation values for the polar case of FigureÂ B.19.





Because the polar and unipolar processes that were used to derive FigureÂ B.19 are WSS, ListingÂ B.7 can be used to take advantage of having RX[n1,n2] depending only on the lag and convert this matrix to an array RX[l].



ListingÂ B.7: MatlabOctaveFunctions/ak_convertToWSSCorrelation.m


function [Rxx_tau, lags] = ak_convertToWSSCorrelation(Rxx) 
% function [Rxx_tau,lags]=ak_convertToWSSCorrelation(Rxx) 
%Convert Rxx[n1,n2] into Rxx[k], assuming process is 
%wide-sense stationary (WSS). 
5%Input: Rxx -> matrix with Rxx[n1,n2] 
%Outputs: Rxx_tau[lag] and lag=n2-n1. 
[M,N]=size(Rxx); %M is assumed to be equal to N 
lags=-N:N; %lags 
numLags = length(lags); %number of lags 
10Rxx_tau = zeros(1,numLags); %pre-allocate space 
for k=1:numLags; 
Â Â Â Â lag = lags(k); counter = 0; %initialize 
Â Â Â Â for n1=1:N 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â n2=n1+lag; %from: lag = n2 - n1 
15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â if n2<1 || n2>N %check 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â continue; %skip if out of range 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â end 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Rxx_tau(k) = Rxx_tau(k) + Rxx(n1,n2); %update 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â counter = counter + 1; %update 
20Â Â Â Â end 
Â Â Â Â if counter ~= 0 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Rxx_tau(k) = Rxx_tau(k)/counter; %normalize 
Â Â Â Â end 
end
  


FigureÂ B.21 was generated using ListingÂ B.7 for the data in FigureÂ B.19.








FigureÂ B.21: One-dimensional ACF RX[l] for the data corresponding to FigureÂ B.19 (unipolar and polar codes).





If ergodicity can be assumed, a single realization of the process can be used to estimate the ACF. FigureÂ B.22 was generated using the code below, which generates a single realization of each process:


numSamples=1000; 
Xunipolar=floor(2*rand(1,numSamples)); %r.v. 0 or 1 
[Rxx,lags]=xcorr(Xunipolar,9,'unbiased');%Rxx for unipolar 
subplot(121); stem(lags,Rxx) title('Unipolar'); 
5Xpolar=2*[floor(2*rand(1,numSamples))-0.5]; %r.v. -1 or 1 
[Rxx,lags]=xcorr(Xpolar,9,'unbiased'); %Rxx for polar code 
subplot(122); stem(lags,Rxx) title('Polar');


Increasing the number of samples to numSamples=1e6 achieves estimation errors smaller than in FigureÂ B.22.








FigureÂ B.22: ACF estimated using ergodicity and waveforms with 1,000 samples for each process. The theoretical values are 0.25 and 0.5 (at l = 0) for unipolar, while for polar these values are 0 and 1.



Â Â â–¡

B.20.1Â Â Cyclostationary random processes



This section aims at providing some intuition about cyclostationarity. More information can be found e. g. in [?,?,?].



A discrete-time process X[n] is wide-sense cyclostationary (WSC) if, and only if, exists an integer period P > 0 such that the mean and correlation are periodic (consequently, the covariance is periodic too), as summarized by:



 Î¼X[n]  = Î¼X[n + P]Â Â and   RX[n,l]  = RX[n + P,l]. (B.77)  

Note that the correlation is periodic but a cyclostationary process generates realizations that are random and not periodic. To avoid confusion, the period P in Eq.Â (B.77) of a WSC process is referred to as its cycle.



Because WSC are more common than strict-sense cyclostationary processes, the term cyclostationary is assumed here to correspond to a WSC (wide, not strict sense), as adopted inÂ Â [?], which is the main reference for the discussion presented in the sequel. In order to better understand WSC processes, it is useful to review the concepts of non-stationary processes in AppendixÂ B.20 and get familiar with representations such as the ones in FigureÂ B.15 and FigureÂ B.16. While WSS processes have autocorrelations depending only on one parameter, the lag l, WSC correlations depend on two parameters (RX[n,l]) and this is a key factor for the following discussion.



Note that Eq.Â (B.77) implies the correlation RX[n,l] in Eq.Â (B.72) is periodic in n for each â€œlagâ€ l. In other words, given a lag value l0, the time-series RX[n,l0] over the â€œabsolute time instantâ€ n is periodic. Hence, it can be represented using a DTFS in which the Fourier coefficients CX[k,l] are called cyclic correlations. Therefore, when RX[n,l] has a period of P samples over n, the following Fourier pair can be used:









 RX[n,l] = âˆ‘ k=0Pâˆ’1C X[k,l]ej2Ï€ P nk â‡” C X[k,l] = 1 Pâˆ‘ n=0Pâˆ’1R X[k,l]eâˆ’j2Ï€ P nk. 


(B.78)







RX[n,l] is also called time-varying correlation and instantaneous correlation.



As explained in [?], sampling a continuous-time periodic signal may lead to an almost periodic signal for which Eq.Â (1.39) does not hold. This occurs in the so-called wide-sense almost cyclostationary processes, in which RX[n,l] has the following generalized Fourier series:









 RX[n,l] = âˆ‘ Î±kâˆˆCCX[Î±k,l]ejÎ±kn â‡” C X[Î±k,l] = lim â¡  Nâ†’âˆ 1 Nâˆ‘ n=0Pâˆ’1R X(k,l)eâˆ’jÎ±kn, 


(B.79)






where C is the set C = {Î±k : CX[Î±k,l]â‰ 0,âˆ’Ï€ â‰¤ Î±k < Ï€} of cycles.



The estimation of both CX[k,l] and CX[Î±k,l] is often done with FFTs and, consequently, both periodic and almost periodic realizations are treated similarly. Hereafter, the notation CX[Î±k,l] is also adopted for CX[k,l].



For a given cycle Î±k, the evolution of CX[Î±k,l] over the lags l can be interpreted over frequency using its DTFT to define the cyclic spectrum:









 SX(Î±k,Î©) = âˆ‘ l=âˆ’âˆâˆC X[Î±k,l]eâˆ’jÎ©l. 


(B.80)






In summary, while stationary discrete-time signals are analyzed using PSDs in frequency-domain (Î©) and time-invariant correlations in lag-domain (l), non-stationary signals include also the time (n) and cycle (Î±) domains. FigureÂ B.23 illustrates the relations.








FigureÂ B.23: Functions used to characterize cyclostationary processes. FS stands for â€œgeneralized Fourier seriesâ€, useful for representing â€œalmost periodicâ€ discrete-time signals (Adapted from Fig. 17.1 of [?] to include the notation adopted in this text and the one widely used byÂ Â [?]).





As further discussed in SectionÂ B.20.3, a cyclostationary process can be converted into a WSS through the â€œuniform shiftâ€ or â€œuniformly randomizing the phaseâ€Â Â [?].



The following example aims at making these concepts more concrete.



 Example B.7. Example: WGN modulated by sinusoid. Assume Î½[n] represents a realization of an i. i. d.Â white Gaussian noise process with variance Ïƒ2 . Each realization is modulated by a carrier of frequency Î©c and phase Ï• (both in radians) leading to9









 x[n] = Î½[n]cos â¡ (Î©cn + Ï•). 


(B.81)






The top plot in FigureÂ B.24 illustrates a single realization of x[n], as generated by ListingÂ B.8. It can be seen that the sinusoid is â€œburiedâ€ in noise. All M=5000 realizations are stored in matrix X. The ensemble variance for each â€œtimeâ€ instant n is shown in the bottom plot of FigureÂ B.24, indicating that the variance has a period Pâˆ•2 (in this case, 15 samples, given that P=30) because it depends on the absolute value of the sinusoid amplitude at instant n. This can be also seen from the correlation of x[n] over time, as discussed in the sequel.



ListingÂ B.8: MatlabOctaveCodeSnippets/snip_appprobability_modulatednoise.m


M=5000; %number of realizations for ensemble statistics 
N=1000; %number of samples of each realization 
P=30; %sinusoid period (in samples) 
X=zeros(N,M); %pre-allocate space 
5Wc=2*pi/P; Phc=pi/5; %carrier frequency and phase, both in radians 
n=0:N-1; carrier=transpose(cos(Wc*n+Phc)); %same for all realizations 
%carrier(carrier>0)=1; carrier(carrier<0)=-1; %if wants square wave 
for m=1:M %for each realization 
Â Â Â Â X(:,m)=randn(N,1).*carrier; %WGN modulated by sinusoidal carrier 
10end
  







FigureÂ B.24: Single realization x[n] of Eq.Â (B.81) (top) and the ensemble variance over time (bottom plot), which has a period of Pâˆ•2 = 15Â samples.





From Eq.Â (B.72), the correlation of x[n] is



 RX[n,l]  = ğ”¼  [Î½[n]cos â¡ (Î©cn + Ï•)Î½[n + l]cos â¡ (Î©c(n + l) + Ï•)]     = cos â¡ (Î©cn + Ï•)cos â¡ (Î©c(n + l) + Ï•)ğ”¼  [Î½[n]Î½[n + l]] = cos â¡ 2(Î© cn + Ï•)Ïƒ2Î´[l]     = Ïƒ2 2  (1 + cos â¡ (2Î©cn + 2Ï•))Î´[l], (B.82)  

which is depicted in FigureÂ B.25(b). The value of Î´[l] is 1 for all n when l = 0 and zero otherwise. Note that FigureÂ B.25(a) is the alternative representation with a pair of absolute time instants [n1,n2].
